DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Delegation to Canada and the United States of America

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrews Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I present the report of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to Canada and the United States of America, April 1995. I seek leave to make a short statement in connection with the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In April of this year a delegation of this parliament led by the President of the Senate, Senator Michael Beahan, visited Canada and the United States of America. Apart from myself, the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) and the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Griffiths) were the members of this place who were on that delegation. The delegation had a broad threefold purpose: first, to assess the political developments in the United States, in particular since the 1994 congressional elections, which returned a majority to the Republican Party in both the Senate and the House of Representatives; secondly, to promote trade between Australia, the United States and Canada, particularly agricultural trade by Australia—in that context we were most interested in the progress of the United States Farm Bill through the congress; and, thirdly, to promote Australia as the location for regional headquarters for the United States and Canadian companies operating in Asia.

PARA.TAB: The delegation visited Ottawa for three days, where we met with many officials, including an almost hour-long meeting with the Rt Hon. Jean Chretien, the Prime Minister of Canada, the Hon. Roy MacLaren, the Minister for Trade and the Hon. Raymond Chan, the Secretary of State for the Asia-Pacific. The visit marked the centenary of trading agreements between Australia and Canada. Unfortunately our time in Canada was limited because of parliamentary terms in the three countries and the need to try to visit both Ottawa and Washington while the respective parliaments and congresses were in session.

Our visit to Washington coincided with one of the most remarkable periods in recent United States history. As honourable members will know, on 8 November 1994 Bill Clinton's presidency suffered a massive blow from a landslide Republican victory in the mid-term congressional elections. The Republican Party regained control in the Senate, which they had last held in 1986, and won a majority in the House of Representatives for the first time since 1954. The elections yielded both the first Republican dominated congress in 40 years and the worst performance by the Democratic Party since 1946. Some assessments credited the change to an anti-incumbency mood within the American electorate, but the fact remains that no incumbent Republican lost a seat.

A number of reasons for the massive swing against the Democratic Party have been advanced. However, there can be little doubt that President Clinton's administration was also a major factor in the result. As a consequence of these elections President Clinton lost control of the domestic political agenda to the Republicans, with the new Speaker of the House of Representatives, Newt Gingrich, quickly moving to fill the policy void by promising to enact his election manifesto, the so-called `Contract with America', in the first hundred days of the new congress, which commenced on 1 January 1995. Key elements of the contract include a balanced budget amendment to the constitution, term limits for federal politicians, large income and capital gains tax cuts, large welfare spending cuts, increased defence spending and a presidential line item veto on all expenditure bills.

The members of the delegation were in Washington during the last few days of the 100 days legislative program. While most of the contract was passed by the House of Representatives, including legislation to preclude the federal government mandating programs or regulations upon a state without funding, two items were rejected—namely, the balanced budget amendment and term limits for politicians. While the major part of the contract passed through the House of Representatives, its progress since then has not been guaranteed in the Senate. The final outcome may have a lot to do with jockeying in the American election presidential campaign as much as any other factor. However, it has demonstrated a marked change in American politics over the last two years. As Governor Evan Bayh, the chairman of the Democratic Governors Association said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is apparent that there was a tidal wave running across the country and it hit the State House just as it hit the U.S. House. The American people are disenchanted with Governments. They don't want big government, bureaucracy or higher taxes, and they want to see progress towards solving the problems they encounter in their daily lives.

During our visit, we were honoured to meet with the Vice President of the United States, Al Gore, representative Pat Roberts, the chair of the House Agricultural Committee, and representative Kika Garza, the minority member of the House Agricultural Committee, to talk about progress so far as the farm bill is concerned and to advance Australia's agricultural concerns. We also met with a series of other people in Washington, including members of leading think tanks such as the Heritage Foundation, the Cato Institute, Bill Kristol, the chairman of the Committee for a Republican Future, and Peter Hart, the leading Democratic Party pollster in Washington. The coalition members were also able to attend the Republican conference, the equivalent of our party meeting or caucus, which was addressed by Newt Gingrich.

PARA.TAB: I want to make some very brief observations in this limited time. I commend the report to honourable members and members of the Australian public. The first relates to Chicago, where we visited. Chicago, which is in the state of Illinois, is the commercial centre of the mid-west of America. It is one area in which there is greatest trade between Australia and the United States. If one looks at exports to Australia by state, Illinois is second only to California. When you take in surrounding states such as Ohio, Michigan, Wisconsin, Indiana and Minnesota, you see that that part of mid-west America is the centre of the most trade between Australia and the United States of America.

We visited the futures market, the Environment Protection Agency, major corporations such as Motorola and McDonald's, and looked with a trade emphasis on Chicago. What surprised us was that Australia only has an honorary consulate at Chicago. Whereas there was previously an office with a staff of 27, Australia's interests in what is probably one of major parts of trading activities between Australia and the rest of the world are represented by one person, an honorary consul. Whilst we are not in any way decrying the activities of the honorary consul—we were most impressed by the activities of Mrs Joan Miller—it seemed totally absurd to all members of the delegation that this was the way in which Australia had representation in that part of the world, considering our great interests in it. There is an unanimous recommendation from the delegation that the government look to reopening a full consulate in Chicago.

Secondly, we visited Boston. I want to say something in particular about our visit to Harvard University, where there is a chair in Australian studies. We were interested to hear about two aspects of the chair. The first is whether the funding of the endowment is realistic in light of change in the value of $1 million from when the endowment was made in 1976, and the second is whether the outcomes are consistent with the aims of the endowment. Casual conversations cannot replace a proper inquiry. The delegation noted that the discussions it held at Harvard raised questions about the funding and direction of the Australian studies chair.

The purpose of promoting awareness and understanding of Australia and the United States of America is worthy, even an essential aim, but can it be maximised with a $1 million capital purse? There seems to be doubt about this and doubts in our mind about the focus of the chair. We have recommended that the Australian government appoint a committee to review the funding administration of the Australian studies chair at Harvard. The review should ensure that the chair remains relevant to the Australian-United States relationship. In that context, I noted recently the establishment of an Australian-New Zealand studies centre at Georgetown University in America. I believe that that ought to be commended as an activity and a focus within the central part of government in America—namely, Washington.

In the remaining moments available to me, I will reflect on the third aspect, which is the relationship between Australia and the United States. In the period since the end of the Second World War, every President from Dwight Eisenhower to George Bush, eight in all, served in the defence forces and therefore, in one way or another, had a connection with and a knowledge of Australia. President Bill Clinton is the first President since the end of the Second World War who does not fulfil that criteria, which in itself reflects a passing of a generation.

Therefore, in order to maintain our connection with the United States of America, it is necessary not simply to rely in this 50th anniversary of the end of the Second World War on what happened during that war but, indeed, to renew that acquaintance and renew those ties in a very real way. We believe that these delegations every two years are important to do that. We would encourage Americans to come to Australia. We believe that they ought to be led by either the Speaker of the House of Representatives or the President of the Senate, giving some sense of the importance that we place on this relationship between Australia and the United States.

Finally, may I extend my thanks to a number of people: High Commissioner Murray in Ottawa; Ambassador Russell in Washington; and, particularly, the Congressional Liaison Officer, Bob Tyson, who oversaw our delegation; Honorary Consuls Joan Miller in Chicago, Margaret Stanzler in Boston, and Mr Stephen Brown of Vorys Sater Seymour and Pease who arranged the visits to Columbus and Cleveland, Ohio; and Judy Middlebrook, the assiduous secretary of the delegation. Finally, I extend my thanks to all the members of our very harmonious delegation under the leadership of the President of the Senate. I commend the report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walker The Hon F.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed works be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Redevelopment of Woolshed site, Barton, ACT.

SPEECH.PARA: The new building will replace unsatisfactory accommodation, which is currently used by the Department of Industrial Relations, in three separate locations in the city. The new accommodation will enable the DIR to co-locate in an efficient, modern office building which will facilitate improvement in the efficiency and effectiveness of the operations of the department.

PARA.TAB: The development of the proposed site, blocks 12 and 13, section 9, Barton, will be undertaken in the following manner. The construction of a four storey office building with 12,800 square metres of net lettable area, basement and roof plant rooms. The construction of a three-level structured car park to accommodate 305 vehicles. Included in the car park will be 350 square metres of retail space, including food services. Associated engineering and landscape works will include 197 surface car parking spaces and a plaza, with paving adjacent to the retail area. The building will be designed to provide safe and suitable facilities and accommodation for the Department of Industrial Relations. It will result in the rationalisation of the department's functions in one building.

The outturn cost of the project is $38.822 million and is inclusive of base building fit out and structured car park fees, holding costs, contingencies and escalation. If parliamentary approval is obtained, construction can commence in June 1996 with the project being completed by December 1997. I commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

That the bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is sad to see the ANL Sale Bill 1995 come before the parliament. Along with my colleagues the member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), the member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) and the member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris), I am very reluctant to support such a bill because of the ramifications it has for shipping. It is sad to think that we will lose ANL, our national line. There is a good position for supporting the reconstruction of ANL, to throw off the old cast and build a new sleek, efficient and fast service which would serve Australia and Australian business in the future.

PARA.TAB: The unions have agreed to this course of action. They have also agreed to put forward new ideas and concentrate on the routes that are important to us and can make money for us and drop those that are no longer economically viable in terms of competing with other lines. When you look at those lines and the ships of shame you come to realise how bad those lines are and find that it is the lowest common denominator that is driving the price of shipping throughout the world today. There are some shipping companies that strive for decent ships and there are those which make it very hard for the good ones to go forward and make a profit, and this is due to the quality of these ships of shame.

This bill makes me unhappy, as did the legislation relating to the sale of the Commonwealth Bank. We are selling off the assets which are part of people's heritage. My electorate takes in the west coast of Tasmania. That is the area King O'Malley represented in the early parliament of our country. King O'Malley fought for and put together the Commonwealth Bank. It was very sad for me to see that bill go through the parliament. It is very interesting that King O'Malley was a teetotaller and yet spoke in many places—including the balcony of Hunters Hotel in Main Street, Queenstown. The only plaque that I can find of him is on Hunters Hotel in Queenstown. I spoke to representatives of the Commonwealth Bank some years ago about having a statue of King O'Malley erected. They did not seem to be overly interested in giving their founding father the recognition I felt he deserved.

The working people of Australia have invested their assets in ANL and the Commonwealth Bank. These are the assets of the working people of our country. ANL is part of that. I have always been concerned that not enough of our export commodities—and we are an exporting nation; we have exported since nationhood—have been carried in Australian owned ships. We have only carried two or three per cent of those commodities out of Australia in Australian owned ships. This has to have a major effect on our economy and our trade figures. All the other business that is associated with foreign ships taking away our commodities—that is, the associated insurance and so on—must go against Australia's trade figures.

As a nation we should be building ships. That should be very high on our agenda. I think it is a shame for the capital markets of Australia that they have not been able to build up a major shipbuilding industry for our country. When you look at what we have done with the commodities we export such as coal, wheat and wool, it is shame that we lack a shipbuilding industry. I certainly hope things will emerge in future which will help this situation. I do not think selling ANL is the right way of achieving that goal.

A considerable amount of work has been done into the development of new breeds of ships that can do 60 to 80 knots. If this becomes a reality in the future, it would transform shipping. These are concepts and ideas at the moment that I know people are looking at. But that sort of shipping would certainly compete with air transport in the future.

In Tasmania we have had Incat develop the fast catamaran industry into a very successful exporter. In some areas those ships work very efficiently. The industry has added greatly to the economy of southern Tasmania. The government has been able to assist Incat in its training programs through Working Nation being utilised in that area. We have been able to put people into training positions at Incat, which is very positive not only for those individuals but also for that company's future. There is nothing so gratifying than to see people who have been out of work for three years ending up in a training position where they will learn new skills such as aluminium welding, which is on the edge of new technology.

In Tasmania we also have new emerging industries in horticulture, with many innovations taking place. We certainly rely on having shipping from our shores not only to reach the markets of Melbourne and Sydney with our fresh produce but also to link into the overseas transport infrastructure that will take our goods overseas and into the emerging markets of Asia. It is very important to the Tasmanian economy that we have efficient shipping and transport services from our shores.

By not having our own ships, goods are at the whim of the international shipping market. We also have no window to see what is happening in international shipping and our national interest is lost. Any influence that Australia could have on change is also lost. By selling ANL we lose the opportunity of having that window into the world of international shipping, which I think is a great shame. The Japanese are very good at having an integrated system in their businesses. I have seen the way that the Japanese system operates in both the meat industry and the coal industry in Australia. The Japanese buy into a variety of areas so that they know exactly where the costs are and what the industries are about. By not having ANL in this country, we are going exactly the other way.

In Australia we should set a high standard in our shipping. We should not accept the ships of shame as being the norm for international shipping. There are many problems when these flags of convenience countries—flags of shame, I call them—are setting some of the standards which are driving international shipping. We should not accept that. I have no hesitation in saying that Australia should be a leader with the standards that we set in shipping. We should not put up with shortcomings, particularly in safety, in a shipping company's mode of practice.

The argument is about having a shipping line which is owned by Australia, employing Australians and having the highest standard of safety and efficiency, and being responsible to one's shipping line's flag and to one's country, so we have the conditions applying that are the normal conditions in the Australian work force. It can be seen as being the Australian way in the ports around the world. It means a lot to Australia, with a strong maritime history of hundreds of years. By selling ANL, we are selling a great part of our history. If the maritime unions and the ACTU and P&O are unable to reach agreement on Australian conditions of employment and employment of Australian crews cannot take place, the bill will not go any further.

I wish the negotiations well. But I am very sad that we are going down this track and not a restructuring track. If the talks fail, hopefully we will be able to restructure ANL to make it the Australian national line once again. That could be done under new circumstances when, heading towards the year 2000, a lot of people of goodwill will be working towards an Australian line. It is with some deprecation that I am here. I will support the passage of the bill through the parliament. As I said, I hope the talks go well. However, if they fail we will be endeavouring to restructure ANL.
Question put:
That the the bill be now read a second time.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.
Bill—by leave—taken as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Mrs B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday we heard some interesting debate from the Labor Party dissidents. We heard from Colin Hollis, who put out a press release in these terms—

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Rocher)—Order! The honourable member will refer to members by their correct titles. I believe you are referring to the member for Throsby.

TALK.START.PARA: —Indeed he is. The member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) put out a press release yesterday saying:

SPEECH.PARA: I am opposed to the Bill—I do not support what the Government is doing. It is wrong for us as a Party—it is wrong for shipping—it is wrong for Australians—and one day people will recognise this.

I do not know how the member for Throsby expects the Australian people to be convinced by his arguments when he declines the opportunity to cross the floor and vote with the opposition. Indeed, these are the tactics the Labor Party has with many of its members. They feel disenfranchised and disillusioned by the Labor Party and are trying to hold themselves out as being independents in their own electorates when they are really the Keating candidates—the Keating members without whom the Prime Minister, the member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), cannot be in power.

PARA.TAB: So it is most disappointing to see that the member for Throsby simply did not have the courage of his convictions to cross the floor when he had the opportunity. We provided that opportunity to the member specifically so that he could show his credentials were good and honest. He said that this was wrong in his belief, that he did not support the bill and that he did not support the government, but he did not have the courage of his convictions.

At the end of the day, like all other Labor Party members who say that they are independents fighting for their electorate, when they get an opportunity to make their point by crossing the floor to give credence and evidence to what they say, they fail. Why is that? Is it because the Prime Minister of the day excites such fear and loathing among his colleagues that they fear that, if they cross the floor and give true expression to what they say, they will be expelled? That is the point. Under the Labor Party regime, they are totally and utterly unable to represent the interests of their own constituencies because they are not afforded the right to cross the floor when they believe in something with such passion. The member for Throsby obviously felt so strongly about it yesterday during his speech that he put out a press release which further stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Hollis defended the former ANL board sacked by his Ministerial colleague, Laurie Brereton, saying that the Board had never received a fair go, commitments made to them were never honoured, they had been undermined and expected to perform with one hand tied behind their back.
We are hearing plenty about exactly that in the current Senate hearings. We also heard from Mr Sedgwick, the head of the Department of Finance, who admitted:
My understanding is that each of the cabinet decisions which were relevant here were communicated to ANL, including the decision to sell 100 per cent.
He then went on to reply to the following question:
Did you, in fact, properly inform the board of the change of the sale arrangements from 49 per cent to 100 per cent—

Because Mr Bolitho gave evidence, in fact, that they were not told that the information was leaked. Yesterday, I quoted from that cabinet minute and I dealt with the question of whether or not the minister had acted within the authority of that cabinet minute—a point that the ASC is duty bound to inquire into.

PARA.TAB: The other thing I did yesterday was to seek reassurances from the government on four undertakings relating to the nature and the structure of the bill, particularly the $15 million appropriation, the real purpose of which is not disclosed by the legislation. The manner in which the bill is constructed can allow for secret payments to be made which could include secret payments to the trade unions which would never be disclosed to this parliament.

It is simply not acceptable to have legislation come before this parliament whereby we appropriate money and are never able to tell exactly the manner in which it is expended because of the way the legislation is framed. For all those reasons, we have voted against the bill on the second reading and will pursue these matters in the Senate. But I would again ask the government to answer my request for the four undertakings as set out in my speech during the second reading debate yesterday.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not take up the time of the House in the consideration in detail of the ANL Sale Bill. The honourable member for Mackellar (Mrs Bishop) is correct in what she said—I do feel passionate about this. What is wrong with feeling passionately about something?

PARA.TAB: I thought very carefully about not crossing the floor, because what the opposition is promising is even worse. What the government is doing is bad enough. If the opposition were just going to vote against the sale of ANL and its restructure, you would have had me over there this morning. But look at the opposition's track record—its constant abuse of the Maritime Union of Australia and its constant undermining of ANL.

You talk about what I said in my press release and in my speech during the second reading debate. Ever since I have been in this House, I have had a track record in that 12 years of supporting the Maritime Union of Australia, supporting their restructuring and, indeed, supporting ANL. As the honourable member for Lyons (Mr Adams) said, I do believe that we should have a viable shipbuilding industry in Australia.

It is essential that we maintain the ANL, an Australian flag carrier and Australian crewed shipping. So let us not hear any more of this hypocrisy. If you people are serious and you want to maintain public ownership of ANL and support the Maritime Union, I will be with you—and I will cross the floor on it. But don't give me any more cant and hypocrisy about what you are going to do.

Don't worry about me calling myself a Keating member. Comrades, when you are standing on a 26 per cent margin, it doesn't matter what you call yourself, you're still going to be elected—as I will be at the next federal election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have had a very interesting debate on the ANL Sale Bill. We have seen a large number of members opposite, including the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown), the honourable member for Lyons (Mr Adams)—and no doubt many other members of the government—totally opposed to what has been happening in respect of the sale of ANL.

PARA.TAB: We, of course, are opposed to the way in which the government is seeking to use the parliament as a sausage machine to pump this legislation through prior to the election, obviously with a view to dampening down continued unhappiness in its ranks. We are in favour of privatisation of ANL. We believe that a private organisation could operate such an Australian line competitively and efficiently in such a way that it has a chance of succeeding. But since 1991 the government has announced that it will sell ANL. In that time it was absolutely not disputed that ANL had a net worth of at least $100 million.

But, since the minister's infamous comments in August 1994 when he said, basically, `You couldn't give it away,' we have found a massive devaluation in the value of ANL, and we now find that the remnant assets of ANL will be sold for a mere $19.5 million. The government has basically had its cake taken away from it, so there will not be anything at all left to eat.

On the one hand, those members of the government who believe in the traditional Labor principles of government enterprise will have one of their icons taken from them, one of their icons will disappear; ANL will no longer be in public ownership. On the other hand, because of the way the minister has talked down the company, the marketplace has decided that ANL is worth almost nothing at all.

We find that this bill includes two appropriations, one whereby a massive amount of $15 million will be put into the pot as an inducement to ensure that P&O goes ahead with the purchase, and another unspecified appropriation which will last for a period of about 12 months. Although this government has announced, for four or five years successively, that ANL will be sold, there has been massive opposition in the government ranks. Yet we find, at the end of the day, that all the government will be able to get from the remnant assets is the amount of $19.5 million.

This Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) is an absolute disgrace. He has failed this nation in a number of areas. In the industrial relations area he brought in a bill which has done absolutely nothing to reduce the massively high unemployment levels. The bill has been so flawed that he has had to come into the parliament on many occasions to try to fix it up. This minister has indicated his incompetence, and his comments of August 1994 when he effectively reduced the value of ANL to $19.5 million indicate he is responsible for reducing the amount of money that the government will receive from the sale of ANL to P&O, if indeed that particular sale goes ahead.
As the honourable member for Mackellar (Mrs Bishop) mentioned, we heard the honourable member for Throsby say that he is totally opposed to what the government has been saying.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say I give the honourable member for Throsby the benefit of at least standing up and being prepared to say what his convictions are, but of course there is only one time when those convictions count, and that is when the bill is voted on here in the House of Representatives. The people of Australia, the so-called true believers in your electorate of Throsby, were in fact watching you, they were in fact watching the honourable member for Charlton and they were also watching other government members opposed to the sale of ANL because they wanted to know whether you were going to put your money where your mouth is.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Throsby has put out a very impressive media release, from which I will quote:

SPEECH.PARA: I am opposed to the Bill—I do not support what the Government is doing. It is wrong for us as a Party—it is wrong for shipping—it is wrong for Australians—and one day people will recognise this.
But in the vote this morning, only five or 10 minutes ago, the honourable member for Throsby had the opportunity of helping us to implement what he in fact said in his media release.

TALK.START.PARA: —But where were you when we sought your assistance to oppose what the government is doing? You went over there, you voted against your principles, because you know on your side of politics that you in fact have to be a party hack. You are not allowed to vote in this parliament in accordance with your principles, as we in the coalition are.

PARA.TAB: This government stands condemned. The Minister for Transport is incompetent. At the next election the people of Australia will see this government for what it is—an absolute, complete and unmitigated disaster.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to clarify my position in connection with this question as well. During my contribution to the ANL Sale Bill yesterday, I made it clear that I did not support and would not endorse the sale of ANL, and this morning I voted for the government's legislation. Let me make it perfectly clear that I did that because I accept the discipline of the caucus, I accept the nature of collective decisions which are made by political parties, and I believe it perfectly appropriate and absolutely necessary to our system of government for there to be discipline within parties, governments and opposition—and between them—and that that discipline, integrity, honesty and loyalty be maintained.

PARA.TAB: I want to make mention of an observation that was made by the member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) during his five-minute contribution at the consideration in detail stage. He made the claim that an off-the-cuff comment by the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) was responsible for what he claimed was a reduction in the market value of ANL, from a net worth of $100 million to its present sale price of something marginally in excess of $19 million. I do not believe in the member's more dispassionate moments that he would make that claim. It is a clever statement, but it is not a credible statement. To suggest that the private sector, to which the honourable member would aver some degree of allegiance, and the value assessors within the private sector are so stupid as to write down the value of ANL from something like $100 million to $19 million simply because of a simple off-the-cuff comment by the Minister for Transport seriously offends the competence and the judgment of people who are required to make such valuations.

I have emphasised previously that a whole series of quite clear problems and disadvantages will accompany the sale of ANL. What I want to emphasise in connection with that general issue is that, unless certain conditions are satisfied by the end of October, the sale will not proceed. It will remain as ANL and will undergo the option of restructuring. In my mind the prospect remains very strong indeed that, as a result of those provisions, there will be an opportunity for Australia to retain its own shipping line, for Australia to expand significantly the freight in and out of Australia which is carried by Australian flag vessels. We will not become a captive of foreign shipping lines, including the ships of shame, as a result of that or as a result of taking into consideration those international shipping conferences which bear so heavily on the important elements that influence Australia's trading capacity as one of the major commercial trading nations of the world and, unfortunately, one of the very minor maritime nations of the world.

We have had a maritime presence in Australia for 200 years, for the whole period of European settlement. It could well be that, as a result of these changes now, maritime involvement by Australia may become negligible. I hope not. For as long as we can see into the future, Australia will continue to be a major international commercial trading nation, and we need to be able to back that up with infrastructure that we own and control to ensure that the benefits to Australia are maximised. I believe that ANL can and should become a fundamental element in that whole process.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a very interesting debate that we are having here. Fancy the member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) and the member for Mackellar (Mrs Bishop) having the nerve to suggest that that was a real division; that they were dividing because they were opposed to the sale of ANL! It is an absolute disgrace for you to say that. Did you think I would come into this House, sit on your side and vote with you under the camouflage that I was in fact voting against privatisation? You know that you want to privatise ANL. You would not know a seafarer or a wharfie from a real estate agent or a mobile phone. My grandfather was a seafarer back in the early 1900s. He travelled the seas, was a first-class fireman and worked beneath deck, where it was nice and hot and life was rugged. He was in Colorado in 1913, two years before they executed Joe Hill, who I am sure would not be one of your heroes.

PARA.TAB: It is quite amazing to see the member for Mackellar spruiking about the member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), who at least had the guts to stand up and say he was opposed to privatisation. Of course, I would have liked to see the member for Throsby with an opportunity for a division on the issue. But, regrettably, the coalition did not offer the opportunity to divide on the issue. The member for Mackellar, with those crocodile tears, preening herself around the place, telling us that she is opposed to privatisation, is an absolute joke. What an absolute joke! You could not sell it fast enough. (Quorum formed) The member for Mackellar is a joke if she thinks that the division which she called was fair dinkum. It was not a division; it was just that she wanted to really pump up the privatisation issue, but under the camouflage of being a pro-public enterprise person—which we know she is not.

If it came to the Commonwealth Bank, she could not privatise it quickly enough; if it came to Telstra, that would be on the block as quick as a flash. Australia Post would be next. Who knows what we would have left if the member for Mackellar were still on the front bench in government. So it was a joke. TALK.START.PARA: —In all the years I have been here, I have never once heard the wharfies' friend the member for Fisher (Mr Slipper), or the member for that great maritime electorate, the member for Mackellar (Mrs Bishop), speak on a bill to do with Australian shipping or with the Maritime Union. Apart from the article in the Illawarra Mercury today commending my stand, none of the rest of the media carried it today. They were all more interested in the nonsense over the airport yesterday. You people are really at the bottom if you have to go grovelling through the press boxes, snivelling around this parliament in the middle of the night, trying to find out what government members have put out.

PARA.TAB: I did not send you a copy of my press release, and you did not get it from the Illawarra Mercury. The only place you got it from are the boxes up there. You people went grovelling around in the middle of the night through the press boxes pulling this one out, putting that one back in, pulling another one out—to see what little bit of information you could get. Well, it has backfired on you. I said at the end of my speech yesterday that I would be voting with a heavy heart with the government, which I did. It would take more than the likes of you to make me rat on the government.

As the honourable member for Wills (Mr Cleary) has said, if you people were promising anything I would have looked at it, but what are you promising for ANL? You want to flog off ANL, the same as the government does. What are you going to do for the Maritime Union of Australia? Each of you who stood there yesterday bagged it unmercifully. Look at the Maritime Union of Australia. No union in Australia has undergone more restructuring. Look at the shipping levels, the crewing on shipping. It has gone from 40 down to 18. Did you know that? Have you ever made a speech about that? Have you ever congratulated the Maritime Union of Australia for its multiskilling, for its training? That is one of the reasons I have opposed this. I want a well trained shipping movement around Australia. I want seafarers working those ships to be multiskilled, well trained and well paid. I make no apology for it. I do not want seafarers from all corners of the world to be paid the starvation wages that they are paid.

The honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Knott) and I have gone to Port Kembla to talk to the seamen there. We have been on those ships. I went to Gladstone to see a ship. There are seafarers there who have not been paid for four and six months. Once in Port Kembla people were fed watermelon for a week. That was their feed. People are being physically and sexually abused. Is that what you want on the Australian coastline?—because by voting to nationalise ANL that is what you are going to get. That is why I am so opposed to what my party is doing. But you people will have to offer a hell of a lot more and give real commitments about the ANL and the Maritime Union of Australia before I make that long, tortuous journey across the green carpet. It will be a long time before you see me do that. You will have to promise more.

Thank you very much for giving my feeble press release such wide publicity. I am sure more media will take interest in it today and may publicise it. Any time you want to go grovelling through the press boxes in the middle of the night, feel free to do so. You can pull my press release out and give it a little more publicity than most of the media in Australia give to my words of wisdom in this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make some points on the issues that pertain to the ANL Sale Bill. I note no amendment has been moved. Clearly, based on his contribution, the member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) has not been following the debate all that closely. There are a few issues that the member for Mackellar (Mrs Bishop) raised on the actual bill that I want to refer to.

PARA.TAB: One of the issues that was raised was in relation to the purpose of the $15 million appropriation. It is important to set the record straight on a couple of the points that were made both in the debate and in the press release the shadow minister issued. I should make it clear that the $15 million appropriation represents contingency planning in relation to certain terms and conditions of the sale bill. It does not represent government expectation. That appropriation may never be called upon or may be called upon to a limited extent.

The reason for the appropriations are set out in broad terms on page 3 of the explanatory memorandum, which has already been circulated. I will go through those briefly for the information of the House. The explanatory memorandum states:

SPEECH.PARA: The first is in relation to the contingency that relevant financiers may exercise change of ownership rights which would impose additional payments on the Commonwealth (all relevant financiers have indicated their consents in principle to the change of ownership). The second element is to provide for the possibility that ANL's operating results up to settlement of the sale agreement are significantly worse than current forecasts. The third is to cover any expenses related to the movement of the transferring items out of ANL.

All sorts of absurd assertions have been made about this amount. They have no basis whatever in relation to the bill that is before the House. It is not possible to be more specific here without running into questions of commercial sensitivity. However, further briefing on the appropriation and on any other issues which may be of concern to the coalition has indeed been offered to them.

PARA.TAB: I should make it clear that many of these matters have already been the subject of discussion in the Senate committee on this issue. So attempts here to derail the matter in this sort of fashion do not do any credit to the opposition, who are showing on this issue—as they did in relation to airlines—that they act without any regard to principle in the matters.

The appropriations will not be used for other purposes and certainly not for the sorts of purposes that the shadow minister speculated on. The sale legislation does not contemplate a transfer of shares in ANL to parties other than the Commonwealth or P&O. This is indeed not a possibility. Regarding the unspecified appropriation in relation to RetainCo, the government has undertaken to move an amendment in the Senate to cap the appropriation at $1 million. This should meet the concerns that have been expressed in that regard.

The shadow minister has raised the possibility of tabling the draft and the final sale agreement with commercial-in-confidence clauses deleted. The sale agreement is a fully commercial agreement and with such clauses deleted there would be little left to table. It is therefore not appropriate to table that agreement.

There has been a deal of discussion on the merits of the legislation and attempts at cheap political point scoring on the part of the opposition in this matter. It has nothing to do with the substance of the bill. It is a matter of great regret that, when key matters come before the parliament, the opposition uses the sorts of tactics that it used earlier in the week in aviation industry legislation and that it is unable to take the appropriate steps with what has supposedly been policy it sees as appropriate and on which it has articulated the government was not moving fast enough in the first place.

The government has outlined in the sale bill a clear process as to its intentions for that sale and the alternatives if those agreements cannot be put in place by the dates that were identified and if the restructuring process that needs to be contemplated as part of that alternative cannot be completed. There is absolutely no value in the opposition's adopting this sort of tactic of seeking to derail. The government has made its intentions clear. The sorts of scares that have been run and the sorts of lines that have been run have no basis in fact and I believe that, rather than this sort of tactic of using time unnecessarily, the bill should be supported. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Mrs B.K.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister may make payments totalling no more than $15,000,000 that:

PARA.TAB: (a) are required to be made by the sale agreement . . .

SPEECH.PARA: We will never see that sale agreement. We are not allowed to see the sale agreement. That is exactly why I asked for the undertaking to see both the draft agreement and the agreement that is finally agreed to.

PARA.TAB: That $15 million does not belong to the government; it belongs to the taxpayers. Here is government putting in place a piece of legislation that gives them carte blanche to spend $15 million of taxpayers' money in any way they see fit. If they were to make a transfer by way of a premium payment in accordance with a sale agreement term to the Maritime Union, then you would never know about it. That money would be virtually a secret commission and we would never know. If they chose to make a payment for another reason that was simply made a term of the sale agreement, we would never know. In other words, accountability is just not there.

It is part of our responsibility as members of parliament to ensure that there is accountability when we appropriate money. In this particular piece of legislation there is none. When I wrote to the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley) asking for the delay of this debate because we wanted more time to look for information, he wrote to me and said, as the parliamentary secretary has said, that with regard to the unspecified, second appropriation there will be a cap of $1 million placed on that. I do not require a briefing. I require an undertaking from the government as to the manner in which the money is to be spent. The word of the government has been broken again and again.

PARA.TAB: For the parliamentary secretary to stand and say that we will not use it for other purposes, implying that it will be applied only to the precise sale of all shares to P&O—which the legislation does not provide for—simply is not good enough. I would be interested to hear a response on that.

The bottom line is that, as legislators, we have a responsibility. DEBATE.TITLE: HUMAN SERVICES AND HEALTH LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1995Cognate bill:THERAPEUTIC GOODS AMENDMENT BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 20 September.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Dr THEOPHANOUS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Human Services and Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

This bill is part of a package of two bills which will replace the Human Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1). That original bill was passed by the House on 31 May but divided by the Senate into two bills on 9 June. A message was received from the Senate seeking the House's concurrence in its action.

Since the original legislation was introduced, a number of minor amendments have become necessary. Rather than pressing on with the original legislation, the government has decided to introduce these new bills to better integrate some related measures and incorporate other minor amendments to the portfolio's legislation. I shall mention these new matters as I outline for members' benefit the key provisions of the bills.

The bill makes amendments to the Childcare Rebate Act 1993, the Health Insurance Act 1973, the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973, the National Health Act 1953 and the National Health and Medical Research Council Act 1992. The bill repeals the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act 1974, which has become redundant due to a sunset provision which prevented further payments being made after 30 June 1992. The bill also makes minor technical amendments to a number of acts as set out in schedule 2 of the bill.

The amendments to the Childcare Rebate Act 1993 will strengthen the original intention of the act and clarify and facilitate certain procedural aspects of the child-care cash rebate scheme.The first group of amendments provides hardship provisions to assist certain groups of persons who are currently precluded from receiving the rebate but who should be entitled to the rebate. These groups are children over the age of 13 years who have a disability or other specified special need which requires ongoing child care; parents who should be considered to have work related commitments, such as those who are eligible for, but not in receipt of, a carer pension; and families in which one parent has a work related commitment but the other parent is unable to work or look after their children due to extenuating circumstances such as a medical condition.

An amendment is sought to allow carers under the age of 18 years who have specified formal child-care qualifications to register under the scheme. Further amendments are proposed to confirm in legislation that family registration is able to be backdated to the date at which the family was first eligible to register, and that the rebate can be paid when a child is absent from child care for specified reasons.

There are also some administrative amendments proposed to rectify a number of drafting anomalies which have arisen. These amendments also make consequential amendments to the act to bring it in line with changes to other Commonwealth legislation. Other administrative amendments are proposed to:

SPEECH.PARA: .allow the Health Insurance Commission to backdate carer registrations to the date at which they were first eligible to register;
.cancel family or carer registrations and recover payments when an administrative error has been made;
.suspend family or carer registrations if cancellation of the registration is being considered;
.ensure that the rebate is not paid for child-care expenses which have been made or will be reimbursed by another agent, such as an employer;
.clarify the eligibility of persons who are not Australian citizens by correcting the description of visa categories to bring the act into line with changes in the Migration Act;
.broaden the nature of courses which overseas students can be undertaking in order to be eligible for the rebate;
.allow the Managing Director of the Health Insurance Commission to delegate powers;
.allow the minister to have some discretion over receipting requirements; and
.to remove technical defects in the original act.

PARA.TAB: The bill has been changed to include two new minor technical amendments to allow the Health Insurance Commission to vary a family's registration if it believes a member of the family who is not included in the registration should be included, and cancel a family's registration where incorrect information is provided in connection with an application to vary the registration.

The amendments proposed to the Health Insurance Act 1973 are designed to correct a number of minor drafting errors in the Health Legislation (Professional Services Review) Amendment Act 1994 which established the professional services review scheme. In addition, the amendments will allow the appointment, as a President of a Professional Services Review Tribunal, of a person who holds or has held judicial office in a state or territory jurisdiction.

One of the new measures in this bill is to the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973. The proposed amendment would expressly give the Health Insurance Commission the function of providing information technology services to the Commonwealth and to other bodies established by laws of the Commonwealth.

This means that the expertise which the Health Insurance Commission has now or will acquire in the future can be made available to perform services for Commonwealth departments or other bodies established by this parliament.

The possibility of utilising the commission's spare capacity and expertise is consistent with the recommended approach of the Commonwealth and Commonwealth agencies rationalising their existing information technology functions. This was foreshadowed in Clients first, the report of the Minister for Finance's Information Technology Review Group which was published in March this year.
Other proposed amendments to the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973 are designed to correct a deficiency in the Health Legislation (Powers of Investigation) Amendment Act 1994.

That act, which gave the Health Insurance Commission the power to investigate fraud under Medicare and to deal directly with the Director of Public Prosecutions, does not allow the Health Insurance Commission to retain evidential material seized under the authority of a search warrant for more than 60 days unless proceedings for an offence to which that material may afford evidence is instituted within that period. This deficiency will be corrected on the basis of advice from the Director of Public Prosecutions that without the amendment the commission's search warrant powers are ineffectual.

The bill also empowers the Health Insurance Commission to engage in hedging of investment transactions, provide consulting, management and related services and exercise its powers and perform its functions overseas.

The commission has undertaken a number of consultancies primarily, but not exclusively, under the auspices of the World Bank. As these activities are expanding, and moving beyond the use of spare capacity in the commission's operations, it is desirable to make explicit provision to cover this activity.

So far as the proposed hedging power is concerned, this is consistent with other Commonwealth legislation and has been addressed, on the advice of the Attorney-General's Department, to resolve any doubt about the commission's ability to enter into hedging transactions.

Hedging is, of course, one of the tools necessary in a prudent and balanced investment program which includes some overseas investments. The commission operates Medibank Private in competition with other private insurers and must have available to it the same opportunities to manage the funds vested in it by its members.

This bill also contains amendments to parts of the National Health Act 1953 which regulate the administration of nursing homes. The government has decided that these amendments should not await the introduction of the new Aged Care Act. The amendments to the current legislation are essential to address two immediate issues that have been identified.

Firstly, there are a number of technical amendments to the National Health Act 1953 (the principal act) consequential upon amendments to the principal act introduced by the National Health Amendment Act 1992 which resulted in the entitlement to general care benefit being calculated by reference to the `notional scale of fees' determined retrospectively under the principal act in place of the scale of fees determined prospectively under section 40AA.

For example, the principal act requires amendment to ensure that nursing home proprietors have a right of review of authorisations of payments of advance of benefit prior to the determination of the notional scale of fees within three years of the relevant accounting period. Secondly, there are a number of amendments that relate to nursing homes which have been granted `exempt bed status'. The amendments contained in the bill will address public concern about exempt nursing homes which fail to meet required standards of care.

The granting of `exempt bed status' under section 39AB of the act enables a proprietor to charge additional fees to nursing home patients. One of the criteria for granting `exempt bed status' is that the nursing home provides a higher level of accommodation and services than are normally available. However, the current provisions of the act do not enable the revocation or suspension of `exempt bed status' for those nursing homes which have failed to satisfy the standards for nursing and personal care.

It is clearly incongruous to continue to allow a nursing home to charge additional amounts for a supposed increased level of accommodation and services, when the level of nursing and personal care fails to meet the basic standards. The decision to suspend or revoke `exempt bed status' is to be subject to internal review, as well as review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

The proposed amendment to the National Health and Medical Research Council Act 1992 is to specify directly the health ministers to be consulted by the minister before appointing the chairperson of the council, the chairperson of the Australian Health Ethics Committee, a principal committee of the council, and the member of the Australian Health Ethics Committee classified as a person with knowledge of the ethics of medical research. Currently the act provides that the minister is to consult in relation to these appointments with the other members of the Australian Health Ministers Conference.

The composition of that membership can of course vary from time to time and currently includes the New Zealand minister for health. The proposed amendment would specify that it is the health minister of each state and territory who is to be consulted in relation to the appointments. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.PARA: THERAPEUTIC GOODS AMENDMENT BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: This bill incorporates and reintroduces all the provisions of the Human Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1995 in regard to the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989, as considered by both houses of parliament last session, and differs from that bill in the addition of one further minor amendment to correct an unintended consequence of a clause in the original legislation.

As outlined in my second reading speech for the Human Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No.1) 1995, the amendments included in this bill will establish a new accelerated process for placing listable drugs supplied in Australia on the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods, ARTG, to cut product approval time to a matter of weeks, without in any way affecting the quality or safety of the medicinal products.

The bill provides a much better definition of some poorly understood aspects of the national regulatory scheme for therapeutic goods, which have been identified in its first four years of operation. A mechanism to address shortages, or lack of essential drugs required by the public in emergency situations, has been included, along with amendments that update and consolidate in a new part of the act, the entry, search and warrant powers to enforce the legislation. Also included in the bill are changes to align the monetary penalties in the current legislation with the `penalty units' classification used in other Commonwealth regulatory legislation, as well as closing a gap in the current scheme, in regard to the removal of illegal therapeutic goods of unknown quality safety and efficacy from the market.

A definition for `food' has been inserted to clarify the interface between food and drugs. Problems have arisen from the present definition of `therapeutic goods' which excludes `food' but fails to define the term. What constitutes `food' in the bill will be linked to the presentation and promotion of a product in the market. The words `prescribed dose' and `frequency of administration' included in the definition are to be read in a pharmaceutical sense, and are not intended to encompass serving suggestions applied to or normally associated with food and beverages.

Other amendments in the bill include a provision to replace the therapeutic goods administration trust account with the therapeutic goods administration reserve, consistent with changes to be made by the proposed Financial Management Accountability Bill 1995 and related bills that will replace the Audit Act 1901.

The appeal provisions in the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989 relating to the review of decisions to register therapeutic goods have also been tightened. This will ensure that technical and scientific data that should be lodged in connection with a general marketing application will be evaluated before a review on merits is undertaken by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

Turning to the new provision in the bill, the legislation currently provides that where therapeutic goods are refused marketing approval within Australia they may still be included in the ARTG as listed goods for export only. The secretary is empowered to require confirmation that the relevant authority of the country to which the goods are to be exported is willing to accept the goods. The secretary's power is currently confined to goods that have been manufactured in Australia for export only and does not extend to products imported into Australia solely for re-export.

The bill proposes that this provision be amended to ensure that the secretary's ability to require confirmation from Australia's trading partners of their willingness to accept goods refused marketing approval in Australia extends to all products, irrespective of whether they have been manufactured in Australia or elsewhere. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this morning to respond to the second reading speech of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Theophanous) to the human services and health and therapeutic goods bills. As second reading speeches go, it went. And it went rather more quickly than the second reading speech for mark I of these bills when debated in the Main Committee on 31 May. Then a pair of relatively minor bills were dignified by a second reading speech that the parliamentary secretary—a man not known for his use of superfluous words—held forth for no less than his allotted time plus a 10-minute extension. I understand that he has since taken the Department of Human Services and Health to task for this, and rightly so, as the time of the parliament is now so scarce that the government tells us that every spare minute is needed for government business.

PARA.TAB: Those who were involved in this debate the first time around may recall that on that occasion the shadow minister, the member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge), told a story that Andrew Peacock told him about Sir Robert Menzies' reaction to his maiden speech. The gist of the story is that Sir Robert told Andrew to cut his speech by half—and it did not matter which half. In regard to this pair of bills, I suggest the government should have applied Sir Robert's wise advice to its own parliamentary program and broken what was really a difficult single omnibus bill into more manageable chunks. Instead, we have a situation where we are back where we were four months ago, while the government sits like a shag on a rock waiting for an electoral tidal wave to engulf it.

We should not be here talking about these bills, which were already dealt with once before in this place as part of the Human Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1995. But what happened? Basically there was a breakdown in communication, a failure to treat this parliament as anything more than a simple rubber stamp and an ignorance about the procedures and traditions of this House and of the other place. Had Senator Harradine not complained, rightly in my view, about the unfairness of a mass of complex technical amendments in the one bill, there would have been no split in the original bill on the floor of the Senate. Now we find ourselves back here having to take both parts of that original bill from scratch. Had the government taken the present course in the first place and offered us two bills for cognate debate, we would not have had to go through this charade. Let us not hear anything from the government about delays to Labor's legislation in either house of this parliament. They disrupt their program quite well without any assistance from the coalition, the minor parties or the Independents.

I will deal briefly with the bills in substance. Other than a couple of added on provisions, particularly in relation to the child-care cash rebate provisions and the Therapeutic Goods Act, the substance is unchanged. Subject to some concerns about some of the provisions of the Therapeutic Goods Amendment Bill, which I will raise in a moment, we have no objection to these bills. Our position is on the Hansard record from last time they were discussed. Indeed, we want to see the last of them.

The shadow minister asked me to raise some specific concerns of his about some provisions in the Therapeutic Goods Amendment Bill which relate to the electronic lodgment of supporting information for listing applications for certain kinds of therapeutic goods. Back in June, when this legislation was first making its way through this parliament, we were urged by the government to get on with the job, because the electronic data lodging facility was due to commence on 1 July 1995, nearly three months ago, and the enabling legislation was vital for its operation.

Indeed, overcoming some unexpected administrative obstacles demanded some complicated late night negotiations and midnight meetings involving the shadow minister's office, that of the parliamentary secretary and the office of the Minister for Family Services, Senator Crowley. Just why is it that the ELF, to give it its fairytale acronym, has been in operation since 1 July—with nary a hitch, as far as I am aware? The answer is that ways and means were found by way of appropriate delegated legislation. That is not ideal, as we who prefer parliamentary scrutiny of legislative action will attest, but clearly possible.

The only possible conclusion I can come to is that the government does not know whether it is coming or going in relation to its own legislative program. It certainly does not seem to ask itself the question, to adapt a well-known wartime phrase, `Is this legislation really necessary?'

When the Therapeutic Goods Act was empowered by regulations debated in this place in 1990, I was critical of the government for not taking into consideration the demonstrated concerns of the community and the alternative therapies industry. Many Australians today consult alternative therapists and make what they believe to be an informed choice about alternative methods of health care.

The coalition have always defended the right of Australians to choice. Those who choose alternative therapies such as acupuncture, naturopathy, kinesiology or herbalism have the right to be protected from charlatans and pseudo-medicos. Our obligation as law makers is to provide frameworks within which people can choose the type of health care that they desire, whether it be mainstream medicine with its use of prescriptive pharmaceuticals or alternative therapies with nutritional supplements, herbal remedies and aromatherapy.

The Natural Medicine Defence Movement has generally welcomed the Therapeutic Goods Act and its regulations in providing one uniform national system of control for the quality, efficacy and safety of therapeutic goods. Nevertheless, it is important that such organisations be continually consulted when changes are made to the act which monitors their tools of trade. Since the act commenced, some 25,000 over-the-counter drug products have been listed on the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods. Included in that list are a substantial number of traditional Chinese medicine products.

Under the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989, the definition of therapeutic goods excludes food—it was not defined. One of the bills introduces a definition of food, the need for which has arisen because of difficulties for both industry and government in determining whether certain products are to be regulated as therapeutic goods or whether they fall outside that regulatory framework.

The original act's definition of therapeutic goods effectively provided that goods for which there was a therapeutic claim came under the act and those for which there was not such a claim were not covered. The new definition of food is rather convoluted although it is intended to make it clear to manufacturers, before they develop a product, whether they should position it in the market as a food or, alternatively, as a therapeutic good.
I still have considerable reservations regarding the definition of `food'. Inquiries to the Therapeutic Goods Administration drew the following response:

SPEECH.PARA: A definition for `food' therefore is necessary to establish when such a product is a food, and when it is therapeutic goods. The definition of `food' in Subsection 3(1) of the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989 is therefore solely for the purposes of this act only, to assist industry in formulating and positioning products in the marketplace, and to assist regulators in classifying products for regulatory purposes.
The TGA's response continues:

The definition of food for the purposes of the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989 is not therefore intended to cover formula dietary foods or supplementary foods. These are covered under the National Food Authority Food Standards Code, Standards R4 for and R9.

That last paragraph, straight from the Therapeutic Goods Authority, seems to tell me that as a result of this new definition of `food', formula dietary foods or supplementary foods such as meal replacement products have now been declared not to be food for the purposes of the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989 and therefore are brought in under the act. Remember: under the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989 the definition of `therapeutic goods' excludes food but now the TGA tells us that the new definition for food does not include formula dietary foods or supplementary foods. It is a bit confusing. I suspect there is going to be a lot of confusion out there in the marketplace.

PARA.TAB: There are numerous products already on the market that could qualify as either a food or a therapeutic good depending on how they are presented and marketed. The argument is made by the TGA that, when presented in capsule or tablet form with dosage regimen and therapeutic claims, these products should be regulated as therapeutic goods. That is where the new definition of food comes in, as manufacturers should now be much more aware of the claims that they make and the form in which the product is manufactured and marketed. Is the whole issue really any clearer than before? I doubt it quite sincerely.

The legislation also provides for temporary approval for the general supply of drugs that have not been evaluated in Australia. Although there are strict guidelines and criteria governing the temporary approval, some concerns have been expressed with regard to health and safety issues. The whole idea of the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989 was that all drugs, pharmaceuticals and therapeutic goods should be properly tested and trialled under strict guidelines within Australia before they are made available for general public supply. The major complaint by pharmaceutical companies at the time of the introduction of the therapeutic goods regulations was that Australian requirements were tougher and more stringent than those in a number of other countries in Europe and in the United States. They argued that not only were the requirements more onerous but the format proposed was unique to Australia. In other words, the way in which they were to present their submission for registration was to be in a format that could only be used in Australia—all this despite the fact that many of the companies are multinational and drugs may well have been on the general market in developed countries around the world for some period of time.

I do not for one moment want to be seen to be pushing for more relaxed restrictions or clinical trialling requirements, but it seems to me that when implementing the new legislation and regulations in the Australian arena there is not always the necessity to also invent new ways of implementation, new mechanisms for bureaucracies to get their fingers into the pie.

The new provisions restrict temporary approval to such occasions as where there is a shortage of an Australian registered drug or where a registered drug ceases to be available without an equivalent registered product being available. In all cases an application for marketing of the drug in Australia must have already been made or alternatively the product has been approved for general marketing in a specified country. Approval under this provision only applies in respect of drugs specified in schedule 10 of the regulations which, generally speaking, are new chemical entities or prescription drugs.

The new section 26A is intended to simplify the procedures and hasten the listing of certain products such as over-the-counter drugs and herbal and vitamin preparations described in schedule 4 of the regulations. The new proceedings will only apply to products for supply into the Australian market. Listable products for export will still be required to be processed through existing procedures.

It is interesting to note that on 5 June Senator Crowley announced the introduction of a new streamlining system to be known as the electronic lodgment facility for listing over-the-counter drug products. But it is not clear from the bill whether section 26A is intended to encompass these new procedures. The minister went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: When the new system begins operating in a few weeks time, herbal remedies, vitamins, minerals and sunscreen products which meet Australian regulations will be able to be approved much more quickly and for much less cost.

If that is so, the government is to be congratulated for streamlining what has become a quite cumbersome and long, drawn-out process. On 1 June, the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht) indicated to the parliament that the average approval time for individual products of five months is well in excess of the initial target of 30 days. He went on to say:

Lodgement of an electronic application under the accelerated listing process is expected to be able to reduce the time frame for product approval from an average five months to approximately two weeks.

Over the period that the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989 has been in place, there have been a number of complaints from manufacturers and importers that the approval process has been too slow and delays often seemingly prolonged. In our initial discussions with the TGA in my office in 1990, we expressed concern that the regulations did not provide for approval within a reasonable time frame. We were then told that our fears were un
founded and that all applications would be processed speedily and efficiently. The Baume report vindicated my earlier stance and recommended that appropriate performance targets be set.

PARA.TAB: The one vital factor in any new listing process is ensuring the integrity of the system. The Australian public must have confidence in our system of evaluation and feel secure in the knowledge that all possible steps have been taken to maintain public health and safety. Although the new procedure provides for the applicant to certify, among other things, that the goods are safe for the purposes for which they will be used and that the drugs do not contain goods that are prohibited imports, some concern has been expressed that the certification may not go far enough. I understand that Senator Harradine has expressed his reservations that we may well be fast-tracking drug evaluations without adequate safety precautions.

An issue which also pertains to therapeutic goods is that of practitioners operating in the wider field of alternative therapies. As alternative therapies become more widely accepted, it is important that the community have confidence in Australian qualifications and accreditation. I note that RMIT in Melbourne has recently introduced an accredited course in traditional Chinese medicine covering such disciplines as acupuncture and Chinese herbal medicine. That course came about as a result of the expressed demand for Australian qualifications in a discipline that is widely practised by people who have only been trained overseas. I participated in the process of trying to convince the vice-chancellor that this was a proper course of action. I am delighted that the course is up and running. I have great hopes for the future of the course at RMIT.

There are numerous schools of alternative therapies offering a range of options for learning the various disciplines. They cover correspondence to full-time study, certificates to diplomas and aromatherapy to naturopathy. The question has often been raised as to the value of a mail order certificate in a particular discipline compared with a course that involves extensive client contact and thousands of hours of face-to-face tutoring. Over the past few years, I have had extensive discussions with a range of organisations involved in the training and certification of those who would learn to be practitioners in the field of alternative therapies. I have stressed to them the importance of developing a national code of training infrastructure that has high professional standards and that could be included at an accredited tertiary establishment.

It is disappointing that the industry itself does not appear to have achieved consensus of a national training accreditation process. Australians must maintain the right to have free and easy access to quality assured alternative medicines and practitioners. I accept that the coalition will not be opposing this bill but I must make the point that it does impose additional regulation on an industry that is already highly regulated.

Many in the community see the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989 as imposing additional levels of bureaucracy without any obvious benefit. I have long been a supporter of minimal regulation and minimal bureaucracy while acknowledging that the safety of the public is also paramount.

Despite assurances to the contrary from the Therapeutic Goods Administration, I still have some reservations regarding the powers of search and seizure. The amendments are not quite as tight as the existing act, which could also do with some clarification. The existing act is more specific about search and seizure, with or without a warrant, being related to therapeutic goods. I am somewhat concerned that officers could go off on a `fishing expedition' and take whatever documents or other things that might—and I emphasise `might'—or, then again, might not be able to be used in developing a case for prosecution. It seems to me that such powers may not be necessary.
