Section 54A, which seeks to extend the period of time for bringing a prosecution, also raises some doubts. Is it realistic to allow such a time span? Is there any evidence to suggest that if the TGA diligently applies itself to investigation and preparation of a case the existing two years is inadequate? Will this extension make the bureaucrats any more efficient or are we, by extending the time period, offering them more chance to be less diligent? Surely, if a case is reasonably clear and the public health is at risk, it is not unreasonable on public health grounds alone to ensure that charges are laid and prosecution is undertaken as expeditiously as possible.

I am aware that the TGA argues that because of increasing sophistication of both production and distribution, and detection methods, that more than two years might occasionally be necessary to bring a prosecution. But it seems to me its argument begs the question of whether or not our detection and prosecution techniques are not also in need of updating and increased sophistication.

The coalition has no real difficulty with this legislation, and we do not intend to oppose its passage. But we do resent and object to the utterly incompetent way this legislation has been handled, and this is something for which I do not blame the parliamentary secretary but I do blame his minister. It was tempting, under the circumstances, to move on behalf of the coalition a motion noting the incompetent way in which this legislation was originally managed in its passage through this parliament so that the original bill was divided on the floor of the Senate and thus rendered inoperable.

This legislation is just another example of the Labor government's cavalier and arrogant treatment of the institution of parliament as revealed by the history of these bills. As I said at the beginning, the coalition is not opposing the legislation. Nevertheless, I would be derelict in my duty as a representative of the many people in La Trobe who are concerned with therapeutic goods to not voice their concerns with a number of the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio The Hon J.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mrs CROSIO
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise too in this House today to speak in support of the cognate legislation before the House. I am sure the member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) will forgive me if I say it is a very wide ranging debate, and not just on therapeutic goods.

PARA.TAB: Even though we now know it is a cognate debate in this House, I would like to put on the record that, as the second reader, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Theophanous), has stated, the bill also makes amendments to the Childcare Rebate Act 1993, the Health Insurance Act, the Health Insurance Commission Act, the National Health Act and the National Health and Medical Research Council Act 1992. It repeals the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act 1974, which has become redundant due to the sunset provisions, as well as the Therapeutic Goods Amendment Bill. It is a very wide ranging debate. That is why it is with a great deal of pride that I speak on a number of issues covering not only that area but also health in general.

I am very pleased to see a number of the changes introduced in this legislation today. Most importantly, the Human Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) proposes to repeal the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act 1974 and other acts and encompasses relevant amendments to other legislation and is designed to again extend what we in the government continue to do—that is, look at the amendments that need to be introduced and streamline efficiency. I think the health debate should be about efficiency and not necessarily about putting more money into the system all the time.

Whether we like it or not, good health and wellbeing are the nub of everything we do. It is essential to get our health right before anything else. It is not really surprising that a recent Morgan poll that was published in the Bulletin in early August showed that, for those polled, health care issues rated higher than the current account deficit. A more recent Morgan poll in the Bulletin reaffirms that health is a significant issue in the community's mind. Last year a poll of women voters showed conclusively that health issues rate very highly in determining how they vote.

My research in my electorate tells me that. I speak with my constituents constantly about this issue, as I am sure other members do. I am constantly reminded by the people in my electorate of their interest in the government's health policies and programs. It is our federal government that has recognised the importance that the electorate places on health care. It is aware that it must be attuned to the voters' views.

Since coming to office our Labor government has now channelled significant resources and energy into improving the lot of ordinary, everyday Australians in all spheres but, in particular, in health. Since the 1983 introduction of Medicare, all sections of the community have had access to medical and hospital services and pharmaceuticals at an affordable cost. That is the bottom line. I think we need to emphasise in this House time and time again that those services are provided at an affordable cost.

We are invariably criticised by the opposition for our health care policies. I take this opportunity to ask those sitting on the opposition benches: does the opposition seriously understand the complexities of government? When our opponents say that our health care system is in disarray, what do they actually mean? Do they mean that people are missing out on vital medical treatment? I hope not, because the surveys have shown that people in this country are getting excellent medical treatment and care.

Australia's medical system compares very favourably with that of other countries. Since the mid-1980s, whilst most of the OECD countries have shown a levelling in health expenditure as a percentage of GDP, Australia's expenditure has increased. That our spending is more than sufficient has been backed up not just by government but by various quarters.

According to the Australian Hospitals Association's annual congress in 1993, it may not just be a question of money. During the 1993 election campaign, and we are all aware of that campaign, in weighing up the major parties' policies—they were the days when the opposition had policies—the congress concluded that Australia's spending of around 8.1 per cent of GDP on health is about right. As well, that forum overwhelmingly maintained that increased efficiency is more important than increased funding.

Studies show conclusively that over recent decades the health status of Australians has improved significantly, aided no doubt by our health care system which guarantees universal coverage and yields a large measure of satisfaction at a reasonable overall cost to the economy. Achieving equity in health care is no simple task in Australia's federal system of government with its overlapping jurisdictions—each state having their own vested interests—wide array of service providers and constantly changing health and sociological trends.

1994-95 OECD surveys show that Australians are now enjoying one of the best managed and socially accepted health systems among OECD countries. In June this year, the OECD's publication Review of Australia compared Australia's health care system performance with that of other OECD nations. This publication confirmed, yet again, that this government has contained health care spending while significantly improving the nation's health status. According to that report:

SPEECH.PARA: Community satisfaction with Medicare is high and rising.

The report goes on to praise Australia's additional budget allocations to enhance home and community care services for the aged and for the disabled; the reforms that we have implemented to private health insurance; Australia's best practice in the health arena; and the reforms to the pharmacy and pathology industries.

PARA.TAB: However, the report criticises any further state government hospital budget cuts, warning that such would undermine Medicare's commitment to universal access to free quality hospital care. Realistically, if Medicare does not operate at optimum levels it would be because it is being thwarted by conservative state governments. I acknowledge that it is a bit old hat to speak these days about the coalition's lack of policy. I will just briefly mention their incredible propensity for inconsistency and say that the opposition's new found commitment to Medicare is looking shakier by the minute.

I would like to place a couple of examples on the record. Earlier this year, the new shadow health minister, the member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge), said that Medicare will stay. But then the new Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) made it clear on 1 February that he was considering dismantling universal access. Meanwhile, the incoming member for Bradfield—a doctor himself—was spending considerable time in Canberra campaigning for a two-tier Medicare levy and the abolition of bulk-billing. I understand that the future member for Bradfield is a longstanding opponent of bulk-billing and he campaigned on that even during his preselection. My question to the Liberals and through them to the coalition is: does the coalition have the abolition of bulk-billing on its agenda? Just what is the opposition's position, given the contrary statements by the future member for Bradfield?

The clear aims and objectives of the Labor government and the contradictions of the opposition distinguish the two sides very markedly. The system that the ALP has developed has been performing well. Doctors are treating more patients through public hospitals and are doing more with less. Average lengths of stay are decreasing and home treatment facilities are being more efficiently utilised.

Certainly, there is room for improvement in the area of elective surgery waiting times. The Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) is presently working on this issue with state ministers and plans are under way to improve waiting times for surgery, such as hip and knee replacements, as part of a recently announced $10 million government package. Seven hospitals across Australia have been earmarked to pilot streamlining their pre-admission and discharge procedures and are held up as examples of efficient waiting list management.

These federal government grants will enable the seven hospitals to collaborate with other hospitals Australia-wide to assist them in reducing patient care within their own hospitals. In deflecting the criticism we receive, one can ask: is it any wonder that the system might clog down at times? Consider the technology that has been absorbed over the past 10 to 20 years. Coronary artery bypass grafting, hip replacements and organ transplants are just a few examples.

Improving health standards is accentuated by other portfolios in their policy formulation. Recognising that living standards and health are inextricably linked to where we live and that people need to have places where they can have fulfilling lives, the Department of Housing and Regional Development, I am pleased to say, is playing its part. That department is ever cognisant that suburb design and infrastructure, access to services such as health facilities and affordable housing make a significant impact on health. Under the Better Cities II program, ways to improve the quality of our urban environment and development are high on that agenda.

I note also that the bill contains amendments to accommodate changes in the child-care area. A very important element of the government's child-care policy is the Commonwealth child-care cash rebate introduced in July 1994. This cash payment helps offset child-care expenses while both parents or sole parents are working, studying, training or looking for work, and improving the affordability of child care for many of our working parents. There is no doubt that quality child care is a must in assisting people in their aspirations for productive and satisfying lifestyles.

I also support the provision in the bill to allow the Health Insurance Commission to market its knowledge and expertise internationally. In these days of user pays, such a scheme is a logical approach. To date its work has included consultancies in a number of overseas countries under the auspices of the World Bank, the World Health Organisation, the International Labour Organisation and, latterly, the United Nations development program. It seems commonsense to me—if we have the expertise, why not sell it? I am well aware that such a scheme can work very well.

The Department of Social Security, which as you are aware, Mr Deputy Speaker, I represent as parliamentary secretary, has had some considerable successes in this regard. It has sold consultancies by way of advice on social policy reform and assistance with the development of institutions delivering social services, especially regarding information technology. Clients have included the International Labour Organisation and the World Bank and DSS officers have worked on projects in Nigeria, Thailand, Kazakstan, Kyrgystan and the United Kingdom.

Another amendment in this legislation relates to simplification measures to the National Health Act 1953—nursing homes. These measures are not to change nursing home proprietors' entitlements to Commonwealth benefits nor result in any change to the level of advances paid to nursing home proprietors. Simply, they will make it easier for proprietors to see how the level of Commonwealth benefit has been calculated. Another amendment will remedy an anomaly whereby current provisions of the Act do not enable the revocation or suspension of `exempt bed status' for those nursing homes failing to satisfy nursing home care standards.

As we all know, Australia has a rapidly ageing population. We need to take stock of the views, needs and aspirations of older people, and we particularly need to be mindful of their interests. We must not ignore the immense contribution they have to make.

Judging by the results of a major survey completed last year, we seem to be on the right track. According to the publication An optimistic future: attitudes to ageing and well being into the next century—the product of a survey commissioned last year by the Department of Human Services and Health—of 2,000 Australians surveyed in the 40 to 55 and 55 to 75 age brackets, we are faring very well. In comparison with other countries our locals seem to have more positive attitudes than their European counterparts.

The survey challenged the misconception that aging is a negative experience and an end, rather than a new chapter. The survey found that attitudes to aging and wellbeing among older Australians are that they are enthusiastic in undertaking new activities and challenges. The overall results were very positive and demonstrate a strong degree of optimism towards the future. Over 88 per cent of respondents said that they are `mostly positive about the future'; 90 per cent judged their health to be good, very good, or excellent, and many anticipated new and exciting possibilities.

This study shows that older people want to play a greater role in the community, feel good about themselves, and feel healthy and positive in their outlook. Despite complaints about our government's policies from the opposition, as I said earlier, it seems we are well on target.

In the wake of this major report, the government has set up a national network of older Australians advisory councils to advise the Minister for Human Services and Health on relevant matters relating to their wellbeing. Among other work, the councils will consider the needs and concerns of older people and the effectiveness and relevance of Commonwealth government services or funding in meeting those needs. Anyone seeking information about what the federal government is providing in the health sphere can find a wide array of programs and work plans to improve all Australians' wellbeing.

The government has always concentrated on identifying problems and finding the solutions to fix them. In this vein, funding has been approved for the Australian Consumers' Council to develop a national health consumers' charter as part of our government's commitment to stronger patient involvement in health care. The charter will enable patients to make clear, informed decisions about their treatment so that they can weigh up the benefits and risks and, most importantly, be fully aware of their rights.

A feature of the government's health strategy has been focusing on women's health, as last year's successful national campaign to fight breast cancer testifies. But it was not surprising to see the first national men's health summit held in Melbourne recently. The government considers the health and wellbeing of Australian men to be of paramount importance. Responding to the needs in this area, our government has initiated various programs, including a recently funded study into the effectiveness of prostate cancer screening.

Also, among the myriad of grants this year to relevant organisations I was pleased to note funding to the Federation of Ethnic Communities Council to consider the health views and concerns of multicultural Australia. These views will be pivotal in formulating a clear and concise picture of the major health issues confronting people from non-English speaking backgrounds who have made Australia their home. I am well placed to comment on the worthiness of such programs. As you would know, Mr Deputy Speaker, I represent an electorate with a very high percentage of migrants, with whom I have constant contact, and programs of this ilk have very special significance for them. I am quite sure that my constituents will appreciate the government's efforts in this regard.

Whether it be finances and support to tackle HIV-AIDS, breast cancer, anorexia nervosa, hepatitis C, diabetes research, drug addiction, or projects to investigate reducing heart disease in the elderly through exercise, the government remains committed to the concept of equity for all Australians, despite the climate of mounting economic pressures. I am very pleased to support the tenets of this piece of legislation today, and I commend it to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning I was in Melbourne attending a meeting to talk about the shambles that the National Food Authority is in. I was not going to come in halfway through this debate. The member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) has very adequately put the coalition's position. After watching on the monitor the absolute rubbish that the member for Prospect and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Mrs Crosio) was saying, I thought I would come into this place and make a couple of points.

PARA.TAB: The member for Prospect attempts to misrepresent the coalition's position on health. This is nothing new; Labor has been doing this for years. As her justification for doing this, the member for Prospect uses the comments of one of our candidates standing for election to parliament. I would like to tell the member for Prospect that, unlike the Labor Party, it is actually the members of parliament who make policy in the coalition, not the candidates. That might be hard for the member for Prospect to understand, given the trade union involvement in the Labor Party. It might be hard for the member for Prospect to understand, given that people like Martin Ferguson are coming into the parliament to illuminate the intellectual capacity over there. The fact is that we make the policy, not the candidates. The candidates will learn that over time. To attempt to misrepresent—

TALK.START.PARA: —He was preselected by—
—Mr Deputy Speaker, can you stop this peanut gallery?

—On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker, I have never attempted to mislead this House. In fact, the about-to-be member for Bradfield at the next election actually campaigned in his preselection for the Liberal Party on stopping bulk-billing.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Fitzgibbon)—You are both senior members of the House. I think we can get on with the discussion without interjections.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you very much, Mr Deputy Speaker. The fact is that there is no substance whatsoever in what the member for Prospect says. A falsehood is not made true just because she says it time and time again. The position of the coalition on bulk-billing is absolutely clear. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) has said it. He is a man of integrity. The member for Prospect may have difficulty understanding that, too, coming from her side of politics. The fact is that bulk-billing stays.

PARA.TAB: The member then went on to laud Medicare because it is doing more with less. The reason it is doing more with less is casemix. The former minister for health Neal Blewett, in his farewell speech to this parliament, which I remember sitting in this chamber and listening to, lauded casemix as one of the great reforms to Medicare. He was right. States that are introducing it are doing more with less.

But the thing that irks me about this is that the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) gets up time and time again at the other dispatch box and disparages those states that are introducing casemix; then the parliamentary secretary gets up and says what a great achievement it is. You cannot have it both ways. You cannot criticise it when it suits you and then choose to have it as your own achievement when it works. You have had nothing to do with it other than to frustrate it, criticise it and then try to claim success for it when it works.

The parliamentary secretary said that length of stay was decreasing in public hospitals. Yes, it is. It has nothing to do with anything you have ever done. Firstly, it is an international trend and, secondly, it has to do with casemix.

TALK.START.PARA: —I never mentioned it.
—Read Hansard. You are forgetting what you are saying. Maybe you did not read the speech notes prepared for you before you gave your speech.
—I do my own. I don't know about you.
—I speak off the cuff. I don't have to write them out.
—Order! We have two pugnacious personalities here. The parliamentary secretary made her point. Perhaps you could make your points without involving personalities.
—I am just trying to give a speech, but I have a peanut gallery over there.
—The parliamentary secretary should cease interjecting.
—Shut the battleship's boiler down.
—And I ask the member for Stirling to restrain himself.

—Then I heard the greatest of all cheeks, the biggest of all misrepresentations: plans are under way to reduce waiting lists. How often have we heard that in this place? How often have we heard all the overblown rhetoric about what you are going to do on the waiting list issue? I will tell you how often: every time an election comes up.

PARA.TAB: I ask honourable members to think back to what happened at the last election, in 1993. Graham Richardson was the minister for health then. He had $100 million to fix waiting lists. How was the government going to pay for it? `We are going to pay for it by attacking all this fraud and over-servicing, and we are going to buy public beds in private hospitals.' How much of that $100 million promised at the last election was spent? I think the government has spent about $500,000 of it at John Flynn Hospital in Queensland. The plan was an absolute flop. The $100 million you were going to find from so-called fraud and over-servicing never materialised.

The fact is that you do not have the vaguest clue about how to address waiting lists. You promise and promise and we hear all the lofty, overblown rhetoric about it, but nothing ever happens. This so-called promise has come only because there is an election coming on; and it will flop like everything else you have tried to do to reduce waiting lists.

The parliamentary secretary then made an interesting contradiction. She made many contradictions; this is just one that I found interesting. She said, `It is no wonder the system is bogged down with new technology, advancements and everything else'—having said, `We are reducing lengths of bed stays.' The contradiction is that, if bed stays are coming down, we should have the capacity to do more, not have the system bogged down. I will tell you why the system is bogged down—

TALK.START.PARA: —I never said that.
—You cannot remember. Go back and read your notes.
—Listen to the debate when you come into the House. You probably lost some of yours coming into the House.
—I got the whole lot of it—and I got it without interjections. You were listened to without interjections, but you cannot give the same courtesy.
—Order! As I have said on previous occasions, this chamber works best when we have one speaker at a time.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy Speaker. I hope you do not have to warn the parliamentary secretary again. I will tell you why the system is bogged down. It is very simple. The Department of Human Services and Health reckons, on its own estimates, that the people who dropped out of private health insurance between 1 July 1993 and 30 September 1994 will use 322,000 public hospital bed days this year.

PARA.TAB: Now 322,000 public hospital bed days is about two quite large city public hospitals crammed full 365 days a year. So just those people who drop their private health insurance in a 15-month period are going to cram two big city hospitals full to the brim 365 days a year. You just cannot build an extra two public hospitals a year to cope with that. You have, therefore, a far greater number of people seeking to use a limited resource. The reason the public hospitals in Australia are bogged down, as your own department identified, is the drop-out from private health insurance.

Second, if you wish to ask any state leader of any political persuasion what the drop-out of private insurance is doing to the bottom line for their public hospital budgets, you would find that it is wreaking havoc. We are losing over two per cent of the Australian population every year from private health insurance and you cannot compensate for it, so the system gets bogged down and comes under strain.

You would love to blame new technology. You would love to blame anyone but yourself. But the fact is, the ideological blinkers that prevent the Labor Party from doing anything about private health insurance mean the public hospitals are brim full. The Labor Party may not understand this, the Australian public does.

By and large, one thing I do agree with the parliamentary secretary on is Medicare is a pretty good system and it provides a good number of benefits that the Australian public like. But let's not be dewy-eyed about it like the Labor caucus. The Secretary of the Department of Human Services and Health, Dr Duckett, in the Australian Health Review actually identified two failings of Medicare. The first was cost shifting between governments and the second was that Medicare is a poor setter of priorities. These are very important points.

I was having a discussion with a gynaecological oncologist some weeks ago, a person who treats gynaecological cancers. He said to me—it was about 2 o'clock in the afternoon—`Already today I have prescribed taxol illegally three times for public patients that I have contrived to be private patients, because if I don't do that they will not get the drugs they need for their cancer.' So one doctor in one morning had shifted $10,000 of costs from a state government onto the federal government. This is happening right across Australia and you do not have a clue how to address it.

The second area where this is happening is in imaging. We hear the Labor Party get stuck into diagnostic imaging for the great and rapid increase in its use—11 per cent compound a year—and if you took them at face value, you would actually be worried about it. But there is a very interesting thing with diagnostic imaging: we do not make any of the photographic plate to do the X-rays or the images in Australia; it is all imported. So, we know exactly how much photographic plate is coming into Australia. The fact is that in recent years the amount of photographic plate coming in has increased in parallel with the rise in population, yet the cost to the federal government is going up at 11 per cent per year.

Rather than get stuck into the radiology profession, you would be better to look at the cost shifting that your system encourages and that you have consistently failed to do anything about for a decade. Because the only explanation for those figures I have given is that the total amount of photographs being done in diagnostic imaging is pretty much the same. The 11 per cent increase comes because the federal government is paying for a lot more of them.

The second thing that Dr Duckett described as a `failure' of Medicare was that it is poor at setting priorities. We see this particularly in the area of preventative health. It was interesting that the parliamentary secretary finished her speech by extolling the virtues of what the government had done, or was doing, in preventative health. If there was something even vaguely genuine about what she said I would back her, but there is nothing genuine here. It is overblown rhetoric.

Medicare is poor at setting priorities. Our conflict is simply this: on one hand we have government departments and government ministers encouraging people to go out there, to get screened, to get tests done, to have a whole stack of things done, but, on the other hand, the same government ministers get upset when that generates new work, pushes up the country's pathology and radiological imaging bills, and—quite unfairly—the pathologists and the radiologists cop the flak for it.

The fact is that preventative health is an area of gross negligence. There is no better example than the immunisation of Australia's kids. Under Labor, 53 per cent of Australian children are fully immunised—26th worst out of 28 in the Western world. Try to explain that away! Vietnam can manage to have 97 per cent of its kids being immunised under a voluntary system.

And what is the government's response? It is, `Oh, well, we'll have a national register'. If you were to ring up the minister's press secretary, she would say, `Oh look, we have fixed that up; we gave $18 million in the budget to fix it'. But there is a problem with that: the $18 million is for only two years. If it is such a great scheme, why run it for only two years? The second problem is this: if we actually know that every second kid on the street is not fully immunised, we do not need a detailed register to tell us. There is no better example of the negligence and culpability of a government than its failure to immunise its kids.

There is a measles epidemic in Sydney at this very moment. There has recently been a whooping cough epidemic in Canterbury, an upper middle-class suburb of Melbourne. Those epidemics do not just threaten the kids who are not immunised, they threaten my four-month-old kid who is not fully immunised because, once a society drops below a certain level of immunisation, you get epidemics. The fact is, when you look at whooping cough, measles and rubella, the incidence in Australia has gone up 17 times in just the last five years. That is how quickly it can change if you drop the ball. That is preventative health.

The trouble is that some people in this place, like me, have long memories. I remember the Better Health Commission; I remember when it was set up in 1985; I remember the lofty, overblown rhetoric. Actually, I recently tracked down someone from the Better Health Commission and I asked them to tell me about it. The reply was very illustrative. They said, `On reflection, I think we were all conned; I think we were there to give the appearance of doing something while not actually doing anything at all'. The Better Health Commission reported in 1986; in 1988, goals and targets were published; they were republished in 1992 and republished in 1993. There were 400 goals and targets—basically, `If you've got a problem or you are an interest group, we have a goal and a target for you'. But, at some stage, you actually have to look at outcomes. At some stage you have to go beyond rhetoric. At some stage you have to judge a government not by what they say but by what they achieve.

Let me tell you what the chairman of the department of community medicine at the University of New South Wales, Professor Peter Baume—someone the government uses for its inquiries, even though he is a former coalition member—said about how many of those 400 goals and targets we will achieve by the year 2000. He said, `One'. The only goal and target we will achieve by the year 2000, according to Professor Baume, is in connection with childhood mortality, which has absolutely nothing to do with anything the federal government has done.

I heard the parliamentary secretary talk about diabetes education. I have a very personal interest in this. I have a memory, too. I remember the national diabetes action plan of 1988. Perhaps some of the government members would care to talk about what happened to that plan. This is an important area of preventative health. It took us 72 years, from the discovery of insulin in 1921 to 1993, to prove that good diabetic control leads to a reduction in symptoms. Those symptoms are nasty and include loss of limb, loss of eyesight, heart disease and kidney failure. We can prevent those symptoms. We could prevent them if the government had implemented what it promised it was going to do in 1988. We could have saved the country a lot of money, and we could have dramatically changed the life of those people and their families who had diabetes.

Another area of preventative medicine is that of folic acid supplementation. It is beyond controversy that, if women planning a pregnancy—and 60 per cent of pregnancies are planned—supplemented their diet with folic acid at the time of conception, it would cut the rate of spina bifida by half. One in 1,000 kids in Australia is born with spina bifida. Imagine what we could do if we could reduce that by half. Imagine the economic savings and the social savings. What percentage of Australian women know that? What percentage of Australian women planning a pregnancy supplement their diet with folic acid? My guess is less than five per cent. We have a lot of work to do here. We can do it cooperatively or we can keep doing it the way it has been done until now, with falsehoods and misrepresentations. Let us have no more of that humbug. We will judge the government not by what it says but by what it does.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition are at it again, saying that we are misrepresenting their policies—policies that we cannot see, policies that we have not seen, policies that the people of Australia are waiting for. They are saying that we have misrepresented them on industrial relations, but what we are doing is looking at their record. They are making similar claims regarding health, but again we are looking at their record. The fact is that they have opposed Medicare in the past. We are also taking into context the statement they made after the last election. They said, `We made a big mistake. We talked about our policies. Next time we had better not talk about our policies. Because we talked about the GST, the people voted against us. So next time we have to be more careful.' Is it any wonder that the people of Australia are looking at the opposition with increasing suspicion when they refuse to say what their policies are?

PARA.TAB: I want to touch on a couple of points that were made by the honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge). He talked about crammed hospitals and how we have neglected people who do not have private cover. What he did not point out is that there are new advantages for people who take up private health insurance. After about 15 years of not having any private health insurance, I am thinking about again taking it up myself. Before anyone says that someone like me should be able to take up private health insurance because I can afford to, I hasten to point out that our incomes determine what Medicare payments are taken out of our salaries. So it is according to income that one makes payments into Medicare, and that is a very fair system. Perhaps the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) pays more than twice as much as you or me and perhaps we pay twice as much as people on very low incomes. That is fair.

However, there is now an enticement for people to take up private health insurance. There is an arrangement between funds and private hospitals which, I believe, will change the context of what is happening in some of our public wards. People can obtain 100 per cent cover, and that is genuine cover. It does not mean that people are being told they can get 100 per cent of a determined fee and then find that the institution or the practitioner puts up the price even higher than the highest determined fee. It means genuine 100 per cent cover is available to people. The costs will all be listed on one bill, and it will be clear and transparent.

I do want to make a point about what the honourable member for Chisholm said about immunisation. This week I received a letter from an organisation which opposes compulsory immunisation. We have to recognise that unlike in Vietnam, which it quoted, there are people in Australia who believe it is their right not to have their children immunised. I am not sure whether we should take that into account; I do not propose to debate that at this stage. I would point out to the writer that we operate under different circumstances.

At the same time, I thoroughly agree with him that there ought to be immunisation of all children. The vaccines used are properly tested. There is no proven danger from most of the vaccines other than to people who are sensitive to them. I fully endorse what he said about the need for more immunisation in Australia but we need to take it in the context that we are operating in in Australia. When we had compulsory X-rays for all Australians, tuberculosis was almost wiped out in our nation. When that compulsory system of regular X-rays was removed, tuberculosis did creep back. We have to draw the line somewhere. That is what we are doing in health.

The legislation is not particularly controversial but it makes some important points. I would like to emphasise some of them. One is the empowerment of the Health Insurance Commission to engage in providing consulting, management and related services in the exercise of its powers and to perform its functions overseas. Just recently, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Long Term Strategies, which is chaired by our colleague the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones), had before it an expert who suggested that we ought to be selling our health and education systems overseas. He said that Medicare is something which could be of value to other countries. The Health Insurance Commission has already undertaken a number of consultancies primarily—but not exclusively—under the auspices of the World Bank. These activities are getting bigger. There is a need for the commission to have explicit provision to cover this sort of activity.

It is clear that we have one of the best health systems in the world. The recent issue of the Economist has indicated that the United Kingdom is having problems with its health system. It costs about seven per cent of its gross domestic product, whereas the United States health system, which is not a similarly organised system as it runs on the private system, consumes about 14 per cent of its gross domestic product—double that in the UK. Australia is in between. It has a better scheme than either of those systems. It has a very good scheme. It does not have the problems of the United States, for instance, of drugs sometimes being three times the price they are in Australia, because we have that negotiating between government and firms under our pharmaceutical benefits system. We have a good system and it is worth selling overseas. I applaud the fact that allowance is made for that in the legislation.

The legislation also makes provision for a number of amendments in relation to nursing homes which are being granted exempt bed status. As the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Throphaneous) said in the second reading speech to the bill, it is important that we have required standards of care and that the exempt bed status remains—or is given—to those nursing homes which satisfy the standards for nursing and personal care. That is particularly important. Those required standards include treating people with dignity.

Recently I was involved with the Archbishop of Canberra and Goulburn, Francis Carroll, in the opening of an extension to Currawanna in Bombala. That hostel for the frail aged has an enviable record. Not more than 85 per cent of the pension is charged to any client—pensioner client or non-pensioner client; that 85 per cent is the limit for all of them. That is because of very strong community support. One of the directors, Paddy Lomas, asked me to convey to the minister thanks for the personal care subsidies that go to Currawanna. I am pleased that the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) and the parliamentary secretary are in the House today to hear those thanks from the hostel for the frail aged in Bombala for that personal care subsidy which, they said, along with the tremendous community support they get, enables them to charge one of the lowest rates in New South Wales.

The Therapeutic Goods Amendment Bill is a short bill. Included is the placing of listable drugs supplied in Australia on the Australian register of therapeutic goods to cut product approval time to a matter of weeks without in any way affecting the quality or the safety of medicinal products. It is important that we acknowledge that the old procedure of demanding that westernised style medicine be provided to our patients and only legitimising that style of medicine has now gone.

One of the pioneers in this region was Dr Henry Pang, who was formerly with the ACT Health Service and who has now moved to provide services in a number of aid agencies around the world. The last I heard of him he was in Africa after serving in the Middle East. He practised medicine which included not just Western medicine but also some of the concepts of Eastern medicine and of alternative medicine. There are practitioners in Australia today who are able to do that on a much wider scale than they were in the past. Our general practitioners are acknowledging the truth that is in alternate medicine procedures. When I say `alternative' I mean alternative to the traditional form of Western medicine.

It is important that, when that happens, all that we provide in the way of drugs or therapeutic goods should contain what they are stated to contain on the labels. It is important, too, that illegal therapeutic goods of unknown quality, safety and efficacy should be removed from the market. So, while we acknowledge the validity of alternative medicine and alternate treatments, we also ought to perform our duty to people and ensure that there is quality and safety within the medicinal products. I am pleased to support both pieces of legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr E.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

SPEECH.PARA: "whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House—

(a)notes the incompetent way in which this legislation was originally managed in its passage through the Parliament, so that the original Bill was divided by the Senate and thus rendered inoperable; and
(b)condemns the Labor Government for its cavalier and arrogant treatment of the institution of Parliament as revealed by the history of these measures".

I would like to reiterate some concerns I have about this legislation which I have stated previously in this place, and that is to do with the changes to the Therapeutic Goods Act dealing with the definition of `food'. Item 2, subsection 3(1) of the bill inserts a definition of `food' which I will not read into the Hansard as it has been referred to fairly extensively by the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles). I was delighted to note a few moments ago in the gallery the presence of an eminent Western Australian medical scientist, Cheryll McCullough. I am sure she will be most interested in this debate.

PARA.TAB: The reason I am taking an interest in a particular section of this bill is not because of my immense enjoyment of food—which would be immediately evident to even the most casual observer—but because of a complaint from a constituent of mine, Mr Morris Czarniack. Mr Czarniack was recently fined $96,000 for allegedly breaching the Therapeutic Goods Act.
Before going on about this case, let me submit an alternative definition of food. Gould Medical Dictionary defines it in this way:

SPEECH.PARA: Any organic substance which, when ingested or taken into the body of an organism through some alternate means and assimilated, may be used either to supply energy or build tissue; classified in three groups: proteins, carbohydrates, and fats, all of which may occur in animal or vegetable substance.
Mosby's dictionary defines food in this way:

Any substance, usually of plant or animal origin, consisting of carbohydrates, proteins, fats, and such supplementary elements as minerals and vitamins, that is ingested or otherwise taken into the body and assimilated to provide energy to promote growth, repair, and maintenance essential for sustaining life.

I know that we have covered this matter in the debate on the Human Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1995. However, since the government made errors and has been forced to reintroduce this bill, I will put to the House the further concerns of Mr Czarniack, whom I mentioned when I spoke on the last bill.

PARA.TAB: The reason I mentioned the medical definition of food is to contrast it with the legislation we are debating. Mr Czarniack recently went on trial for selling a product called Well Being Essiac Herbal Mist, which the Therapeutic Goods Administration deemed to be in breach of the Therapeutic Goods Act. The product was made only of food products—that is, food according to the definitions of the medical dictionaries. Certainly in their individual states, the ingredients would probably also fall within the definition used in this legislation.

At the time I previously spoke about this matter, I pointed out that Mr Czarniack's house was raided by 11 federal police simply for selling a product made only of food products. I sympathised with him then, but, since the recent events at my own office, my sympathy to him and his family is even greater. Mr Czarniack was charged with selling a product which breached the Therapeutic Goods Act. He asserted that his product was simply a food product which was not consumed in the normal ways but was rubbed into the skin and absorbed by the skin.

According to Mr Czarniack, his product fell within the definition of food. To prove that, he even ate the product. He spooned it into this mouth and swallowed it. He ate the stuff, yet according to this legislation it is not food. Perhaps it was a Clayton's food—the food you have when you are not really having food. Mr Czarniack's cream was full of nutrients which, according to the medical dictionary, are those products that afford nutrition. Nutrition is defined as:

SPEECH.PARA: The sum processes concerned in the growth, maintenance and repair of the living body as a whole or its constituent parts, especially those processes most directly involved in the intake, metabolism and utilisation of food.

Mr Czarniack's creams were made only of food products. When mixed together, they formed a cream which was rubbed into the skin. The active ingredient was egg; that is, that is the ingredient that assisted the other ingredients to be absorbed or ingested and taken into the body. All the other ingredients were food as well. The eggs simply allowed the other foods of nutritional value to be ingested through one's skin. For that, Mr Czarniack had his home, pharmacy and his parents' home raided by 11 federal police and he was fined $96,000. It does sound farcical. It would be funny if it were not completely true.

PARA.TAB: As I understand it, Mr Czarniack's theory was that certain parts of the skin are lacking in nutrition and are therefore impaired, so to speak. Mr Czarniack thought that the best route to feed nutrients to that area of the body was as close as possible to it. His theory was to feed the nutrients in through the skin. He mixed in together the foods he thought relevant. They were to provide the nutrients. Adding the egg enabled the nutrients to be absorbed or ingested through the skin. Essentially, the skin ingests the food and the body is being fed, just in a completely different way. Nevertheless, it does not stop his creams being defined as food, just as the stuff fed through the nasogastric tubes is still food, no matter how it is ingested.

Mr Czarniack was charged and fined because it was alleged that his products were therapeutic and breached the TGA. He disputed this, saying it was simply food. Following his case, these amendments came in offering a definition of food under the TGA. It suggests that food means goods for oral consumption which meet certain criteria. The oral consumption requirement alone would exclude Mr Czarniack's goods. While only made of food, they would not be considered food because they are not taken orally but are rubbed into the skin. The reason I am speaking up for Mr Czarniack is that I believe he has been treated very unfairly. While I have no problem with there being a definition of food in the legislation, I question the definition and why a product made completely of foods—and it falls within the definition of foods according to the medical dictionaries—will not be a food by this legislation, even though it can be eaten and swallowed.

So what if it is used as a cream? It is still food. I understand Mr Czarniack would not register his product with the TGA because it would have exposed the make-up of the product to his competitors, whom I understand reported him to the TGA. But the legislation did not offer him protection from their stealing his idea, the essential qualities of his product—and perhaps that is something which should be considered for future changes to the legislation.

I understand that the TGA argued Mr Czarniack's products were therapeutic. He argued they were simply a food. Since then, we find this legislation has made it to the House to offer a definition of food, and I guess the story would go that Mr Czarniack could not call his products food because they do not fall within the TGA definition, though they would, I understand, fall within the definitions offered in medical dictionaries.

Mr Czarniack took the view that his product was not a therapeutic good but simply a food product consumed in an alternative way but which was beneficial to the body, as food is by definition. I concede that claims about the qualities of the product may have constituted it as therapeutic. It is perhaps the fault of the legislation that this gentleman, an innovative and creative man, can be punished so severely for showing some flair and inventiveness. I trust the government will take on board the views of Mr Czarniack. He is, as I say, a creative and innovative man whose initiative should be nurtured and not legislated against. He needs to be approached by the Department of Human Services and Health and have the views of small inventors and pharmacists listened to.

I fear this legislation, or at least parts thereof, is at the instigation of bigger companies who disliked the competition Mr Czarniack was offering. I concede Mr Czarniack's products may fall within definitions of the TGA for therapeutic qualities in that they may be promoted as performing a certain function. But, at the end of the day, it is still just plain old food. I take it this legislation is now here to stop Mr Czarniack and his innovations, perhaps at the behest of the large multinationals.

I should add I have been contacted by many constituents who had in the past used these products and found a need for them. They could not understand how Mr Czarniack was being victimised, as he was, by officials from the TGA. They could not understand why they were not allowed to consume his products.

I will conclude by making a few points about which I hope the parliamentary secretary can satisfy my curiosity. The definition in this legislation for food says it must provide hydration. On that point, would ice, because of its application to reduce swelling, inflammation and so on be considered therapeutic and, therefore, cause water authorities, ice vendors and so on to register with the TGA? How about yoghurt? We all know that yoghurt has therapeutic uses, one of them being that women can apply it to their vaginas to treat thrush. Yoghurt is a food but it appears it would not be treated as food by this definition because it must be taken orally.

It is the same with vinegar. Vinegar, as we all know, is pretty effective in treating forms of insect and marine bites. It is rubbed onto the skin and not taken orally; so, if vinegar is used therapeutically, it cannot be claimed to be a food. This may be drawing a long bow in comparison to Mr Czarniack's case, but the principle I believe is pretty much the same.

Another part of the definition of food is that it must satisfy a hunger. Does that mean bulking agents which have therapeutic claims and which satisfy a hunger will be classed as food even though they have no nutritional value? Why can we have therapeutic goods which satisfy a hunger or thirst but which offer no nutrition?

I would again urge members of the department to listen to people like Mr Czarniack. He is not a witch doctor. I have met him on quite a number of occasions over the years. He does not have two heads. He does not oscillate dead cats over his head in cemeteries at midnight. He is just an ordinary bloke trying to run a business. I hope these concerns of his are heeded. I look forward to hearing of dialogue between the department and Mr Czarniack.

Finally, I would like to address a few comments made earlier in the debate by the member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio). She was telling us about how great Medicare is. Labor has lied about the Medicare levy, as you would know. They have bumped it up since its introduction, which has only resulted in more people leaving private health insurance. Membership of private health insurance has dropped from 91.5 per cent in 1983 to 35 per cent in August this year. That is why we have over 100,000 people waiting for elective surgery.

What has Labor done about this problem? Not a single thing. I predict that at the next election Labor will tell porky after porky about our health policy. They lied about it at the last election and they will do it again. That is why they do not support truth in political advertising. If Medicare is so great, why are doctors telephoning my office saying that Medicare has not paid them for their bulk billing? One doctor is still waiting for $18,000, which Medicare owes him and which has been overdue for some time. Another doctor is waiting for $11,000. As the member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) said in a debate earlier this week, he wanted:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to tell the chamber about the neglect of the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) in the administration of her department. Right now there are tens of millions of dollars in Medicare bills that have not been paid and which have been outstanding for over a month. The minister claims that the Health Insurance Commission wants an 11-day turnaround. In August, after one month, 1 1/2 million bills remain unpaid.

PARA.TAB: In other words, the HIC has been sitting on over $33 million which should have been paid weeks earlier. Some 10 per cent of bills have not been paid. Maybe the minister has been distracted from administering her portfolio, but this raises very serious questions about the sort of job she is doing.

SPEECH.PARA: Just to correct the propaganda being spouted by the member for Prospect earlier—and this was also mentioned by the member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge)—I point out that it seems to me that members of the government think that if they repeat the lie often enough people will believe it. They are experts at rewriting history. I put on the record that last year over 100,000 Australians were waiting in queues for elective surgery—a third of those had been waiting for over six months.

PARA.TAB: In Labor's 1983 election policy the then Labor leader, Bob Hawke, promised Medicare would mean that `nine out of 10 Australians will pay less for the health needs of themselves and their families'. Health costs have increased since 1983 beyond the rate of inflation. Mr Hawke said in his 1984 election policy in November 1984:

SPEECH.PARA: For the term of our next government the Medicare levy will not be increased.
The levy was increased from one per cent to 1.25 per cent from December 1986. Health Minister Blewett said to the Australian on 23 January 1990:
I could give a guarantee that there would be no increase in the (1.25%) levy and fundamental changes to Medicare over the three year period.

Labor subsequently introduced a $2.50 Medicare co-payment from June 1991, which it subsequently replaced with an increase in the levy to 1.4 per cent, announced in August 1992 and effective from July 1993. The Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) said on 19 June 1994:
There is no proposal to increase the levy and there won't be.

The levy was increased from 1.4 per cent to 1.5 per cent from 1 July 1995. You might have been able to con the people at the election in 1993, but I think the battlers have had it up to their necks with the Labor Party. They will not believe you again.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Snow)—Is the amendment seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haviland Mr C.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not be supporting the amendment that has been moved by the member for Stirling (Mr Cameron). Last week in a debate on industrial relations, I made the comment that if there is one issue in this House that gets the opposition fired up it is industrial relations. I guess I have to say that there are two issues. There are two issues which I love to debate—industrial relations and human services and health issues.

PARA.TAB: There are clearly defined differences between the views of the Labor Party and the views of the opposition in terms of these two issues. For a number of reasons, I always had a lot of pleasure speaking on human services and health legislation. One of the reasons is that it highlights the differences between the government and the opposition on matters of basic public and social policy.

We just heard the usual nonsense about Medicare. I was intrigued by the member for Stirling's comments about private health insurance membership numbers. He said that the numbers had dropped from 91 per cent in 1983 to 35 per cent now. I wonder why that happened. He seems to have forgotten that in 1983 there was no Medicare; there was no national health system. Unless you were a pension or a welfare beneficiary you had to have private health insurance. No wonder 91 per cent of people had private health insurance. Now only 35 per cent of people have private health insurance. I will come to that point in a minute. The private health insurance reforms of this government are in the news again today.

I always enjoy speaking in support of government legislation, particularly bills that have been introduced by this minister at the table, the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence), because we have made a lot of worthwhile reforms to the health system. Medicare is a fine system. It is the best health insurance system in the world. It is the envy of other Western countries such as the United States. Some people in the current US administration have certainly expressed interest in how Medicare works. But just because Medicare is a great system does not mean that we cannot continue to improve it. That is what this government is doing with the various pieces of legislation that it has introduced into the parliament.

Earlier on today we had the coalition's health spokesperson, the member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge), in here attacking the government over health and over Medicare in his usual churlish manner. Now we have a fairly churlish amendment, which no doubt we will have to vote on later today, moved by the member for Stirling, trying to score political points on Medicare and on health. As at the last election when health and industrial relations along with the GST were defining issues, I expect that, once again, both health and industrial relations will be defining issues in the minds of the Australian public when they go to vote at the next election—whenever that is going to take place.

This morning I was interested to hear that one of the lead items on the ABC News was concern about how this government's private health insurance legislation, which is supposed to take effect from next Sunday, 1 October, was in trouble. Apparently, it was in trouble because the AMA is going out and telling its members who are doctors not to sign the contracts, which would sabotage the intent of the private health insurance legislation—even though some doctors have already indicated they will sign the contracts.

It is interesting to look at the issue of contracts and the coalition's policy—or lack of it—in relation to the industrial relations debate. This week we have had a bit of focus on industrial relations. That is not surprising given the obvious intent of the coalition, if it ever does get elected to government, to take some pretty draconian measures on industrial relations. The `take the contract or take the sack' mentality will come in. It has been foreshadowed at every election since 1983 that, if the coalition were ever elected, we would have these attacks on trade unions.

Wouldn't it be interesting if we applied that philosophy to the private health insurance legislation? We could say to the doctors, `Well, either take the contract or we don't pay you Medicare benefits any more.' How would that sit? How would the AMA react then? It would be very interesting to consider the attitude of the AMA, which in some senses is a bit of a trade union—although that is stretching the term a bit, I think. With apologies to the rest of the legitimate trade union movement, the AMA does act as a bit of a trade union, a union of doctors. It is a pretty greedy, grubby one at that. Nevertheless, in some senses it does play that role. It is now urging its members not to sign the contracts under the private health insurance legislation.

I refer to a speech that I made in this House on 27 March in which I drew the attention of the House to comments by the new Liberal candidate for the seat of Bradfield, Dr Brendan Nelson. He was quoted in the Australian Health and Aged Care Journal in February this year as saying the following:

SPEECH.PARA: In some areas of policy I will be seen as very liberal and progressive, and in others I'll be quite dry. For example, in the field of industrial relations, I assume a position perhaps even to the right of John Howard.

That is Dr Brendan Nelson's position on industrial relations. Of course, he is the former President of the Australian Medical Association. I ask the question again: wouldn't it be interesting if we applied the same sort of industrial relations philosophy of the Liberal Party—that is, take the contract or take the sack—to health policy? Perhaps we could tell the doctors that if they do not do it our way we will stop paying them medicare benefits. I do not think that would go down too well—why should we accept it in industrial relations?—especially after the great lengths that this government has gone to in the area of private health insurance to deal with the issue of falling numbers in health insurance.

PARA.TAB: Quite frankly, if it were up to me I would let the numbers drop altogether. I am a great believer in the public health system. I know that private health insurance has its purposes and, in the area of ancillary benefits as opposed to hospital benefits, I am still a member of a private health insurance fund—Medibank Private. I know that a number of people are. In areas that Medicare does not cover, such as dentistry, chiropractic and physiotherapy, private health insurance does come in handy.

In the area of hospital cover we have falling numbers. But this government, through the legislation that was passed eventually by both houses, has bent over backwards—it has gone to great lengths—to deal with that by bringing in a more efficient and comprehensive scheme whereby private health insurance can be useful and the erosion of private health insurance numbers can be stopped. But what does the AMA want to do? It wants to sabotage it. It wants to coax its members not to sign contracts, obviously in the hope that it will fall over.

What do we hear from the coalition? The coalition do not seem to have a health policy at the moment. I guess in a sense that is not surprising. The last five that they have had failed dismally at the polls. We are still waiting to hear what their health policy will be at the next election. I guess the reason we have not heard yet is that the AMA has not written it for them.

The opposition accuses the government of having vested interests at heart, and having a special relationship with the trade union movement. Why shouldn't we have one? The very history of the Labor Party is tied up with trade unionism in Australia, so why would we not have a special relationship with the working people of Australia and with those elected to represent the working people in the workplace—the trade union movement? Certainly the coalition does not have such a relationship. We all know what will happen if the coalition get in. The Accord will be ripped up and we will have draconian legislation and draconian industrial relations policies that we have heard about already this week.

The AMA, another special interest group which drives just about all of coalition policy on health—or what there is of policy—has not written the coalition's policy for the next election yet, and that is why we have not heard what it is. I guess we will be waiting for the sixth attempt by the coalition to come up with some coherent health policy. I do not expect that it will be much better than the previous five.

Health, like industrial relations, will be a battleground in the election and a fairly easy one for the government to knock over the coalition on once again, because they just do not have an answer. Medicare is here to stay. The coalition talks about how they now embrace Medicare. They even embrace basic bulk-billing. Maybe the penny is starting to drop. But they still do not mind having a whack at us when they come in here moving churlish amendments and attacking the minister and the government on health policy. What is their policy? When is the AMA going to provide the opposition with their policy? Obviously they have not written it yet.

This government continues, as with this legislation, to further improve our health system. We do not rest on our laurels. Just because we have Medicare and it works does not mean that we cannot try to improve it, as we are doing in cooperation with COAG and state governments in the coordinated care trials which have been advertised in the last week or so and are for public discussion.

We will continue to do that. The Labor government is about reforming and making the health system accessible to all Australians and equitable for all Australians. That is why legislation such as this—even though in this case it does talk about relatively minor amendments to various pieces of legislation—is part of this government's determination to continue improving the health system and making it fairer and more equitable for all Australians. I commend the legislation to the House.

TALKER.NAME: Dr THEOPHANOUS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Human Services and Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend members for their contributions to the health bills. I want to respond to a couple of matters that were raised. It is interesting that the opposition raised the question of the behaviour of the Senate in forcing us to actually split this bill into two and to come back with two different bills. We were accused by the opposition of wasting the time of the parliament. What an extraordinary claim. It was the Senate's behaviour in the first instance which forced all of these changes.

PARA.TAB: You might have understood that if there were some matter of enormous moment, if there were some issue that they wanted to bring out which they wanted to deal with in some dramatic way, but we have had no amendments moved to the legislation, with no indication from the opposition parties that there is anything particularly that they want to go on about. So one wonders what the whole point of that exercise was in requiring the two bills to be separated. But then to say that we were wasting parliamentary time is an absurdity. The reality is that it was they and other parties in the Senate that forced this division of the bill into two. We are happy to re-present it in that form to accommodate people, but it is a bit rich to then come in here and say we were wasting parliamentary time. It is they that have done this in this matter.

Precisely because there are not really that many controversial issues in this legislation, even though it deals with a whole range of programs in health and some in human services, we have had a very wide ranging debate and discussion. What has essentially happened is that, because people did not have much to say about the bill and the legislation, they have turned—especially the opposition members—to having a go at the government in relation to our policies, particularly the health policy.

There has been very little that has been raised on the bill itself. There were some matters concerning the administration of therapeutic goods, but the government is putting into place through this bill a number of amendments to further streamline that administration to make that administration easier and, more importantly, to overcome problems where there has been criminal or quasi-criminal activity in relation to therapeutic goods. The House has not opposed that. So the overall thrust is that the bill's general provisions obviously are being supported.

That leads me to discuss some of the matters raised by honourable members. I suppose the opposition's general gripe, because they had very little to say about the bill itself, was an attack on the government and the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) on general health policies. The shadow minister, the honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge), hardly said anything about the bill but actually proceeded along those lines. It is not possible to reply to everything that he said, and I am sure the minister will in due course deal with some of the issues which he has raised. They are not directly relevant to this particular legislation. But simply coming into this House and uttering certain generalisations is not effective criticism. It is not criticism that anyone is going to take seriously. If the shadow minister has any concrete concerns, he should raise those concrete concerns by reference to facts, and not simply after discussions with some of his Liberal colleagues, especially Liberal health ministers in the states.

In relation to the two relevant issues that he raised, as I said, the minister has already put into place a number of very important programs. I am referring here to hospital waiting times and the issues surrounding private health insurance. It is a bit rich to have the shadow minister trying to lecture us about things like hospital waiting times when we have a situation where several of the state governments that are controlled by conservatives, controlled by their forces, are actually dramatically cutting back expenditure and cutting back the provision of services in health, especially in relation to public hospitals.

The experience that we have had with the Kennett government in Victoria has been appalling. On the one hand, the minister concerned, Marie Tehan, lectures us about health insurance while, on the other hand, her arrangements in relation to hospitals have brought about dramatic cutbacks in the provision of public hospitals in Victoria—something which is recognised not only by the Labor Party but by the newspapers and a whole range of independent observers in Victoria.

What has been the response of the Kennett government when these claims have been made? It has virtually abused those people who have made the claims rather than dealt with the issue. Mr Kennett finally found that this approach was not working and, during Christmas and New Year, he went around visiting all the public hospitals in Victoria, trying to chat to people about how concerned he was—not about additional money, not about the fact that he had made all those cutbacks—as if that was going to reassure them or create better hospitals in Victoria.

If the opposition wants to talk seriously about health policy and the delivery of health services, why does it not begin by having a chat to those conservative state health ministers who have disgracefully attacked health, one of the basic human needs of our society? We do not hear much even from the shadow minister; we certainly do not hear the Leader of the Opposition telling Mr Kennett, Mr Court or any of the other conservative Premiers that the cutbacks in health ought to be reconsidered. Then opposition members say that the problems of hospital queues, for example, are simply a matter for the federal government, when we have put into place a whole range of health initiatives and continue to do so. When the state governments misuse those initiatives and do not put the money to the intended purposes, that is a bit much.

The shadow minister also raised the issue of immunisation. He claimed that the immunisation program was not succeeding and that we were not doing enough. He had raised this matter with the minister's office, which arranged for a briefing for him by the department on the matter. Notwithstanding that briefing, he came into the House and tried to make some kind of political capital on the issue of immunisation. He raised questions about the number of people involved, the shortfalls in immunisation, for example, as if the government is not aware of it and not doing anything about it.

In fact, we are establishing a very important register to try to determine the extent of immunisation for different illnesses among particular groups of children. We are trying to set up a comprehensive register of children's immunisation records in order to do even more to ensure that they are. What is wrong with that? He says that this is a token measure. That is nonsense. It is a very important initiative which will be followed through to ensure that those groups of children that have been discovered as having missed out will be immunised. The register is not a token gesture; it is a very important part of a process of systematically dealing with this issue. We reject that general attack from the shadow minister.

The Minister for Human Services and Health has shown a great awareness of this whole area of preventative health. Since she became minister we have taken up a whole range of preventative health matters that the states have failed to take up and we have taken up matters which have not been taken up previously by the Commonwealth. Despite this, the shadow minister claims that these initiatives are to account for nought. That is very unfair criticism of the minister, and it is certainly not backed by any facts or by any significant argument.

He mentioned that there are 400 goals and targets in health and then he said that, according to a discussion that he had had with Professor Peter Baume, only one of those targets is going to be met. I do not know where he gets that idea from, but this government is in the business of meeting its targets. We are always being criticised by the opposition, which claims that we will not meet our targets. For example, we were criticised at the time of the last election when we promised 500,000 additional jobs. The opposition claimed that we would not meet that target. In fact, we have met our target in two years instead of three years and we are exceeding our employment target.

When we make commitments in relation to goals and targets in health by the year 2001, we will meet those goals and targets. It is not just empty rhetoric; we are committed. If, as can be the case when we have such a range of targets, we encounter a situation where we find specific problems, specific blockages or specific impediments, we are not going to sit on our hands; we are going to overcome those problems and impediments because we are determined to achieve those outcomes.

The shadow minister made all sorts of generalised criticisms of the government's health policy, but he mentioned absolutely nothing about what the opposition intend to do in health policy and program implementation. He said nothing about what they intend to do on the key issues, even the ones that he referred to. He said nothing about how the opposition intend to make arrangements with the states—because health involves extensive policy negotiations with the states. There was nothing about the opposition's spending commitments in the health area. There was absolutely nothing in policy terms.

How serious are we to take the kinds of criticisms that he makes? We are looking forward to when the opposition actually announce something. The only thing that we know about their health policy is that they now agree with our policy on Medicare, or at least they say they do. The fact that most of the Australian population does not believe them is another matter. Why would anyone believe them? At every election since 1983 they have opposed the fundamental universal principles of the Medicare system.

When John Howard was Leader of the Opposition previously he was opposed to Medicare. However, there has now been some kind of conversion by his party colleagues. Why has there been a conversion? Is it because they sincerely believe in the principles of Medicare? No. Is it because they have finally been persuaded of the social justice aspects of Medicare? No. Notwithstanding the opposition's continuing attacks on Medicare over all those years, the Australian population still supports Medicare in a very big way. Therefore, the opposition have taken the view that, if they are going to have any hope of winning the next election, they had better rid themselves of their opposition to Medicare.
