For this shallow reason—not an embracing of the fact that the Australian people and the Australian Labor Party were correct on the Medicare issue, but simply for a shallow, narrow, political reason—they are going to try to tell people that they accept Medicare and especially the bulk-billing aspect.

We know about the links between the Australian Medical Association and the opposition. Are we really to believe that, if the opposition were to be elected, the AMA, after its constant, systematic attacks on key aspects of Medicare, is going to say to the opposition, `We've helped you get elected, but now we don't want you to do anything about changing the nature of Medicare'? You can be sure that if the opposition was to be elected there would be enormous pressure from the AMA and other interest groups to change certain key elements of Medicare.

Why would the Australian people believe that the opposition, with their total lack of commitment to the social justice principles of Medicare over all those years, are going to withstand this kind of pressure? The newfound enthusiasm by the opposition for Medicare is shallow and the Australian people will not believe them if they go forward and say, `We intend to retain Medicare as a key feature of our health policy.' We want to make this point to the Australian people—and we will in the election context.

The other thing that we will do is point out the opposition's total failure to come out with any significant policy in the area of health. If they manage something before the election, we can be sure it is going to be full of generalisations without too much in the way of specific content, and when that is the case I can assure you that the Australian people will not be fooled by such generalised sweeteners in the area of health. They will be looking at the performance of the Liberal and National parties in the states—at what they have done with health when they have gained state government. That is what they will be looking at. And what they have done with health is outrageous, totally unacceptable, contrary to the principles of social justice and certainly very bad for ordinary Australians, especially low income earners.

So let us not hear any more of this cant and hypocrisy from the opposition. Let us see some commitment—if they have any—to real concrete policies. Then we are ready to debate those policies if they ever come up with them.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEVIS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill amends the Higher Education Funding Act 1988—the act—to implement budget decisions to increase student places and research funding. The costs of these initiatives will be offset by the reallocation of existing discretionary funds, reduction of pipeline places for Victoria, and refinements to the higher education contribution scheme, HECS.

PARA.TAB: The 1995-96 federal budget decisions reflected in this bill demonstrate clearly that the government is maintaining its commitment to the development of a high quality and accessible higher education system. They also confirm the government's ongoing policy of no up-front fees for Australian undergraduate students. They strengthen the government's commitment to HECS as the mechanism whereby Australian undergraduate students make an equitable contribution to the costs of their education. The changes in HECS build on the essential features of the scheme and bring forward revenue which will assist growth of the higher education sector without increasing the size of any student's HECS debt or reducing the thresholds at which repayments must commence.

The act sets out maximum amounts for grants to institutions. This bill amends the act to reflect changes in expenditure as a result of the budget initiatives to provide new places, additional research funds and the carry-forward of quality funds. The bill includes funding for 1997 and 1998.

The amendments provide funding for 5,850 new higher education places, plus pipeline, in the years 1996 to 1998. These places will go to states with strong population growth and currently low participation rates. Queensland will be the major beneficiary of these new places; New South Wales, Tasmania and Western Australia will also receive some places. The higher education budget package provides for funding of growth in other states in 1999.

The Victorian government has previously expressed fears that as many as 10,000 higher education places would be redistributed from Victoria to other states to address growing differences in higher education participation rates and population growth. The provision of extra places to Queensland, New South Wales, Tasmania and Western Australia has, however, been achieved without any reduction in the existing funding level or number of places at any university. There will be a minor reallocation of some of the growth anticipated in Victoria but Victorian institutions will still experience small increases in both funds and places and participation and access rates in Victoria will remain significantly higher than in other states until at least 2003.

Amendments to the act also increase the total funds available for research infrastructure to about $293 million over the 1996-1998 triennium. This represents an additional $109 million for research infrastructure. This reflects the government's consistent view that an adequate research infrastructure is crucial for universities to maintain their research and research training capacity at internationally competitive levels.

The amendments also provide an additional $40 million for competitive research grants to assist the nation to maintain and strengthen its research capabilities and to enhance the contribution made by research and scientific development to national economic and social goals. This funding will be made available through the Australian Research Council and is on top of the $350 million already committed for these purposes over the 1996-1998 triennium.

There is also a welcome boost to opportunities available for outstanding research students. From 1996 there will be an extra 100 Australian postgraduate awards on top of the 1,600 already available. In addition there will be five new postdoctoral fellowships making a total of 55 from 1996.

The amendments establish the higher education innovations program. This program amalgamates the national priority—reserve—fund and the quality assurance program. The higher education innovations program will continue to provide incentives to maintain and enhance the quality of higher education as well as provide funding for specific innovative projects of national priority.

All of the initiatives outlined are achieved without any net additional expenditure and without introducing up-front fees for Australian undergraduate students. A vital element in this package is a set of refinements to HECS which bring forward revenue but do not increase the size of an individual's HECS debt. It is only by making these changes that the government is able to deliver substantial improvements in the higher education sector without recourse to the easy, but fiscally irresponsible, course of increasing overall government expenditure. One such refinement introduces an extra incentive for early repayment of HECS debts by allowing a 15 per cent discount on voluntary payments of $500 or more.

Another initiative introduces a voluntary option whereby HECS debtors can elect to repay their debt at a lower threshold and receive a 10 per cent discount. If HECS debtors elect to take up the option, they will make a commitment to repay their accumulated HECS debt at two per cent of assessable income when they are above a specified threshold—$20,000 in 1995-96—but below the first compulsory threshold—$27,674 in 1995-96. Their outstanding HECS debt will then be reduced by 10 per cent. This change will not be mandatory. A person choosing to take up the offer will lodge an election form with the Australian Taxation Office, which will `trigger' the discount and repayments when the person falls within the specified income range.

These initiatives build on the essential features of the HECS scheme. They not only benefit the Commonwealth through earlier repayment of the HECS debts, but provide a significant benefit to the HECS debtor by introducing discounts in the size of their HECS debt.The government has created a more flexible, accessible and dynamic higher education system and is committed to introducing policies that make further improvements. The government, however, believes that its policies for access to publicly funded higher education should meet, first and foremost, the needs of Australian citizens and those who have demonstrated a long-term commitment to Australia.

Consistent with this, the act amends the HECS provisions so that New Zealand citizens, and Australian permanent residents of three years standing or more who have not become Australian citizens, pay their HECS contribution up-front at enrolment. They will also have no further access to the open learning deferred payment scheme—OLDPS. Those students who have had their application for citizenship approved by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs may continue to defer their HECS and OLDPS contributions. This will ensure that students who have had a citizenship application approved but who may have to wait some months to attend a citizenship ceremony will not be financially disadvantaged.

As with other changes to HECS, the revenue brought forward as a result of this change will be used to fund additional higher education student places. The discount on mandatory up-front HECS payments is removed by these amendments. Under HECS, students who pay their contribution up-front at enrolment receive a discount of 25 per cent on their payment. This provides an incentive to pay up-front. This is not appropriate for those students who are precluded from deferring their contribution.

Another measure relates to the provision of HECS exemption scholarships for teachers. These scholarships were introduced in 1989 to support a greater degree of professional development among teachers. Since that time, the government has introduced a new, more flexible $60 million national professional development program which addresses much of the same objectives.

As a result of this initiative, and in light of the priority to provide additional undergraduate opportunities, the $4.8 million previously allocated to teacher HECS exemption scholarships will be reallocated to help create student places. In future, Commonwealth support for the professional development of teachers will be provided solely through the national professional development program. As the scholarship program will cease from the end of 1995, there will be no need for a provision in the act exempting scholarship holders from HECS liability, and the act will be amended accordingly.

Currently under HECS there are three rates of repayment—three per cent, four per cent and five per cent of taxable income—depending on the debtor's level of taxable income. As part of the 1995 budget, the government is introducing four additional repayment rates, of 3.5 per cent, 4.5 per cent, 5.5 per cent and six per cent of HECS repayment income. The 3.5 per cent and 4.5 per cent rates are intermediate repayment rates and operate in a range between existing threshold levels. The 5.5 per cent and six per cent rates are additional repayment rates being set above the existing maximum threshold level. These additional repayment thresholds will return revenue to the Commonwealth at a faster rate without increasing the size of the HECS debt for individuals.

An amendment to the act also redefines taxable income for HECS assessment purposes. From 1 July 1996, if a HECS debtor's taxable income has been reduced by a net rental loss—commonly referred to as `negative gearing'—then for HECS assessment purposes the amount of rental loss claimed will be added to the debtor's taxable income. For income earned in income year 1996-1997, and in subsequent income years, HECS assessable income will be used to determine whether or not a HECS debtor is required to make a compulsory repayment against their HECS debt.

It is a principle underlying HECS that students in publicly funded higher education places should be expected to make a contribution towards the cost of their tuition when, and only when, they have the financial capacity to do so. It is the government's intention that, by instituting this budget measure, those with the financial capacity to repay their HECS debt but who are in a position to minimise their income by claiming rental loss in their individual tax return will no longer be able to avoid making repayments on their HECS contribution.

In summary, I stress that this bill presents a very tightly integrated package of measures which provides for growth in student places where they are needed, enhances research funds and postgraduate scholarships, does not alter the fundamental elements of HECS nor require reallocation of any existing student places, and does not increase overall government outlays. This package, or `cocktail' as it has become known in the higher education sector, was developed following extensive consultations with the higher education sector.

As I indicated at the time the budget was handed down, any attempt to unravel this package or to introduce amendments which reduce revenue raising aspects will mean that the government is forced to reconsider its announcement of additional places allocated to Queensland, New South Wales, Western Australia and Tasmania. Alternatively, the government will have to consider the reallocation of existing places from other states.

Through this package, the government has responded positively and quickly to the resource needs of the higher education sector with both new policy and effective savings without cutting the overall funds available to higher education. This bill underscores this government's commitment to the provision of opportunities for all Australians to have access to higher education; access which is dependent on academic merit and ability, not on the capacity to pay. I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill and commend the bill to the house.
Debate (on motion by Mrs Gallus) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Delegation to Europe on French Nuclear Testing

TALKER.NAME: Mr BILNEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I welcome this opportunity to report to honourable members on the multi-party parliamentary delegation which I led to Europe in the first half of September. Members will recall that that delegation comprised the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price), the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson), the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), Senator Bourne and me.

PARA.TAB: The delegation visited eight countries in quick succession: Germany, Belgium, the United Kingdom, France, the Netherlands, Sweden, Denmark and Austria. As you know, I had to leave the delegation after the first week in order to attend the South Pacific Forum in Papua New Guinea and the member for Chifley, Mr Price, who is the Chairman of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, led the delegation in my absence.

This visit took place as a result of the upswelling of outrage among Australians at France's decision to resume nuclear testing in the Pacific. All Australians are appalled at the decision of President Chirac to ignore world opinion and to break the moratorium on testing which was introduced by his predecessor, President Mitterrand. This decision shows complete disregard for the feelings of those living in this region who are deeply concerned about the environmental impacts of the testing over the long term.

Australians do not accept that these tests are either defensible or necessary and in all sorts of ways the Australian people have given expression to their anger on this issue. We have sent delegations to France, we have made protests, we have taken action in a number of international forums and we have given the French government no comfort whatsoever on this issue.

What did this delegation set out to do? Our main goal was to convey to the parliaments, governments and peoples of Europe our determined opposition to nuclear testing. We wanted to encourage a more forthright stance on the part of France's European neighbours, as we know that the only way we will end nuclear testing is by building a unanimous international chorus of opposition to it—and the countries of Europe are particularly important in this regard.

We wanted also to lobby for a resolution in the United Nations condemning all nuclear testings—a matter which the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Evans, is now pursuing in New York. As well as that, we wanted to urge support for a truly comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty which would ban all testing in all environments for all time. And, finally, we wanted to explain carefully the reasons for our position, to make clear that our disagreement with France was confined to one issue and one issue only, namely, the issue of nuclear testing.

I was quite surprised at some of the misinformation which had crept into the public mind in Europe on this issue. For example, I was asked by one television interviewer in France why it was that the Australian government was funding Greenpeace's activities! It is a curious but unfortunate fact that from the distant vantage point of Europe it is easy to depict the Australian government as responsible for a variety of protest actions, some of which are illegal. In fact, we were in Paris at the time of the riots in Papeete and I am sure that in the eyes of some there was the idea that the Australian government was somehow involved in those protests. Of course the government was not and it does not condone illegal protest activity.

I am pleased to report that the delegation achieved its principal objectives to a very substantial degree. We had some 37 meetings with government ministers, parliamentary committees, other parliamentarians and relevant figures and bodies such as the European Union and the International Atomic Energy Agency. We held press conferences and we gave media interviews in each country to pursue our goal of raising public awareness of Australia's position. As well as that, the delegation took part in a video conference from Stockholm with the foreign relations committee of the Finnish parliament. The delegation also attended part of the opening of oral pleadings in New Zealand's action in the International Court of Justice against French testing.

The countries which we visited were very deliberately selected and in all but three countries our interlocutors were very receptive to our representations. In those countries our discussions focused on the ways in which we could work together to advance our shared objectives. In two other countries—Germany and the United Kingdom—public opinion is running strongly against renewed testing, but for various reasons the response of governments has been disappointingly quiet.

In those places we were given a polite and attentive hearing but it was clear that there was a reluctance to take our views on board, or for that matter the views of their own constituencies, on this nuclear testing issue. Nevertheless, it was pleasing that, after our visits there, when the first test actually took place, both the German Foreign Minister and the leader of the British opposition issued statements which advanced, very considerably, their public positions on the issue. For that reason, and as a result of the continuing pressure that we are keeping up, I believe the chance of further movement by these countries is considerable.

The visit to France fell into a category of its own. But even there we were very pleased by the access we were given to senior ministers, including the Minister for Defence, Monsieur Millon, the Minister for Overseas Territories, Monsieur De Peretti, and the Minister for Aid, Monsieur Godfrain. A meeting with the French foreign minister was scheduled but had to be cancelled at the last minute because of an urgent international meeting on Bosnia which Monsieur de Charette had to attend.

Our discussions were forthright and robust but were held in a calm atmosphere. The French ministers explained the reasons for their government's decision. For our part, we very clearly put Australia's position on the issue to the French. We went through one by one the reasons advanced by the French side, pointing out that their arguments in favour of testing were based on false premises. For example, arguments about reliability of the nuclear weapons might make sense to a mathematician or a defence scientist but, in the real world, no potential aggressor against France would stake its chances on the possibility that French nuclear missiles would not work. Given that 200-odd French tests so far have been successful, the chance that a first weapon used in anger would not go off is not one that an aggressor would be likely to take. And if the first one did not go off, what about the second or the third?

We also attempted to explore further the possibility that France might obtain the data to construct the computer simulation programs it is looking for from other nuclear powers, such as the United States. That is a matter I have raised on a number of occasions before, including before President Chirac's election. I regret to say that the French authorities do not seem interested in the idea—for one reason or another, it has not appealed to France.

We took particular pains to explain to the French ministers that Australia was not attempting to deprive France of its nuclear capability. We reiterated that Australia's opposition to testing being carried out by China equalled our opposition to that being carried out by France. We took issue time and again with the view that Australia was opposed to France's place in the Pacific or that the government was encouraging economic boycotts of French goods. We pointed out that neither position is the case.

I have to say that these discussions did not in full measure yield the results that we might have wished. On the need for France to continue testing, we did not persuade our interlocutors to accept our point of view. But I am sure that they do now understand our position much better, even if they do not agree with it.

I am certain, too, that an important part of the overall success of the delegation was the broad participation in it of all major parties represented in this parliament. I would like to pay tribute to the contribution of delegation members from the government, the opposition and the Australian Democrats. The fact that all the major political parties in the parliament were represented helped us to reinforce the impact we made by underlining the fact that opposition to nuclear testing is shared across the political spectrum in this country. It was particularly useful, when meeting ministers and MPs from the conservative side of politics, for example in the UK, that they should hear our messages conveyed by people such as Mr Downer or Mr Sinclair who, I note, are present in the chamber. It was useful that they should hear our messages conveyed by people who, on other issues, would normally be expected to be on the same side of the argument as they are.

Where do we go from here? The campaign is by no means over. Another delegation from this parliament, led by the President of the Senate, is currently in Europe on a visit to the European parliament, to Spain and the OECD. This delegation will be raising the same issues we did as part of its agenda. As well as that, we are continuing to make our voice heard in international forums. Australia is actively involved in negotiations on a draft resolution for debate in the United Nations General Assembly. We very much hope that the resolution will gain the widest possible support as it will be an important way of giving expression to the international community's condemnation of nuclear testing. It is a large part of Senator Evans's agenda for his current visit to the United Nations in New York.

Nevertheless, it now seems inevitable, though I say it with reluctance, that more tests will occur, but certainly not as many as we first thought and feared. Nor is it clear to the government that any further bilateral action that Australia could take would make President Chirac change his mind.

I do believe, however, that the storm of opposition which has been aroused over this issue—and of which our delegation was part—has had a measurable impact in France. One has only to look at France's welcome acceptance of a zero yield comprehensive test ban treaty—a concept which has been resolutely promoted by Australia—as well as the statement made by President Chirac recently, which clearly leaves open the possibility that the number of tests by France will be reduced. There are also indications that the duration of the testing period will be shortened. So, overall, I am optimistic that our sustained campaign of public opposition will reinforce this trend, and that we will soon see a definitive end to nuclear testing in this part of the world and, indeed, throughout the world.

On behalf of the delegation, I conclude by expressing my thanks to the officers of the Parliamentary Relations Office and the officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade—in Canberra and overseas—who, in their unfailingly helpful and efficient way, put together the arrangements for our visit and made an important contribution to its success. I present the following paper:

TAB.EMPHASIS: Parliamentary Delegation to Europe on French Nuclear Testing, 2-17 September 1995

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Mr Bevis) proposed:
That the House take note of the paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) announced the idea of a delegation to visit European countries and lobby on French nuclear testing—I think it was on what is sometimes known as Hiroshima Day—I was glad to hear the Prime Minister's statement, and was certainly one of the first to publicly welcome it.

PARA.TAB: I have taken the view for quite some time that, if anybody is to persuade the French to desist from nuclear testing, it is the European Union. France, when it made the decision to proceed with nuclear testing, had obviously made the calculation that Australia, New Zealand and the South Pacific countries would object, and that France could live with that. What the French did not estimate was the strength of protest that would emerge from within Europe itself.

At the heart of French foreign policy are France's relationships within the European Union and the whole structure of European unity itself. I thought the idea of our going to various European countries, putting our case to them and trying to persuade them to take a strong stand against France resuming nuclear testing was a constructive one. In fact, I said so in a press release that I put out on 23 July, which was some time before the Prime Minister made his statement that such a delegation should go. Bearing all that in mind, the delegation was not only a good idea—given the limited prospects we had of persuading the French to reverse their decision—but also fairly effective.

As the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs (Mr Bilney) pointed out in his statement, there were really three messages that we wanted to get across. The first concerned our opposition to French nuclear testing itself and the fact that all Australians are opposed to France's decision to resume nuclear testing. It is not an issue that has divided the political parties in Australia—parties which are so divided on so many issues—and it was important that people in Europe properly understood that.

We put our arguments to the Europeans, very much emphasising the non-proliferation arguments. We emphasised the fact that France had signed up to the non-proliferation treaty review conference, on the grounds that it would exercise utmost restraint, and then as soon as the ink was dry on the paper went off—as did the Chinese, for that matter—and resumed nuclear testing.

Given the enormous difficulties that were involved in persuading many developing countries and many non-aligned countries to sign up to the MPT review and extension conference, and given the difficulties involved and the amount of diplomatic capital that was invested in getting those countries to sign up, it was a matter of some outrage that the French should treat that process with the contempt that they clearly did.

We argued quite effectively. In Europe there was widespread agreement with the proposition that, at a time when we should be arguing for non-proliferation of weapons of mass destruction, the French and the Chinese, by resuming nuclear testing, were doing nothing but give comfort to the nuclear threshold states. We certainly put the environmental arguments, but the evidence of the environmental damage caused by French nuclear testing is equivocal. There is a shortage of data available from the French themselves. The environmental argument will need to be developed when more data is made available.

As I have said, these arguments were very well received in just about every country we visited, with the obvious exception of France. In the case of the United Kingdom, I believe that privately the British government sympathises with the arguments that we have put, but they are not prepared to say so publicly. The British are themselves a nuclear weapons state, and they do not feel that it would do much to advance their important relationship with France if they were to criticise the French on this matter.

I happen to think that strategy by the British government is the wrong strategy, and it is probably one of the very few things on which I would agree with the British Labor Party. I was glad that the leader of the British opposition was prepared to put out a press release condemning the resumption of nuclear testing by France. What the opposition says, the government here would say may not matter very much—that is what they tell us.
Mr Price interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, they think the British opposition is different because it is Labor. The Australian Labor Party are really profound; there is real depth to them! The second argument that we put was that we wanted a successful conclusion to the comprehensive test ban treaty with a zero threshold. Again, that argument was very well received everywhere we went, including France. The French have said that they will sign up on those terms to the CTBT, once their testing program is complete. There is no question of the support in Europe for the comprehensive test ban treaty and the zero threshold.

PARA.TAB: The United Kingdom was the one country where I wondered whether we would get unequivocal support. When Sir Patrick Mayhew, the British Secretary of State for Northern Ireland—who, I think, is the fifth in the British cabinet hierarchy—visited Canberra last week, I raised these issues with him, including my disappointment at the stance that the British government has taken on French nuclear testing. I am glad to say that he told me that not only would Britain sign up to the CTBT, but it would definitely do so on the basis of a zero threshold. That was the first confirmation I had heard from a minister, although I believe that the British ambassador to the committee on disarmament had made those points. It was good to see that response from the minister, and in terms of that objective we were very successful.

The third objective was to ensure that the momentum of protest against what the French were doing was maintained. We argued that the way to maintain this was to get support for a resolution in the United Nations General Assembly and in the International Atomic Energy Agency—the most important forum being the United Nations General Assembly.

All the indications that we had were of at least in-principle support for some type of resolution. Amongst members of the European Union, there was some concern that they could be put in the position of voting against France in a forum such as the United Nations, and at a time when Europe is trying to develop a common foreign policy. But, as we pointed out to the Europeans, `The French didn't consult any of you when they made the decision to resume nuclear testing. You, yourselves, are not obliged to support the French on this issue. You are obliged to support your consciences and the principle of non-proliferation.'

I must say that that message was well received and I would be very surprised if we did not win just about overwhelming support from European countries in the United Nations General Assembly. No doubt the British will not, no doubt the Germans will be nervous, but I think the majority of countries in Europe will support the resolution which is to be brought to the General Assembly. In terms of our three objectives, I think we did about as well as we could have hoped.

I would like to say something about the meetings that we had with the French because they were of particular interest. As the minister pointed out, we met with Monsieur Millon, the French Defence Minister, and his officials. We also met with two other ministers: the Minister for Development Cooperation and the Minister for Overseas Territories. It is important to understand that we were very firm at those meetings. We put Australia's case very definitely and, if I could say so, very bluntly. But it is also very important to understand that, in responding, the French were always polite and civil and were prepared to go out of their way to meet with us and spend time with us.

We made several points to the French over and above the simple points about our opposition to nuclear testing. One point we made was that we are not Francophobic: we are not anti-French and Australia is not an anti-French country. After all, as we pointed out—I think it might have been to the foreign affairs committee in the Belgian parliament—something like 30,000 Australians died in the First World War in helping to defend France. To accuse Australians of being somehow Francophobic is an absolute absurdity. We were able to make that point well and truly while we were in France.

We made it clear that we did not want to see the relationship descend to the level of a trade war. We made it clear that we were not arguing about the issue of the French presence in the South Pacific and that we were not arguing that France should withdraw from the South Pacific. The people of French Polynesia and the people of New Caledonia are entitled to self-determination, whether they are French colonies or not. If they want the present arrangements to remain in place, that is their decision and their right. It is not for us to be arrogantly telling those people that they would be much better off severing their ties with France. It is entirely a matter for them.

I believe that, although the French understood the sincerity of those types of remarks made by the minister, made by me and made by other members of the delegation, our position had already been somewhat undermined by the Prime Minister's statement on 9 August when he said, in response to some remarks by President Chirac which, admittedly, were rather inflammatory, `We gave up our colonialism in the 1970s. The French are still hanging on to their colonialism in the Pacific. Maybe the French should have a good look at themselves.'

That was a very silly and ill-considered thing to say, because it was a statement that played into the hands of President Chirac and one that, in a sense, has embarrassed Australia. But the point is that, despite the Prime Minister's gaffe, the official position of the Australian government and of the Australian opposition is at variance with that view—and the Prime Minister, of course, has retreated from that position.

Let me finish my remarks about France by saying that our meetings with French ministers—I have said this already—were friendly and constructive, although there were obviously points of disagreement. Those meetings were held on a Thursday and a Friday. On the Sunday we were amazed to hear the vicious attack launched by President Chirac against Australia and Australian motives. President Chirac claimed that Australia provided no aid to the South Pacific at all. At the breakfast meeting with the Minister for Development Cooperation the minister talked about the need for Australia and France to cooperate more in their development assistance programs. How the President could have come out and made that claim, after such a meeting that we had with the Minister for Development Cooperation, I do not know. There is clearly a breakdown in communications in the French government between President Chirac and the rest of his ministry, or between President Chirac's office and the rest of his ministry, and that is something that I would have thought that the French government could closely examine.

The minister made the point in his speech and in France that one of the things the French should be doing should be looking at sharing data with the United States rather than testing to obtain more data. That was a constructive proposal. I remind the minister that, when we suggested that in an amendment to a motion in the House of Representatives earlier in the year, he said it was a pettifogging suggestion and voted against it, which was a pity; I did not think there was any need to vote against a constructive suggestion. Nevertheless, I was glad to hear the minister take up something that I thought was constructive, which he used to think was pettifogging but which he now thinks is constructive. It is a wonderful thing to see the Labor Party evolve, to follow the lead of the coalition.

Let me conclude on a serious matter. We had a meeting in Vienna, after the minister had returned, with the International Atomic Energy Agency and a subsequent meeting, after we had returned, with the Australian Safeguards Office, at which initially some alarm was expressed by the delegation that the IAEA and the ASO were not able to guarantee that Australian uranium could never be used in French nuclear testing.

I am satisfied that that issue has been resolved, by information provided to me by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) that the French no longer produce fissile material; they no longer produce material that can be used in nuclear testing. So there is no question that Australian material can now be used for French nuclear testing. I thank Senator Evans and the minister at the table for ensuring that we were able to obtain that information, which has been constructive.

It was a successful delegation. I thank the staff at the various embassies—the ambassadors and the officials who helped us. It was a really productive exercise, and it shows that bipartisanship, when it is heading in the right direction, can work quite successfully.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BILNEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a personal explanation.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Snow)—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?

TALK.START.PARA: —I do.
—Please proceed.

—The suggestion about pettifogging is not one which the Hansard will show as accurate. I said that the opposition at that time had adopted a pettifogging approach to the whole motion which we had moved at that time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price The Hon L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would first like to thank the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) for proposing this delegation. I will pick up on the last part of the contribution of the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) by saying that it is always worth while, when we have the opportunity, to show that members on both sides of the House work very constructively in the nation's interests. We do this not just in this delegation but in other work of the parliament.

PARA.TAB: I would like to pay tribute to our delegation leader, the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs (Mr Bilney). It was very useful that he is such a fluent French speaker. I did not understand all that he was saying in French, but most of it seemed to be getting a very good reception.

I would like to acknowledge the contributions of the honourable member for Mayo, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) and Senator Vicki Bourne. It is also worth mentioning that we were accompanied by Graham Fletcher and Peter Charles from the minister's office, and I would like to thank them for their contribution. In the latter part of the delegation, I would particularly like to thank Dr Janet Gardiner from our Bonn embassy, who nurtured us through with good humour and good advice.

Last but not least, most members understand that this delegation was put together at great haste and it required some considerable effort by our overseas posts. I would like to report back, as the minister has, that none failed and indeed all did an exceedingly good job.

This delegation was one of those things where it was good to be honoured—a privilege, actually—and I would like to thank the House for that opportunity. But it was a privilege to represent something that was deeply felt by ordinary Australians and gave the sense that you were actually going to accomplish something.

As the minister said, our mission, as much as we might have liked it, was not to stop French testing. Unfortunately, that was not possible—indeed, the first bomb went off while we were over there—but it was to inform European parliaments and ministers of the Australian and South Pacific attitude.

It was based on the strategy that whilst ordinary Australians had reacted to this French decision in a most remarkable way, and that was mirrored in New Zealand and in many of the small and smallest countries in the South Pacific, as strong as that protest was, it really was not going to make one iota of difference as far as the French were concerned—the real leverage on the French government was France's European partners.

I want to make the point at this early stage in my contribution that we have nothing against the French people. We are not against France, as the minister said. We object only to one decision and that is the French government's decision to resume testing. Indeed, many Australians should remember that a majority of the French people themselves are opposed to this testing, as are overwhelming numbers of people in the European nations that we visited.

The minister pointed out some of the gross misconceptions. He pointed out that he was questioned whether Australia was funding Greenpeace. There was the suggestion that, really, Australia's opposition was a clever marketing campaign to promote Australian wines—an absurd suggestion. There was the suggestion that we had banned all French goods in Australia—equally absurd. Then there was the suggestion, as the minister said, that we were really trying to get France out of the South Pacific.

If the minister made one point repeatedly, it was that Australia, since 1988, had welcomed the constructive role of France in the South Pacific, had worked closely with France and looked forward to doing so. However, I am drawn to comment on this issue of the French colonies. As a Labor member, I have to say that the issue of self-determination for the French colonies is one for them and for France. But if any country has reopened that issue, it is not Australia, it is not New Zealand and it is not the South Pacific countries. It is the action of the French President in deciding to recommence tests.

Whilst I do not envisage Australia raising this issue in the United Nations, it certainly will attract the attention of a number of countries and I would be surprised if this issue is not raised in the UN committee for decolonisation. If so, France would only have one person to blame and that would be itself.

Whilst in France, again as the minister said, we put vigorously the idea that rather than continuing on this path of testing which is so infuriating world opinion and isolating France, why not look at using computer simulation? Why not look at adapting the technology used by both the US and the UK?

The French minister gave two responses: one was the compatibility of the weapons; and the second was a national consideration. The second really was that France wants everything about its nuclear deterrent totally French—not one iota non-French. This is an ideological position very difficult to overcome. On the compatibility argument, there are real grounds to move there, although I accept that there are some problems. But I also have to confess to the House that I am not convinced that the French reasons for testing are entirely valid, that is, the obsolescence of some of the weaponry and wanting to maintain its reliability.

In fact, some of the tests can be categorised as testing new weapons, and not force de suasion or not a deterrent but, as these are for submarines, actually projecting power. Of the attempts by the French to try to cause a distraction from overwhelming opposition was this notion of Europeanising the deterrent. I am pleased to say in the other countries we visited that this concept was rejected out of hand. In fact, for some of the newer members of the EU, it has really placed in question this whole idea of having a European defence. In some ways I think that is a backward movement, but it is seen for what it is, a smokescreen or a device to deflect attention.

I must say I was disappointed at the German reaction—that is, the French having insisted that we see no minister in that country—although we did see the head of their equivalent to our foreign affairs department. I am disappointed that Germany, a country in such close cooperation and partnership with France, for historical reasons felt constrained from perhaps publicly making a more vigorous opposition to the resumption of testing as they have made privately. I think Germany's leadership position in Europe really demands more than it has shown.

Of the countries we visited, the UK disappointed me most. We saw a very junior minister, but we got no comfort whatsoever. On reflection, we got a better justification for the French testing in the UK than I think the French themselves gave. I do not want to detract from the bipartisan nature and record of achievement of the delegation, but permit me to wryly observe that I believe the Queen of Australia seems to be having a difference of opinion with the Queen of England on this issue.

Hopefully, the isolation that France enjoys and that the UK government has in Europe on this issue may change with the forthcoming Commonwealth heads of government conference. I hope that the UK will listen to the very vigorous views that I suspect will be put by all countries to it.

I only realised later that I had one regret about our visit to Brussels. When we were in Denmark we were pleased to be able to speak with the ministry for the environment, the minister apologising for not being able to be there. They had quite some confidence in the EU commissioner for the environment who, as you may be aware, is already acting within the EU context to ask France to provide justification for testing. I am only sorry that whilst in Brussels we did not meet with the commissioner herself.

I am quietly confident that we all may have underestimated the power of the EU commissioner. Either way, if the commissioner decides in favour of France, then it remains a possibility that a European country can take the matter to the European court and get justice there or, hopefully, the EU commissioner herself may be able to bring down a decision that will stop this testing.

One of the lessons I learned, as they say, is that the world is a village. Ordinary people in Australia are reflecting their anger and concern about the testing in France, but ordinary people in Europe are also reflecting their anger. It was a real delight in Denmark to meet and speak with some young students who had cycled all the way from Denmark to France as a tangible measure of their protest. We were not able to visit all the countries we would otherwise have liked to, and no slights were intended, but to meet some young students from Norway—who were going to spend the whole night and morning getting back to Norway to go to work the following day—was indeed a pleasure.

In Sweden we were able to speak via videoconferencing in the parliament to our Finnish counterparts. As much as we like to think that we are sometimes at the wrong end of the world, we already have the ability to video conference through the audio and video facilities in the House. All we need to do is spend the extra money to get the equipment which would allow us to speak to our Austrian counterparts or to our UK counterparts, et cetera. If there is one matter arising out of the report which I would like brought to the attention of the presiding officers, it would be that we could purchase such equip

SPEECH.PARA: ment. I would be grateful if you would pass that on, Mr Deputy Speaker Snow. I do not want to overstate what members of parliament can achieve. Clearly the heads of state, the heads of government and ministers are your main strike weapons. But it is also nice to have members of parliament and the relevant parliamentary committees in dialogue. I think this delegation has shown that we can accomplish quite some good in a very bipartisan way on an issue that is of prime concern to ordinary Australians. I want to say thanks to all members and senators for the pleasure of being on this delegation. I again congratulate my fellow delegation members and, in particular, the minister who led the delegation.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are not many occasions in the passage of political events in this country of ours where there is a bipartisan approach. More often, fortunately, they occur in the consideration of external affairs rather than domestic affairs. But in this particular instance both external affairs and domestic affairs were linked with the delegation led by the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs (Mr Bilney), whom I commend both for the statement that he has made to the House and for his leadership of the mission. His facility with French certainly gave him a capacity to respond on French media to the real audience that we sought to target—the French people.

PARA.TAB: It is important that we understand the particular climate within which the decision has been taken by France. It is important to understand the extent to which, with a new president and a new government, there was a feeling by some—certainly by the president and his prime minister—that this decision to resume testing in some way established a counterbalance within Europe which might have been seen to offset the expanded economic strength of an enlarged Germany, the testing being designed to re-establish the supremacy of France within an expanded European Community. In any event, it left a feeling that an agenda was being played out by France that ignored totally the feelings of the French community and certainly the feelings of the rest of the world.

Early in our visit the minister drew reference to a cartoon that we all might recall which best highlights the circumstances of the distance between metropolitan France and Mururoa Atoll, which is the part of the south-east Pacific where the tests took place. He referred to a cartoon showing a globe of the world and a French general saying to President Chirac, `See, Mon Generale, it will not hurt. You push the button here and it goes bang down here.' He was talking about the other side of the world. It is because France is on the other side of the world and because, without doubt, the decision to resume nuclear testing was related to attitudes and perceptions in France of her role within Europe and of President Chirac's conception of his role within French history that I think the decision to send an all parliamentary delegation was certainly worth while.

Whilst I will come back to the point we reached at the end of our deliberations, in opening I would like to say that the mission was worth while. I commend the minister and the member for Chifley (Mr Price), who took over after the minister left, for being able to accomplish as much as we did. It was a mission on which we knew from the very beginning we would be frustrated by our inability to stop the French testing at all.

As far as the actual countries we visited and the discussions we held are concerned, much of what has been done has already been catalogued by my colleagues, and I do not intend to repeat their remarks. There are some particular occasions, though, that I think are worthwhile re-emphasising. The first is that, while it is true that in Germany we did not meet a minister, we did meet a senior official within the department of foreign affairs. We did without doubt get the feeling that the public approach to France by Germany—by the German government and the chancellor—was quite different from their private approach. Indeed, we were very pleased to see the German foreign minister coming out, after the first French test, with quite a strong public condemnation of the resumption of testing. We were assured that privately at least, within the forums of the community and the bilateral contact that exists, the Germans had been more forthright than they were prepared to be publicly—even with us.

Within Germany, as within every other country of Europe, there seemed to be two layers of resistance. The first and the most notable was within the community at large. The community right throughout Europe—in part because of the publicity attracted by our visit and the actions of Greenpeace and others—certainly had concentrated their minds on the consequences of the resumption of French testing. An aspect that each of us stressed was that it was not a matter of Australia condemning France on any issue other than on that one particular focus: resumption of underground testing.

I believe that by doing that, not only were we able to maintain the momentum of bipartisan representation but we were also able to assist in the momentum of concern in that wider European community. We all recognised that the particular relationship between France and Germany has been quite instrumental in the development and formation of the European Community. It was because of that focal relationship between Germany and France in the community that we saw it was important that we visited more than one country and helped to ensure that the community's views were reflected in the consciousness of the status of the French decision and reflected back on those who took the decision.

The second part of the visit that also impressed me, which certainly from afar I had not registered, was the changing character of the European Community as a result of its expansion. Three of the countries we visited—or two we visited and one whose foreign affairs committee we spoke to by virtue of a teleconference—have recently joined the European Community. While little has been said, I do not think enough attention has been given to the impact on the decisions and the function of the European Community as a result of its expansion.

While Austria, Sweden and Finland recently joined the community as relatively smaller countries, in contrast to Germany in particular and the economy of France, there is no doubt that the momentum towards not only a common currency but progressively towards a common foreign policy and a common defence policy I think is now more unlikely to proceedthan perhaps previously might have been thought. One of the significant reasons why it is not going to proceed is not that those new countries have joined the European Community but that France has recommenced nuclear testing in the South Pacific.

I am sure the French did not look towards that consequence during their discussions. Indeed, one of the other aspects of that consequence is, as several members have mentioned, that while France was calling on her European colleagues not to dissent from her status on an issue that she said was within her sovereign responsibility and was not something that was domestically within the concern of other countries, when it was mentioned that the French did not consult with the other members of the European Community prior to recommencing the nuclear test program, they reacted in a way which showed how frustrated they are and that, if there is to be a common European foreign policy, it need not automatically be that of France. That is a concept which the French find a little hard to accept but it is a concept which now is filtering through simply because the French have ignored that very consultative mechanism which they were largely instrumental in writing into the whole of the concept in the first place.

There is a fallout in a way that the French did not expect. It is in part a product of our visit and the fact that publicity was attracted to the locality of the testing and the fact that there had been no consultation. Perhaps that is why this resistance developed.

There has been mention of our interview with David Davis, a junior minister within the British government. Like others of my colleagues, I was very disappointed in the approach taken by the government of the United Kingdom. It was only in the United Kingdom, in Germany and amongst one group of French liberals in the Belgian committee of foreign affairs that we found any resistance at all to the idea that there should be a united approach to condemn France for the resumption of nuclear testing. As the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) said, David Davis gave a greater justification for the resumption of French testing than even the French themselves. I found that most disappointing.

We all understand that France has been overrun successfully over the last 100 years. It is not that we do not understand France's strong commitment to either force de frappe or force de suasion, whichever term you like to use. Indeed, as the minister and others have said, we not only understand it; we endorse it. We recognise that the French feel vulnerable. They do not want again to be overrun by another country. That is not only a natural feeling for France; it is a natural feeling for any country. So the circumstances around their force de frappe and force de suasion were not matters that we canvassed.

What we canvassed was that there was no need for them to extend their nuclear capability by having a test in the first place. Having exploded the nuclear weapon, there was absolutely no reason for them to proceed in what they said were tests to establish the calibration procedures, which it has been suggested they could very easily attract from the United States. There has been some discussion about that today. Let it be said on record that I, amongst others, have raised this with the Americans. I have been assured that they have made offers to the French, even though the French and the advisers to Charles Millon, the French Minister for Defence, assured us that they had not been offered the necessary advice to allow them to develop their own computer testing processes. They said that, even if they had, `Our weapon is different.'

I fail to understand how any formula cannot be developed. Certainly when they have already had nearly 200 tests of their own you would think they would have the fundamental information. To my mind, the fact that the Americans were prepared to give them the additional information totally destroys the validity of their calibration requirements in future testing. As for obsolescence, as the minister said in his statement today, if the first weapon does not go off, the probability of the second going off is certainly far greater. They have shown that their first did go off. I certainly am most apprehensive about reports I have read that the whole thing is really about miniaturisation, about developing a new trigger mechanism, and certainly not just about obsolescence and calibration.

So there should be no doubt that whatever the explanation of the British, of David Davis, or of Charles Millon, the French Minister for Defence, and his advisers, from our point of view we do not accept that there is any longer any necessity for the continuation of the test program. It is important that the French, partly as a result of this discussion today and certainly hopefully as a result of the discussions that we had in Europe, should register the strength of our views and our feelings.

I summarise by saying: where did we get to as a result of our visit? I know others have said it, but I think it is important to reiterate that Chirac's popularity has not declined peculiarly because we visited but because of the consequence of a recognition that nuclear testing is against the mood in the European Community. Our visit was no more than a factor in marshalling and mounting dissuasion within the countries of Europe against the continuation of testing.

In that respect, it is particularly unfortunate that President Chirac has seen fit to refuse a visit to the Swedish Prime Minister and the Austrian Chancellor. I regard that as yet a further downward step in France's leadership of Europe. I find it quite incredible that, at an age when France is saying that we have an expanded Europe and we are going to be able to play a continued important role in the future, they should take decisions of that character.

As far as the arguments of Chirac himself are concerned, there is little doubt that he has little communication with his own ministers. As has been said, the discussions with each of his ministers—the Minister for Defence, the Minister for Development Cooperation and the Minister for Overseas Territories—were exactly the reverse of the statements he made on air on television on the Sunday following our visit. One wonders what sort of an agenda he was pursuing for that reason. There is only one focus of our objection: the resumption of nuclear testing and its continuation.

The third real concern that we all had is where we go from here. CHOGM provides another forum for opposition. The resolution of the South Pacific Forum shows the strength of opinion of the South Pacific countries and New Zealand. One of our purposes was to try to ensure support for a United Nations resolution, which will be hopefully brought up immediately after the commemoration and celebration of the 50th anniversary of the establishment of the United Nations. We hope that many countries will join with Australia towards a resolution which will really place a moratorium on further test bans until the comprehensive test ban treaty can be concluded. We hope that resolution will be universally supported.

Above all, it is essential that the French understand that we hope that they will not only become a party to that comprehensive test ban treaty with a zero threshold—as they have said they will do, and as we hope will Britain and the United States—but also sign the protocols of the Treaty of Rarotonga. We trust that they will desist from further testing and recognise that the product of the decision by the French President has been very much to the detriment of France and not to its benefit.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am left with a number of very strong impressions after spending two weeks in Europe on this Australian delegation. The first and most important and overwhelming is that France is totally isolated on this question. France stands alone in its actions in resuming nuclear tests. It has done enormous damage to its credibility and its standing both in Europe and throughout the international community.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, the other very strong impression I gained is that the French President and some of his chief advisers and strongest supporters are locked into a time warp. They still think we are in the 1970s. They do not understand that the world has moved on and that in the 1990s, in the post-Cold War era, the people of the world do not want nuclear weapons being expanded, developed and tested. They want the world's leaders to be removing, reducing and eliminating nuclear weapons. They do not want more nuclear tests.

The third very strong impression I gained from our visit is that, thanks to Jacques Chirac, Australia's reputation in Europe is at an all-time high. The people of Europe recognise that Australia has shown very strong international leadership on this question. They respect us greatly for the effort that we have put in in taking this question straight to the French. They respect the principled basis of our arguments. They understand that we are working on behalf of a lot of people. They respect the role that we have played in assisting those small nations in our region in the South Pacific who, as very small nations, do not have much of a voice themselves. We as a major nation in the South Pacific region have worked on their behalf as well. We have incredibly increased our reputation and support amongst the people of Europe because of the principled stand that we have taken on this issue.

It was a great honour to be involved in this delegation. I thank the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) for enabling it to occur and for the parliament for allowing me to be part of the delegation. As the only Queenslander on the delegation, I was pleased to be able to be a voice for the people of Queensland in Europe on this issue, because the people of Queensland have felt very strongly about it.

Nuclear testing has been an issue that has affected us for a long time. The people of Queensland were very angry during the 1970s when the French atmospheric testing was carried out because a lot of the fallout was occurring in North Queensland. So there is very strong opposition in Queensland to French nuclear testing. Although these tests are now underground and do not have the same immediate impact on the environment that the atmospheric tests did, there is still a very strong feeling amongst the people of Queensland of great opposition to nuclear testing in the South Pacific. Again, it was a great opportunity for me to be a voice for the people of Queensland in France and in Europe on this question. So I thank the Prime Minister and the parliament for that opportunity.

I have been on a couple of other parliamentary delegations. This one was quite unique in that we worked totally as a united team. The team consisted of members of the opposition, a Democrat senator and members of the government, but we were one voice. That had an enormous impact throughout Europe. It certainly had an impact on politicians who understand how Australia has a pretty vibrant and vigorous parliamentary system and how it is often very difficult to get two sides to join on an issue. We were there speaking as one voice, and we made a very effective team in doing that. That unity helped us to successfully get our message across.

Of course, we were not able to end nuclear testing by the French. As much as we all would have liked that to have happened, we knew it was not going to be possible just from our visit, but I do believe we achieved a lot of our other aims. Our first and most important aim was to bring clarity back to the debate, to try to counter some of the arguments that the French media and French government spokespersons had been trying to peddle throughout Europe about other motivations behind Australia's campaign.

It was very helpful that we were in Europe at the time President Chirac made two speeches about the French nuclear testing issue. Being in Europe, we were then able to talk to the media, the politicians and the people to counter some of the points that President Chirac made. We were very successful in that we very clearly identified our two strong objections—disarmament and the environment. None of the other baggage that President Chirac was trying to attach to us had any relevance or any basis in fact at all. The Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs (Mr Bilney) and other speakers here today have outlined how we managed to counter those things.

We will gain a side benefit from the Chirac actions, but that was not our motivation. The fact is that Australian wine sales probably will improve in Europe. It is pretty good wine. That was not our motive. It is clear that the people of Europe, like the people of Australia, are angry about the French. They are using one of the few vehicles they have to express their view—that is, a consumer boycott of French goods—as a means of expressing their anger at the French government's decision.

When we were in Germany, we were told that French wine sales there had been cut by about 30 per cent. When we were in Sweden, we were told that sales of French cheese and French wines had been cut by over 50 per cent. While we were in Holland, a lot of shop windows and house windows around the streets of Amsterdam had posters saying `Boycott French wine'. I took a photo of one of those posters. It is not something that we have engineered; it is something that the people of Europe are doing themselves.

We are not leading any official government boycott of goods because we do not believe that it is an appropriate way for a government to act, particularly the Australian government which has fought so long for so many years to get a free trade system in this world. We do not want to endanger those free trade systems by imposing individual political boycotts on particular products from time to time.

We cannot stop the people of Australia or Europe from using one of the few opportunities they have to express a point of view—that is, to vote with their wallets and say, `I'm not going to spend my hard earned money on French products while the French keep doing these things in the world.' Another strong impression I gained while I was away was the overwhelming support from the Scandinavian people and governments for our position.

We visited two Scandinavian countries and met with Scandinavian people and politicians. We received a strong level of support from those people. As the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) has indicated, the Scandinavians are new members of the European Union; yet they are some of the loudest and strongest in their condemnation of France. I think that is a brave stand to take because France is a powerful economy within the European Union. As new members of the European Union they probably run some risk in asserting their opinions that strongly. They were prepared to do so on a matter of principle, and that is what is very important.

There were a couple of highlights for me on the trip. I would like to mention one. I had the opportunity while we were meeting with the French Minister for Defence, Mr Charles Millon, to present a petition on behalf of all members of the parliamentary Labor Party. That petition was signed by the 106 members of the parliamentary Labor Party. I presented it to the Minister for Defence for presentation to the President and government of France.

TALK.START.PARA: —And you've got a photo to prove it.

—As the minister says, I have a photo to prove that I actually did do it. That was a good opportunity for politicians from Australia to very clearly, directly and in writing state their principled views on why they are opposed to French nuclear testing.

PARA.TAB: Another great opportunity we had, although it has not come to pass as part of our ongoing campaign, was a visit to the International Court of Justice in The Hague on the first day of the reopening of the New Zealand case. We were there to show our support for the New Zealand government in the reopening of their case. It was a great opportunity to visit the court and see the way in which it operates because it is the supreme international court. That was a great opportunity for me personally.

We also received very strong support from the people of Austria. We had the great honour of meeting the chancellor of Austria. He has been the strongest European leader in his condemnation of the French. I congratulate him for the strength of his actions. Unfortunately, he has paid a price. He is now not allowed to go to France and meet with the French government. In my view, that demeans the French more than it does the Austrians.

The people of Austria are very anti-nuclear. They do not have nuclear power stations on their territory, although they probably receive a bit of power from France which is generated from nuclear power stations. They are all very anti-nuclear—anti-nuclear weapons and anti-nuclear power. They particularly felt the fallout from the Chernobyl accident of 10 years ago. Their people really do not want to be involved in the nuclear industry or on the military side of it at all. That is why they were so strong in their campaign against this.

As has been stated before, our visit involved going to nine cities in 10 days. It was organised only three weeks prior to our departure. We received outstanding support from the embassies and the high commission in London. They did a wonderful job in organising a program for us as quickly they did. I thank the embassy staff, the ambassadors and the High Commissioner to Great Britain for their great work in setting up the visit. I also wish to thank Dr Janet Gardiner from the Australian embassy in Bonn, who accompanied us for the last seven or eight days. She did a great job too in supporting us and keeping us on track.

May I also thank the other members of the delegation for the work they did and for the opportunity to be with them and to share some of their experiences. I think that we worked very effectively as a team, led most ably by the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs in the first week and by the member for Chifley (Mr Price) in the second week. They did a really good job in their leadership roles, and I appreciate that.

It is a great honour to represent your country in other countries and to be able to put your country's case. We had a very specific and narrow agenda. I think we did a good job—if you don't mind me saying so—in putting Australia's case most effectively. We have continued to ensure that France is isolated. I think the end result is that France will not explode anywhere near eight tests. Because of the strength of international opinion, the number of tests will be down to three—or there may be a fourth one. I do not know how long France will be able to keep putting up with the mass of international protest against it.

My advice to the French government is: stop now and learn from your mistakes. The people of the world do not want your bombs. They do not want them being tested in the South Pacific. Wake up to yourself, France, and heed the message of the whole international community.

TALK.START.PARA: —The cessation of nuclear testing and the signing of the comprehensive test ban treaty are the issues of the moment. Aside from the possibility of accidents, there are serious regional concerns about the long-term consequences to the marine environment. Countries of the South Pacific, like Australia and New Zealand, are opposed to testing in their region on both environmental and moral grounds.

PARA.TAB: I am not speaking today because I took part in the delegation led by the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs (Mr Bilney) but I am pleased that such a high profile delegation went from the parliament of Australia to Europe to convey Australia's opposition to French nuclear testing. At roughly the same time, an unofficial group of Australian members of parliament went with parliamentarians from other parts of the world to Papeete. Because it was not an official delegation I found myself paying my own way. But as I thought it was such an important issue to the people of my electorate and that I was, in every sense of the word, representing their views, I thought it was an important thing to do.

It is not good enough for the French to say they will sign a comprehensive test ban treaty in the future. Deferring difficult issues cannot be tolerated, because those people in our electorates expect us to speak with meaning and act decisively. The issues that I am raising concerning these matters are not what the French government and their spokespeople have said—`a lot of Australians bashing the French'. Our argument is not with French people, whom other generations of Australians have fought with as allies; our argument is with the French government. I acknowledge that 61 to 62 per cent of French people themselves are opposed to nuclear testing and that 95 per cent of Australians are opposed to French nuclear testing.

I could not help being moved by the fact that when we were in the area where these tests were to take place—in fact, one took place just as we left the South Pacific—the French could not be doing those tests if it did not have a colony there. I am not going to say, as we have been accused of saying, that we were there to stir up a feeling for French independence, because that had not entered my head before I got there. It is obvious that those tests would not be being carried out there if it were not for the French having that colonial presence. But it will be for those people themselves to decide.

As one other speaker here today has said, `It is not Australians who have brought this issue of colonialism to world attention but rather President Chirac himself.' The people do not want that testing there in the main, but they have been led to believe that they will not get financial support if the South Pacific is not tied to that nuclear industry.

What of the future? We have a responsibility to maintain our protests. A group of parliamentarians from around the world got together the day after our protest march in Papeete and decided that through international networks there would be a group of parliamentarians formed against nuclear weapons. Parliamentarians for a Nuclear Weapon Free World has met in the federal parliament only this week. Senator Bruce Childs has been elected president. My colleague sitting next to me, the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles), is the vice-president and I am the secretary of that group. We must maintain our protests. I am hopeful of meeting with the French ambassador in Canberra tomorrow to convey the issues that are important in my electorate and are important to other members of this parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to address the statement presented by the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs (Mr Bilney). I compliment the mission on the work they did in Europe and in bringing to the attention of Europe and, to some extent, North America the issue of French nuclear testing. As my colleague for Adelaide (Ms Worth) has said, at the time the mission was in Europe visiting ministers of various governments and trying to get them on side to help us lobby against the resumption of French nuclear testing in the South Pacific, we were in Papeete participating in a peaceful demonstration against resumption of nuclear testing.
