The French Polynesians in Tahiti were almost uniformly opposed to testing. I cannot say, however, that they were uniformly opposed to the French money or the French President.

PARA.TAB: The issue of independence has been raised here today. Before I went there I knew there was an issue and that there were some in French Polynesia that were for decolonisation. They wanted, and still want today, to end the colonial era of the French in that part of our part of the world. But there are still many who derive their incomes from the fact that the French do reside there. Many derive their incomes from the fact that they are testing on the atoll at Mururoa. It is a very complex issue.

After we had finished our protest march and had held our meetings we formed the group called Parliamentarians for a Nuclear Weapon Free World. Then we got on the plane. At 7.30 in the morning, Sydney time—one hour before we landed in Sydney—the French exploded the first nuclear device that they had exploded in a number of years.

While we condemn the French for resuming testing nuclear weapons in our part of the world, we also have to be careful that we condemn China. It is a different issue for us because we see the islands of the Pacific as part of our part of the world and we see that we are responsible for those small island nations to some degree. We increasingly pay attention to them and to their needs. In a foreign aid and a bilateral sense, we try to work with them to help improve their lot in life and help them maintain their environments, which are under a great deal of threat from many sources. The one threat they do not need is nuclear weapons going off under a coral atoll. I can tell you that in an earlier visit to the Marshall Islands I discovered that the people there feel there is a very severe increased incidence of cancer among the people of the Marshall Islands because of the French nuclear testing.

We condemn not only France for resuming this action but also China for its nuclear program. I suppose we say that at least the Chinese are doing it in their own country, on their own land. It is my view that it no longer makes any sense to continue to test these devices of which we should see the world well and truly rid.
The mission was helpful. I commend all the members of the mission on the excellent work they did in bringing this issue to world attention.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 3.00 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 101A. The debate may be resumed at a later hour and the honourable member for La Trobe will have leave to continue speaking when the debate is resumed.
—I direct my question to the Leader of the Opposition under standing order 143. I refer to the bill standing in his name on page 8999 of the Notice Paper.
—He is feeling the pinch, is he? He ought to be, too.
—Order! Those on my right.
—Now that the government has introduced, and the House has passed, another bill on this subject does the Leader of the Opposition intend to withdraw his bill?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to take my private member's bill off the Notice Paper, and the reason why I do not intend to take it off the Notice Paper is that for so long as it can remain on the Notice Paper under the standing orders of this parliament, it will be a reminder to this parliament, and it will be a reminder to the people of Australia, that it was the coalition that forced the government to do something about the curfew at Sydney airport. It will also be a reminder to this parliament, and a reminder to all honourable members, including the Minister for Social Security, and including the member for Lowe who is very conveniently absent from the parliament today, that it was the Liberal and National parties that were prepared, after 12 1/2 years of your doing nothing, Laurie, other than to lie to the Australian people, and putting a lorry of lies to the Australian people—

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! First and foremost, members will be referred to by their correct titles and by their electorates or, if they are ministers, they will be referred to correctly. Secondly, I do not want to have to interrupt people to remark about unparliamentary language. Thirdly, might I suggest to those people on my right that when ministers are going to respond to questions they would like to be heard in silence, and I think the Leader of the Opposition does as well.

—So, after 12 1/2 years of government and after 12 1/2 years of opportunities to do something about the curfew, who was it that provoked this government into doing something about the curfew? It was the Leader of the Opposition and the members of the Liberal and National parties! Not only did the introduction of that bill bring forth from the government—belatedly after 12 1/2 years—a piece of legislation to entrench into law the existing curfew arrangements at Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport and to add a few changes at the shoulder to sort of dress it up and tizzy it up and pretend to the Australian public that it was in some way different from the measures that had been put forward by the opposition; above and beyond that it has provided the parliament with an opportunity to debate issues related to the reopening of the east-west runway.

PARA.TAB: It has provided this parliament with an opportunity of debating how the Labor Party believes in dumping all of the aircraft noise over Sydney on a limited number of people, making absolutely certain that the constituents of the Minister for Industrial Relations, the constituents of the member for Watson, Mr Leo McLeay, and the constituents of the member for Barton, Mr Punch, are completely free of any noise; ensuring in the process that the constituents of some of your own colleagues, who apparently do not have the courage to stand up for their constituents in this parliament, will be affected by noise. It passes very strange to me and to many people in the opposition that the Minister for Social Security has remained completely mute on this issue; that the member for Grayndler has remained mute on this issue; that the member for Lowe has not only remained mute on the issue but has scuttled off overseas; and so has the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, the member for Barton.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, on a point of order, under standing order 145, on relevance and length of answer: I think we have heard a lot from the opposition about length of answers and relevance. Let us talk about it.
—There is no point of order. The Leader of the Opposition has the call.

—They have been strangely mute, and the member for Lowe has scuttled off overseas. We have had from both the Prime Minister and the Minister for Transport a fear campaign, a campaign of dishonesty and deceit, a campaign of lying about safety issues, the likes of which we have not seen even in relation to other subjects such as industrial relations. It really is a forte. I wonder why the Prime Minister believes he has got to start telling lies this far out from the election.
—Order! I have reminded the Leader of the Opposition about unparliamentary language.
—It is not as if he has not had any practice at it.
—Mr Speaker, on a point of order: the Leader of the Opposition has attacked the member for Lowe, who delayed her departure on a parliamentary delegation—
—Order! There is no point of order. Resume your seat.

—From both the Prime Minister and the Minister for Industrial Relations and the Minister for Transport we have this argument advanced about safety. We have had the Prime Minister alleging that people will literally get killed if the policy of the opposition were introduced.
—No, you are the one who is—
—Is that what you believe?
—Order! Those on my right.

PARA.TAB: Mr Keating interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, Prime Minister. I am sure you will get a turn.

—I remind all those interjecting ministers on the frontbench that if you are alleging that that is the consequence of our policy then you are also alleging that it is the consequence of a policy advocated by the New South Wales Premier, because in the last New South Wales election campaign the New South Wales Premier said that he was also in favour of reopening the east-west runway.

PARA.TAB: Let me take the opportunity of putting at rest this argument about safety. The Prime Minister says that it would be dangerous in the extreme to reopen the east-west runway. The Prime Minister suggests that it would introduce into the operations of the airport very dangerous safety considerations. Perhaps the House would like to hear the views expressed by a Mr Tony Williams, and if you dispute Mr Williams—

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—Oh, you are disputing him? He was only an adviser to Graham Richardson when he was a minister in your government. I think it would be very valuable for the Prime Minister and the Minister for Transport to listen to what Mr Williams had to say. In an interview on ABC Radio, he said:

ANSWER.PARA: So there are two considerations. The first is the time difference. In order to get the departure off, if you do it on the east/west runway it takes an additional 20 seconds, if you do it on the north/south runway it takes an additional 50 seconds, if the departing aircraft is on the north/south runway it is sitting on the runway in a collision situation—
I repeat: `it is sitting on the runway in a collision situation'—
for a longer period of time. It is more likely to and has led, frequently, on a weekly basis to the infringement of separation standards. So I would argue that it's not quicker and it's not safer.

In other words, he is arguing that it is not quicker and it is not safer to maintain the policy of the operation of the airport which is now maintained by the government. He is an admitted environmental and aviation expert, a person who was an adviser to a former minister in the government. So not only do you have people of that ilk but you also have the Regional Airlines Association, the air traffic controllers union, the Australian International Pilots Association and the current minister's predecessor, Senator Collins, who said in the Senate on 13 August 1991:
There is absolutely no reason whatever why simultaneous operations, if conducted efficiently and professionally, cannot be used—as they are used in Adelaide as well as Sydney—with perfect safety.
So you have all of this evidence that has been presented to the Senate inquiry. You have the interview of somebody who was an adviser, and an expert adviser, to the government.

PARA.TAB: So, far from my being willing to withdraw my legislation, it is my intention to leave that piece of legislation on the Notice Paper as a reminder of the way in which the politics of the Keating government are to punish a limited number of people in Sydney to the detriment of the wider good.

No sort of phoney argument about economic credentials, no attempt by the Prime Minister to represent my opposition to the privatisation of Sydney airport until the noise issue is fixed, is going to cut any ice.

Remember, this fellow over here was the bloke who for 10 years opposed the privatisation of the Commonwealth Bank. He was the man who in the 1980s conspired with the former Prime Minister of Australia to prevent the sale of Qantas, to prevent the sale of the Commonwealth Bank, to prevent the sale of the then Trans-Australia Airlines at a time when it was a seller's and not a buyer's market. And, as a result of the politics that you played on privatisation in the 1980s, you permanently cost the Australian public millions of dollars of extra proceeds from the sale.
Government members—Time! Time!

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't like to be reminded of that.
—Order!

—But if you had sold those enterprises through the 1980s, the Australian taxpayer would have been permanently enriched to the tune of tens of millions of dollars. They and many others are reasons why I have absolutely no intention of withdrawing that private member's bill.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Is the Prime Minister aware of reports in the media today concerning the sale of assets? What would the consequence be for aviation and the government's impressive micro-reform agenda of any decision to defer the sale of assets such as Sydney's two airports?

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind those on my left this time.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, you know that, when this government came into office in the three weeks before the 1983 election, deceitfully the coalition signed up the two airline agreement which subjected Australian passengers to cost-plus airfares. So heavy was the charge that, since the government deregulated the airline system in the 1980s, we have seen a 60 per cent increase in traffic movements and a 20-odd per cent reduction in airfares.
—You made sure Ansett was looked after, and you bragged about it.
—Order! The member for Hume!

—That micro-economic change was followed up in One Nation removing the domestic and international interface between the airlines by merging Australian Airlines into Qantas and giving Ansett an international licence.

PARA.TAB: The third element of the change from those days of regulation under the Fraser-Howard governments is, of course, the sale of the airports so that their efficiencies might be further enhanced. We have regarded these as important changes to one of the big industries of this country—transport, aviation and tourism—and they have been singularly important in lifting the travelling public through the air traffic system, its safety and its efficiency.
Not only have we done it there, we have done it in the waterfront, in shipping and in telecommunications—we have seen a dramatic fall now in telephone charges.

TALK.START.PARA: —You're kidding!
—The member for Hume.

—We have seen a dramatic change in all these areas. The challenge is to keep these changes going. Those on the other side of the parliament say that they're the ones to keep it going; that the Labor government has come as far as it can on the labour market; the Labor government has come as far as it can on air traffic; it has come as far as it can on shipping and the waterfront; and—this is your spiel around the boardrooms—it is now time to hand it over to us, the hairy-chested people who will go in and do the final nut cracking. The Leader of the Opposition said on 17 February 1995:

ANSWER.PARA: The greatest priority that faces the government at the present time in the national economic interest is to reignite the process of micro-economic reform.
Reignite it! This is the same person, Mr Speaker, who wants to cut down by 20 to 25 per cent the throughput and efficiency of Mascot airport. Then, on 20 May this year, he said:
A coalition government will revitalise the micro-economic reform process.
He said:

A productivity commission will carry out a stocktake of the progress on micro-economic reform. There will be particular emphasis on areas which impact on Australia's international competitiveness, as well as a timetable for decision making and implementation.
This is the sort of chatter we have about the needs of micro reform on his side of the House. Mr Speaker, he had this to say on 3 September 1991, talking about Sydney airport:

What makes what this government has done so criminally irresponsible in a political sense is that all along it has known the right thing to do. It is one thing to be invincibly ignorant about the correct economic prescription; it is an infinitely more culpable thing to know what the right thing is and to conscientiously eschew that course of action in the name of political expediency and political opportunity.

That is exactly and precisely what the Leader of the Opposition is doing. He was upbraiding them—members of the government—he said, who knew what the right thing was to be done and who were then culpable, not through invincible ignorance but because they were doing something which was politically expedient and politically opportune—his own words. Then he said this about the member for Barton:

Anybody who knows anything about the scandal of Sydney airport and the disgraceful political featherbedding of the honourable member for Barton must regard this as one of the most shameful exercises in political cynicism at the expense of the interests of the greatest Australian city this country has seen. The government was going to do all these things. It was going to be the party of great reform. It was going to be here to say this is the end of its third term, and, here we are, we picked up the rest of the reform agenda.

In other words, he is upbraiding Mr Punch for what he says is his opportunism—and of course Mr Punch resigned his place in the ministry over this decision and put his integrity on the line—yet he talks about the right thing to do and knowing the difference between invincible ignorance and doing something politically opportune.

PARA.TAB: In his remarks earlier he said that I had imputed to him things about the safety issue and, to quote him, `lies about safety'—on my behalf, about him. Let me quote him from 8 February 1989:

ANSWER.PARA: In the interests of safety, airport facilities should be upgraded immediately including the construction of the third runway. . . . The Government is playing carelessly with a situation that could too easily result in a major tragedy. The risk must be averted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—J.W. Howard on 8 February 1989. The very same cross-wind operation that he now gets up in the House and accuses me essentially of lies about—the very same subject of trying to move back to a cross-wind configuration. Then he had this to say, Mr Speaker, to the question, `They may get less traffic if the third runway is built':

ANSWER.PARA: Many people will get less . . . because you will have the north-south pattern. I think the case for it—
the north-south pattern—

TALK.START.PARA: —What were you saying in 1983, baldy?
—The member for Mayo wants to be careful.
—He is talking about `it' being the north-south pattern—

ANSWER.PARA: on general interest grounds is absolutely overwhelming.
Mr Speaker, let us get this right. He is saying that the case for the north-south pattern on general interest grounds is absolutely overwhelming. The next sentence is this:
Our policy is to build it. That has been our policy for the past six and a half years.
Then, of course, you have got all the shadow ministers on the other side saying the same thing. Then today he is slipping and sliding all over ABC radio, saying that:
The crux of the debate is what I have just said, and that is we have always championed the third runway, but we don't have a third runway at the moment.

In other words, because the cross-wind runway is out, three becomes two. Mr Speaker, that is the sort of duplicity and dishonesty that he is now into. Mr Speaker, is it any wonder the Financial Review says today:
Who is the real John Howard?
. . . There is an urgent need for the Liberal Party to define itself in terms of policy substance. For unless it does, Paul Keating will.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you read this, today's the Courier-Mail?
—The Leader of the Opposition knows better.
—Let me make it quite clear that I will be defining what he stands for in policy terms. Let him put his money on that one. The Financial Review continued:

PARA.TAB: In the absence of policies, the entire country is attempting to decipher Mr Howard through his deeds rather than his words. And with a little help from the Prime Minister . . .

ANSWER.PARA: Indeed! For the most crass of political motives, having supported the north-south configuration of the third runway for years and years, now for a handful of votes in the seat of Bennelong he is trying to hold the government to ransom by putting asunder the assets sales program, which will advance the micro reform agenda. In the largest micro change in the airports of this country in 25 years—the opening of this runway and the attendant increase in traffic—he now wants to cut back the movements from roughly 80 to 85 per hour when the new control tower is operational to 55 to 60 per hour only when the cross-wind runway is put back in the system. That, of course, would be a danger and would be inherently unsafe, with an aircraft on the cross-wind direction needing to cross the runway and flight paths of two other intersecting aircraft.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is only one, you dope.
—Order!
—The Leader of the Opposition went on and suggested that the government has lied about the safety issue, when he himself said:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government is playing carelessly with a situation that could too easily result in a major tragedy. The risk must be averted.

He has also said, `It makes it criminally irresponsible to do something that is right when people know it is the right thing to do in the name of political expediency and political opportunism.' The real John Howard has stood up—the John Howard of the 1980s, the Mr Do-nothing, the bloke that squibbed all the big decisions. He is going around now saying, `We will reignite the micro-economic reform agenda'—reignite it by closing down the capacity of Mascot airport—`we will reignite it only if I don't lose a few votes in Bennelong.' He wants the Australian community to believe that they are the new wave, the hard people who will do the micro-economic changes that need to be done—

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you ask them?
—Order! The member for Mallee.

—the people who will stand up to trade unions, the people who will make the reforms on the waterfront and in the airline system. Yet, with the first whiff of grapeshot, the first pressure that he gets from his own constituency, what does he do? Not only does he say that he is in favour of reopening the cross-wind heading; he will actually stand the government's budget up to the tune of $2 billion to get his way. In other words, he will not only detract from the micro-economic reform agenda but also try to vandalise the budget on the way through. Now we are finally seeing him. As I told our party, the public and the media, he is the same old person. He is the same person without ideas and without principle. In the 1970s, it was all Malcolm Fraser's fault. He could not get the float of the dollar through because Malcolm would not cop it.
—Oh, macho man; show us your chest.
—Order! The member for Mackellar.

—He could not resist the increases in tariffs because Malcolm would not encourage any other policy. He could not reform the waterfront because there was no courage on the part of the coalition to summons it. Now, monkey cunning, he is hiding his policies. If you want to go to the election without policies, you also have to go without views. And your opportunism and your views have dribbled out. As they have dribbled, we have stood on them; we have spudded them. One is this arrant and arrogant opportunism on the part of the Leader of the Opposition in respect of this airport.
—This is next week's program, is it?
—Order!

—The whole air traffic system of Australia would be held to ransom were this to happen. You have seen the statement now by Mr Olsen in South Australia. You have seen statements by the Victorian government. You have seen statements across the country about the flow-on implications for Brisbane, for Melbourne, for Adelaide, for Perth and for other locations. Were this to happen, where we would see some of the reductions coming would be on traffic from places like Albury, Cowra, Dubbo, Mudgee, Tamworth, Armidale, Griffith, Hay and Wagga. All those places will be forced to hub because they will not able to have small, light aircraft access due to constraints on Mascot airport with cross-wind directional runways.

PARA.TAB: This is the real implication of John Howard's policy. He is entitled to his view, even if it is wrong; but he is not entitled to try to rip a hole in the budget to get his way. I say to some of these people in the press gallery that if the scales are falling from your eyes it can be for only one reason: you were not here in the 1970s and the 1980s; because, for any one of you who was, he is just like he always was—without ideas and without principles.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Prime Minister and goes to the nub of this matter.

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Those on my right! I want to hear the question.

—You are a bit panicky over there. Prime Minister, if you seriously argue that the Leader of the Opposition and I are setting up the world's worst airline collision at Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport by reopening the east-west runway, if you are going to pursue these types of arguments, is it not therefore your position that you and the Minister for Transport have already set one up at Tullamarine in Melbourne where Simops by that name and other crossover runway operations occur now, winds permitting, on a regular basis?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the National Party knows—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —very obviously that at any time during the day in Sydney now there will be two aircraft coming down from the north or south on two flight paths which intersect the flight path for the east-west runway. That being the case, he knows it would be an act of lunacy to be running the east-west runway in a system on a cross-wind heading with two intersecting runways.
—There is only one, you know.
—Two intersecting runways!
—Those on my left will just sit and not interject. The Prime Minister has been asked a question by the Leader of the National Party—and he will be heard.

—Because Mascot's configuration is unique in Australia, there is no other model; there is no other parallel that you can make. It is that way because there are two parallel seaward runways and there are no such conditions in any other place. Also, the movements in Sydney are nearly double those in Melbourne. Let me just read what the Civil Air Operations Officers Association of Australia had to say. The question was put:

ANSWER.PARA: Are you suggesting the cross runway operation is not safe or just less safe?
The answer was:

They rely more heavily upon the skill of the aerodrome controller in judging the point of conflict between two aircraft operating on the crossing runway set-up. At the moment with parallel runway operations, any conflict is removed from the precinct of the airport itself. There are standard arrival routes and standard instrument departures which put in place a procedure whereby aircraft cross at points remote from the airport.
Miles out from the airport.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like surrounding suburbs—Lowe!
—He continued:

ANSWER.PARA: They are operating in a safer sense because of the standard operating procedures that are put in to cover those types of operations.
He went on:
Parallel runway operations in the purest sense is the safest form of operation than operations on any intersecting runway.
That is exactly what the two airlines have said in their statement when they published their views endorsing the official views. They said:

We accept the advice of the regulatory authorities of our own technical experts that safety and efficiency would be diminished by permanently reopening the east-west runway to jet movements. The key point is that intersecting runways are inherently less efficient and less safe.

That is the view of the two airlines. That is the view of the regulatory authority. It is the view of the people who operate the system. But the Leader of the National Party has the gall to put his view in here, trying to juxtapose an argument to say that because there is one directional runway in Melbourne and other ports with a cross-wind heading they have cross-wind runways. If the winds change, what do you want to do? Close the airport down for a day or two? The cross-wind runway will be used in Sydney when the weather changes, as well.

PARA.TAB: Since the government deregulated the airline system there has been a 60 per cent upward movement in traffic. If we were to adopt the opposition's policy all the people who come from the provincial cities of New South Wales would need to hub at a certain airport and get into a wider-bodied aircraft. So the people in 10-, 15- or 20-seater planes from Albury, Cowra, Dubbo, Mudgee, Tamworth, Armidale, Griffith, Hay or Wagga will all have to hub somewhere and then climb into a wide-bodied aircraft so it can get access to the Mascot airport. That is why this parallel system is inherently more safe.

But the government has the other policy in place, and that is to diminish the burden of the noise through two things. One is the most ambitious noise abatement program in the world and the second is the establishment and development of Badgerys Creek airport so that the city has a complementary airport, so that burden is taken from people. But the Leader of the Opposition wants to put the noise back on, as the minister estimates, 86,000 people or, as the mayor of Rockdale estimates, 142,000 extra people as aircraft again use the east-west configuration on a permanent basis.

All of this is about relieving the Leader of the Opposition from some pressure in the seat of Bennelong. He can go on as much as he likes. He is damned by his own quotes. He is damned out of his own mouth on safety, on micro-economic reform, on doing what should be done when you know what is right to be done. He is damned backwards and forwards. That is why I say he thinks the public in some way are going to fall for the malarky that he is out there trying to even up the noise. They all know the issues here. They have been in this debate for years. It has been on for 20 years. They all know that, if the east-west runway opens, about 100,000 people are going to get more noise. They know that if a cross-wind heading is used again the place is going to be inherently unsafe. They know that capacity is going to go down. The tourism industry knows it will not cope with the numbers. They know it is all about his seat.

He is telling them he is the new leader—that he is the person who is going to make the micro-economic changes; he is the one who is going to take on the unions; he is the one who is going to reform the waterfront; he is the one who is going to crack the micro-economic nuts. He is as he has always been. He does not amount to a row of beans. In political life he has been a policy sponger, and he has never changed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call the honourable member for Greenway.

PARA.TAB: Mr Howard—Feel better? Do you feel better now, Paul?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Leader of the Opposition! I am trying to announce a distinguished visitor. I inform the House that we have present in the gallery this afternoon the former distinguished Prime Minister and now Speaker of the National Parliament of Papua New Guinea the Rt Hon. Rabbie Namaliu. On behalf of the House, I extend a very warm welcome to him.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Transport. Can the minister outline the implications of the delay in the government's timetable for the construction of Sydney's second airport at Badgerys Creek?

—I thank the member for his question. I take this opportunity to indicate to the House the very serious national implications of any delay in the construction of the new airport at Badgerys Creek; that is, the Sydney West airport that this government is committed to commissioning in time for the year 2000 Olympics. There is no doubt that delay is an absolute certainty unless the Leader of the Opposition backs away from his reckless attempt to vandalise the government's airport leasing strategy. Have no doubt about that; a very considerable delay is involved. I will indicate to the House exactly why.

PARA.TAB: The whole financing of Sydney West airport is predicated on the leasing of Sydney's existing airport. Indeed, the two airports are leased together. Ensuring that Sydney West is built and opened by the end of 1999 to a standard and to the timetable set by the government is an absolutely non-negotiable condition of the lease of Sydney airport. We are very busy. I indicate to the House that the environmental impact statement on the first of the major road links to that airport will be released early next week. We are working with the Federal Airports Corporation and the Department of Transport to have that job under way, because it faces an extraordinarily tight time frame.

The leasing of Sydney airport and the funding of Sydney West are an essential, intrinsic part of an overall package. By broadening that leasing process, the opposition leader is making that timetable impossible. In turn, he is ensuring that Sydney only has one airport in the year 2000 to cater for the great influx of traffic that will bring those hundreds of thousands of tourists to Australia in the year 2000 to attend that great event.

In the process, he will block and delay the work of thousands of construction workers in western Sydney whose job it will be to ready that airport and to have it there to serve the interests of Sydney. Along the way, he will ensure enormous congestion and chaos at Sydney airport. Not only is he sentencing us to one airport; he is saying that, if he is ever unfortunate enough to be elected, it will be one airport with cross-runways operating jet movements. That is what he has committed himself to. The capacity of the airport then falls over.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Tullamarine.

—The capacity of Melbourne airport, in case you do not know, on a yearly basis is about half of Sydney's. Adelaide's capacity is about a third of Sydney's. They do not have the demand that Sydney has. They would not be affected in the way that Sydney will be as a result of this outrageous prescription of the Leader of the Opposition.

PARA.TAB: Not only would we have no jobs, no airport and enormous congestion and chaos at Kingsford Smith airport; we would also have a flow-on delay at every airport around Australia. One of the truisms of Graeme McMahon in the circular he put out last year to all the frequent fliers at Ansett was that a delay at Sydney airport prangs around the whole system. It has a knock-on or repeater effect. Every time a plane is in a holding pattern or is stuck on the ground at Kingsford Smith, it is late getting to the other end. That compounds itself around the whole system.

That is not all that will be lost. A delay in the leasing of Kingsford Smith airport will also mean a delay in the transfer of curfew operations and the curfew shoulder operations that are covered by the bill that passed through this parliament yesterday. So there will not be any of those freighters going out there at the end of 1999 either. They will all be stuck at Sydney airport.

Simultaneously, in the national scene, the Leader of the Opposition will hold back the leasing of all the other FAC airports. That includes Melbourne and Adelaide. It is significant that John Olsen has already publicly called upon the Leader of the Opposition to back away from this piece of madness. He did so in the Adelaide Advertiser yesterday. It is significant that Jeffrey Kennett was told by John Howard before he announced this in the parliament yesterday that there would not be a delay in the leasing of Melbourne. He gave him that undertaking. But the fact is that it is an undertaking he cannot keep. Every one of the bidders have said that they will not bid for Melbourne if it precludes them from subsequently bidding for Sydney, because Sydney is worth twice as much as Melbourne.
So every bit of advice to the government from the Finance department, Treasury and BT Australia says you have to start with Sydney. So that is what you are pranging into.
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Those at the far end of the chamber on the cross benches!

—If that is not bad enough, he has now done something even worse. Not only is he blocking the leasing strategy but he has thrown a real cloud over the principal asset. Yesterday, he said that Kingsford Smith should be a domestic airport only. This is the message he sent to those people who are proposing to bid many hundreds of millions of dollars for this asset.

PARA.TAB: If he were to do that, in one fell swoop he would increase the cost of developing Sydney West airport because we would not only have to have it ready in 1999 for international and domestic flights on the curfew but also have to cater for 75 international flights a day. That is more than 500 international flights per week—of those, 420 are jumbo jets. That is the sort of airport you would have to build first up at Badgerys Creek.

In the environmental impact statement, the additional cost of that was put down at $1 billion. So it is a further $1 billion hit as well. At the same time, he guts the value of the principal asset of the Federal Airports Corporation. It would be very hard to imagine how he would do it while keeping his commitments to fix up the budget surplus. How in God's name would he do it?

We have waited a long time in this place to see some opposition policies. Now we have at least two: we have a policy on IR and we have a policy on Sydney airport. Both of them have been personally designed by the Leader of the Opposition. If they are anything to go by, at least let us bring on the rest.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Is the Prime Minister aware that the Regional Airlines Association, the air traffic controllers' union, the Australian International Pilots Federation, international experts—of which the Minister for Transport is not one—and even the minister's own colleague, the former Minister for Transport, Senator Collins, have all agreed that it is possible to operate the three runways at Kingsford Smith airport in a safe manner? Does this not prove that your claim that a three-runway operation at Kingsford Smith cannot be conducted safely is clearly false?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is just drivel. That is just tripe. No-one with any authority said any such thing. If that is the case, why were you arguing so hard for the third runway for so long? So we are down to that sort of dishonesty now, are we? The third runway means the second seaward runway but there are now only two because the previous one is not operating; is that right? Is that what you are about?
—Oh, come on, Keating; that is not correct.

—I have seen some low rent stuff in this House in my time, but trying to say that he was in favour of the third runway when at the time there were two operating and the third was the seaward runway, and to now suggest on radio and elsewhere that he was in favour of three runways—but now there are only two and he is not in favour of them—is startling. It takes your breath away. You do not know what to say about it.

PARA.TAB: It is so palpably pathetic and dishonest that you hardly wonder what you can say about it. In other words, he is now saying he is in favour of three runways if they are all running at once but he is not in favour of two. So when for years they were telling us, `Build a seaward runway,' they really did not mean that, they only wanted two. Is that what you are telling us?
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Those on my left!
—I will give you his words. On the ABC today, Fran Kelly said:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . and that failure to do it would put lives at risk. It could mean a loss of lives.
And Mr Howard said:
The crux of this debate is what we just said—that is, we have always championed a third runway. We don't have a third runway at the moment.
Can you believe it?

TALK.START.PARA: —Your attack is off course.
—Order! The member for Flinders!
—So when he was out there arguing to build the third runway into the sea he did not mean it.
—Now give us that two and one bit again.
—Order! The member for Flinders!
—He said:

ANSWER.PARA: Many people will get less because you'll have the north-south pattern. I think the case for it on general interest grounds is absolutely overwhelming.

So you did not mean that at the time, is that right? When you said, `Our policy is to build it', you meant the one that was already built, is that what you meant? You meant the one that was already built.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fancy taking weeks.
—Order! The member for Mayo!

—The fact of the matter is that all the authorities everywhere have argued that the intersection of two north-south configured runways is essentially unsafe. A dramatic reduction in the capacity of Kingsford Smith airport would mean all the members for the National Party held areas would lose their direct access to Mascot airport. What it means is that they will have to hub through some other places like Wagga or Dubbo.
—Well, why is the Regional Airlines Association supporting it?
—Order! I warn the member for Hume.

—They will have to take their 10 seaters and their 15 seaters and climb into a much larger wide bodied aircraft for the final journey to Sydney airport. That is what it means for them. What it really means, though, is what this saga has meant from the very start—that is, once the blowtorch is put onto John Howard about anything that is difficult, he drops back. All I can say is: if the mayor of Hunters Hill can shift him this far in a week, just imagine how far we are going to shift him in the election campaign in a month.

—My question is directed to the Treasurer. Is the Treasurer aware of reports of proposals for wide ranging tax concessions? Can the Treasurer advise the House of the impact of such proposals on the current account?

—I thank the member for Dunkley for his question. Yes, I have seen various reports of the need for tax concessions. Almost every week there are further such reports outlining what the opposition is saying in various places around the country.

PARA.TAB: We have seen this week in the latest edition of Womens' Weekly, which is a very popular magazine bought by almost a million Australian women, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition pledging tax relief for families and tax concessions for retirees. A few days before that the Australian carried a story saying that the opposition was considering options to slash tax on bank savings and would offer small businesses dramatic relief from fringe benefits and capital gains taxes.

Two weeks ago, the Leader of the Opposition's office issued a list of so-called policies which included promises to provide an incentive to take out private health insurance, to provide assistance to single income families with children, to provide more money for roads and to provide a guarantee of a fixed percentage of Commonwealth revenue to the states. Just before that we had in the Lismore Northern Star the Leader of the Opposition advocating an increase in Austudy and promising to the children at Ballina High School that there would be a substantial increase in Austudy. The day before another promise appeared in the Australian which stated: `The opposition pledges more science funding'.

Almost every week we are seeing these sorts of promises coming from the coalition. They are everywhere you look. They are promising tax cuts here, tax cuts there, tax cuts everywhere. Perhaps this is what the opposition means when they talk about having released a lot of policies. Of course all of these promises would cost a lot of money. For example, the promise by the Leader of the Opposition to bridge the gap between the dole and Austudy—a promise he made to the children of Ballina High School—would cost $185 million.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?

—Some $185 million. That is just that one promise. His promise, which he has repeated a number of times, to give the states a fixed share of Commonwealth taxation revenue would cost $2.8 billion over the next two years. The health insurance incentives which he is advocating, if they are anything like what they were in Fightback, would cost about $850 million. Obviously, they are a very expensive set of promises. All of the promises that I have not been able to cost would obviously cost hundreds of millions, perhaps billions, of dollars.

PARA.TAB: This is the same opposition which is opposing the government's measures to reduce the budget deficit. In the budget debate this year we have seen the opposition oppose $1.5 billion worth of tax measures. They are also seeking to reduce various spending cuts, such as the better targeting of child-care assistance and changes to the HECS scheme. As we have heard in the last couple of days, they now want to stop the government going ahead with the privatisation of the airports at a cost of something in the order of $2 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not in the budget! You know that!
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition!
—It is in the forward estimates for 1996-97, 1997-98 and 1998-1999. You know it is there and you would prevent it happening. They couldn't even lie straight in bed.

PARA.TAB: Whilst we have got all of this going on, we have got them going around the country making all these promises about tax concessions. At the same time as they are trying to stop all sorts of measures getting through the budget, they are also saying that they support severe corrective measures to address the current account. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition is on record on various occasions saying that we should have severe corrective measures, tighter fiscal policy, to address the current account deficit; yet at the same time he is promising all these tax cuts and trying to stop the government from introducing tighter fiscal policy.

What a total stack of contradictions! What a complete set of non sequiturs in terms of a logical development of policy! How can you possibly go round saying that you support measures to address the current account through tighter fiscal policy, when you are trying to stop us doing it and you are also advocating all over the place measures to loosen fiscal policy. The only way that that hangs together in any shape or form is if you also have a stack of policies to draconically smash through government expenditure programs. There is no other way.

Since you say you have ruled out any tax increases, the only way all that hangs together is to have a secret plan to smash government expenditures, particularly in the areas which you have not ruled out cuts in such as health, education, community services, housing, welfare, employment programs—these sorts of things which are essential to the living standards of the Australian people. These are the areas in which your policies would have to involve dramatic cuts if there were to be any kind of logic about your policies.

So the policy position that the opposition is adopting means that they are not at all concerned about budget outcomes, they are quite happy to see large budget deficits, which makes a nonsense of the business about addressing the current account. This was repeated in the Women's Weekly where, in the same paragraph that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition said he promised these tax concessions, he said he would cut back on the current account deficit in the first term of government and eliminate it in the second but at the same time he has this array of measures to cut taxes and is trying to stop us tighten fiscal policy. The only way that that could possibly hang together is to have a secret plan to slash government expenditure in a host of areas which are so important.

Of course, that is what they did last time. It is exactly what they did last time. When the now Leader of the Opposition was Treasurer, what he did was to slash welfare expenditure. He cut the real level of pensions and unemployment benefits.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought I let the budget blow out.
—Yes, you did.
—I cut wages and let them blow out?

—You did both. You never ever got a surplus but what you did do was to slash welfare expenditure. You also cut social wage expenditures in the areas of health, education, community services and housing by some 17 1/2 per cent per capita in real terms. There was this dramatic attack on social expenditures by the opposition when they were last in government. It did not give them a budget surplus; they still had budget deficits.

PARA.TAB: The only surpluses that have ever been produced by a government of Australia has been under this government in the late 1980s for four years in a row and, of course, we will be restoring it to surplus this year and in the years hereafter. We are the ones with the credentials on budget policy; we are the ones with the credentials in terms of producing good budget outcomes; and we are the ones with the credentials to attack the current account deficit—certainly not the opposition with this set of crazy policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. In view of, firstly, the ABC board's subverting of its charter with backdoor sponsorship deals in recent years; secondly, the financial disaster of the Asian television service and its many misleading statements concerning that venture; and, thirdly, the collapse of its pay TV deal and the apparent disappearance of the $12 1/2 million seeding grant and licence C, what confidence can the government and the public have in the current ABC board and what mechanisms exist for any accountability? Does the government intend to continue to give the board the right to dispose of half a billion dollars of public funds in any way it sees fit?

—I thank the honourable member for North Sydney for his question. The first point to make about Australia TV is that half the members of this chamber and half the members of the Senate have been congratulating the ABC on the great job it has been doing in putting together Australia TV. I am always surprised at how frequently Senator Alston, the opposition spokesman on communications, attends the launches promoting Australia TV both in Australia and overseas. I have heard one or two opposition spokesmen as well advocating that Australia TV has done a good job in raising our profile in Asia.

PARA.TAB: I am not going to deny to the member for North Sydney that the ABC has certainly not met its targets in obtaining sponsorship for Australia Television. That is why the government at the moment has a review of the international broadcasting services of the ABC, both Radio Australia and Australia TV. But I would have thought the honourable member for North Sydney would agree with the view, which is widely held I think on both sides of this House, that it has been good for Australia to have Australia TV out there raising Australia's profile. The question, as we conduct the review, is whether this is the best way for the public's finances to be used to promote Australia in the region, or are there alternative options that can be explored. Decisions will be made on Australia TV probably by the end of next month.

Senator Alston, the opposition spokesman on pay TV, has criticised the government for the fact that the ABC has been involved in pay TV. Yet Senator Alston was the senator who moved the amendment in the Senate that forced the ABC to be involved in pay TV. It is a bit hypocritical of the Liberals to run around saying that it is a terrible thing that the ABC has not been successful in pay TV and the government is responsible when it was a deal between the Liberals and the Australian Democrats that actually forced the ABC to be issued a licence.

From the government's point of view, we said that we did not want the ABC's involvement in pay TV to have any detrimental effect on the ABC's free to air services. So we gave the ABC $12 1/2 million to try to ensure there was no impact on the excellent content that goes to make up the ABC's free to air services. I know that some people, including Senator Alston, are suggesting that all $12 1/2 million has been spent. My advice is that that is not correct: it is significantly less than that.

But really it is up to the ABC board and the board of Australian Information Media to make public announcements about this issue. People should remember that the parliament required the government to issue the licence. We have done that. It is not the government's job to negotiate the ABC-Fairfax-Cox corporate arrangement with the cable operators. That is the responsibility of the board of AIM.

The final point I make is this: you asked whether I have confidence in the board of the ABC. Yes, I do. I think that the ABC produces some excellent quality television and radio and I hope that continues for many years to come.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Prime Minister aware of reports about alternative industrial relations proposals? Is it the intention of the government to adopt such proposals?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker—
—Give us the story about New Zealand.
—I am aware of the federal opposition's dramatically changed approach to industrial relations from that which the government has pursued over a decade—
—He told us all about New Zealand.
—I warn the member for O'Connor.

—The federal opposition wants to run an industrial relations policy which drives individual members of the work force on individual wage contracts, but where in the negotiation of those contracts there is no test as to disadvantage. There is no test as to whether a working person will be compensated when other elements of what is now an award package are negotiated away under an enterprise agreement.

PARA.TAB: The government has made clear in the House before that such things as overtime, penalty rates and holiday leave loadings may be traded in and cashed out to an employee provided this can only happen on the basis that the employee is made no worse off. In other words, if the employee wants to take some of these benefits as cash, the government's no disadvantage test provides flexibility in the labour market. But we do believe that there are community obligations on areas such as sick leave and other things that should not be cashed out.

This is not the case with the opposition. The opposition will allow these things to be basically taken away without compensation. I gave some examples the other day. Let me flesh some of them out. I talked about a nurse who was receiving penalty rates and overtime. She now finds they have gone and this would reduce the nurse's income by about 22 per cent or $5,000 a year. A truck driver who works 12 hours overtime a week is offered a new contract by his employer with just the minimum conditions. In that case, even if he works 12 hours more than a usual full-time driver, he finds his annual income is cut by $113 a week or $5,900 a year—a cut of about 18 per cent. That would apply to the 359,000 people in that occupation at the moment.

We saw an example recently where a Mr Geoff Allan in Western Australia was dismissed when he refused to take a workplace agreement which did not include overtime pay and did not offer any compensation for losing annual leave, sick leave and public holidays. Unluckily for Mr Allan he worked in Western Australia. The Western Australian government has introduced its version of what the Leader of the Opposition believes is a good industrial relations policy. Mr Allan was eventually sacked for not agreeing to the conditions. No doubt some other person who has agreed to the conditions has taken his place. This is the chipping away.

You would say, `Well, why would the coalition want to do these things?' Is it that it will increase the profit share? Yet the profit share is already at a record high. Is it such that it is going to improve our competitiveness? But we are already 40 per cent more competitive than we were a decade ago. Is it for productivity? You would say, `Well, it must be for productivity.' Yet in New Zealand, the country mentioned in the interjection, in the period since individual contracts were introduced in the legislation labour productivity has risen by one per cent. In the equivalent period in Australia it has risen by 2 1/2 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the wages comparison between the two?
—The member for O'Connor, you have been warned.

—You have to say to yourself: if it is not working in New Zealand for productivity why would they do it other than for spite, other than an ideological view that people at the bottom end of the work force ought to take the chop and take a big salary reduction while people at the top end go their hardest. The years of wage restraint in this last decade in Australia have been predicated on these two principal points: wage restraint for employment growth and restraining the top end power of the ACTU constituency so that there is a fair wage outcome for the people at the bottom.
—Or to increase wages.

—In other words, the trade unions and the work force have moved as a group, saying, `We want wage and salary justice for all of us.' In doing that in the areas of extreme market power in the ACTU top end area we will restrain it so that people down at the bottom get a go. Under its policy the coalition is saying, `Let her rip at the top and we will cut into them at the bottom.' If the opposition cuts into them at the bottom there is no way that anyone would restrain the top end power of the trade union movement—no possible way.

PARA.TAB: As a consequence, we would see wage inflation reintroduced into Australia. What would happen under a Howard government is that the Reserve Bank would go for the interest rate lever immediately because there is no accord and interest rates would rise to cover the increase in wage inflation that would come from it. It is worth recalling that the Leader of the Opposition has had this to say:

ANSWER.PARA: The federal coalition's labour policy would bring the greatest change to Australia greater than its proposed goods and services tax.

That is the view he put in 1993. He has always seen the big change as not the GST—even though he is still hungering for that. He regards the greater change as a change in the labour market policies, as introducing their labour market policies. That is what he sees as the great change. So does the ACTU and so does the work force. That is why a coalition government would be met immediately with a very large wage round which would kick wage inflation along, and straightaway the Reserve Bank would go for the interest rate lever. That is why in a coalition government you will see a dramatic increase in interest rates as the only remedy to try to handle wage inflation.

PARA.TAB: They were under no misapprehension at the ACTU congress yesterday about what J.W. Howard has in store for them. They were under no misapprehension that the people on the bottom deciles of the labour market will have their incomes cut dramatically without compensation, with the abolition of the no disadvantage test. They know that 43 per cent of the work force have either changed jobs or taken jobs in the last three years and that 43 per cent of the work force will have no award protections. They know these things, yet this is what is proposed by the federal opposition in terms of industrial relations policy.
The Leader of the Opposition is running around saying that it is a scare campaign of lies. It is a truth campaign about his policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Look at those behind you, Paul.
—Order! The member for Gippsland.
—I have always had policies.

—On wages you have always had a policy, and that is to gut the people at the bottom end of the system. That has always been your policy, and it has never changed. That is why you said in 1993 that the coalition's labour policy would bring the greatest change to Australia rather than any change to the tax system.

PARA.TAB: That is why these examples, as in the Western Australian example, make clear that there are very large losses facing ordinary Australians, up to $5,000 a year, by the election of a Howard government, because the industrial relations policies would tear away at all the award protections and all of the protections of the no disadvantage test for conditions which have taken a century to put in place. That is why the Leader of the Opposition would transport Australia back 100 years, simply back to the common law.
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Those on my left.

—It would be back to the master and servant provisions, back to the only basis of protection in law—the master and servant provisions of the common law. You could understand if these characters were part of the landed gentry, like the old British Liberal Party, with the houses in the country and the big estates, but most of them you would not trade for a jam jar full of 5c pieces. Yet they think they are the born to rule squad who will put working people back in their place. As I have said on many occasions, there is one little hang-up over here we have always had: we thought most of us in public life were born to rule them, and so far we have been going pretty well at it.

—My question is directed to the Deputy Prime Minister and Leader of the House. Earlier this week the Deputy Prime Minister stated that to reopen the east-west runway at Sydney's Mascot airport would increase its capacity by 10 extra jumbo jets per hour. Today, the Prime Minister has stated that to reopen the east-west runway would be a failure of micro-economic reform because it would reduce the capacity of Sydney's Kingsford Smith airport. Who is correct—the Deputy Prime Minister or the Prime Minister? You can be sure that both of you can't be.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me assist you and your leader's policy which you are having trouble conceiving. Your leader's policy is that you should be able to operate cross-wind jet operations, which require not the stub of the east-west runway but the whole of the east-west runway to operate. The Regional Airlines Association states:

ANSWER.PARA: It is imperative to open 07-25 runway for regional aircraft SAAB 340, Dach-8s, metros and smaller aircraft that would have a very low noise factor. In fact, a bus on the roads would make more noise.

PARA.TAB: Every non-jet aircraft taken out of the mainstream traffic flow allows more jet aircraft onto 16-34 runways. There should not be a noise problem as this procedure has been used for many years.

ANSWER.PARA: That is not the operation on the totality of the east-west runway; that is the operation on the stub of the east-west runway.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is wrong. The Prime Minister is wrong.
—No, I'm absolutely right. So the point is this—
—No, the Prime Minister got it wrong.
—No, you are confused, I'm afraid.
—Those on my left! The minister has the call and will be heard.
—If you operate the jets in that mode utilising the totality of the runway and not the stub, because the jets need—
—Oh, so you are both right!
—The member for Gippsland!

—full operation of the runway, of course, all the consequences that the Prime Minister discussed flow—all the consequences in relation to safety, all the consequences in relation to capacity, the massive reductions of capacity, the massive difficulties with safety and the fact that you cannot seem to comprehend that no other airport in Australia operates with a parallel runway and a cross-wind runway that operates across the runways—none!

PARA.TAB: When Senator Collins was the responsible minister, he put a caveat on any cross-wind runway operations with a single runway, not a parallel north-south runway and said that international jets could not utilise that system because it was an unsafe operation with people who were unfamiliar with the operations into Sydney.

When you put down your proposition, which they don't do anywhere—that is, to operate jets on the full extent of the east-west runway instead of the stub of the east-west runway—then you produce a situation where there is a massive capacity loss. If, however, you operate on the stub of the east-west runway—which you also argue against on safety grounds—that is advocated by the Regional Airlines Association with the positive benefit, they argue, that there would be a massive increase of 10 jumbos per hour on the north-south runway, a most extraordinary thing, the impact of that, of course, would be to massively increase the noise over the people at both ends of the runways and be an unsafe operation.

The fact that you absolutely cannot comprehend these things—because it is a more complex equation than one plus one equals two—is merely an indication of how little you know about sensible policy development. Your leader, however, has opted for one thing and one thing only. Your leader has repudiated that type of operation—no, he just does not want propeller-driven aircraft on the end of the east-west runway. He wants jets across the full extent of the east-west runway. The impact of that is: firstly, massively unsafe; and, secondly, it collapses the effective capacity to operate at the level of present operations, which is an absolutely ludicrous proposition—absolutely ludicrous!

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want to ask the Prime Minister to add to the question?
—Order! I will give the opportunity for a few people to test the capacity of the airports early this afternoon if they continue to interject.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Housing and Regional Development. Is the minister aware of recent media reports from the Australian Housing and Urban Research Institute and the National Centre for Social and Economic Modelling commenting on the state of Australia's housing? Can the minister inform the House of the government's response to these issues?

—I thank the honourable member for Bass for her question. It is a timely question in the sense that it anticipates by just a few days the 50th anniversary of the passage of the Commonwealth-state housing agreement. That agreement has been in place as a framework for a great deal of housing policy throughout the postwar period. It has resulted in the construction of nearly 400,000 houses and the housing of about 500,000 additional people during our time in office.

PARA.TAB: In terms of attitudes to housing in Australia, in part some of that research refers to the very high level of satisfaction generally with housing; according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, 86 per cent of Australians are satisfied with their housing. In addition, the ABS has recently indicated, according to a comprehensive survey, that home ownership in Australia is at historically very high levels at over 70 per cent. Further, this government has made a major contribution through the first home owners scheme which resulted in housing about 370,000 people.

There was some reference by the Leader of the Opposition to a report by NCSEM which went to the issue of affordability for housing for low income people. This government's record is that in part we have sought to care for low income people by quite dramatically increasing public housing stock—by about 50 per cent since we have been in office. But we also recognise what was certainly not recognised by the opposition in its time—the fact that a great number of people in the private rental market require housing assistance.

Back in 1983 the level of housing assistance for low income people was around $5 a week—a miserly amount and an amount quite insignificant in terms of what people were paying by way of rent. In our time in office we have increased the maximum rate of rent assistance for single people by around 90 per cent, for families with one or two children by 105 per cent and families with three or more children by 135 per cent. So not only have we dramatically increased the extent of public housing; we have effectively put alongside public housing a very substantial scheme for assistance in the rental market. I emphasise that because it is an important part of comprehensive housing reform.

The Commonwealth-state housing agreement was created in the 1940s as part of a vision for postwar reconstruction. It recognised the needs of an immigration that would be one of the great immigrations of the postwar period. It recognised the needs of growing industry and the provision of public housing to go with that industry. It recognised that we needed to develop policies within the context of comprehensive social policy. That is why when the Leader of the Opposition speaks about poverty and inequality we remember that rent assistance under his government was five bucks a week. We remember that under the previous government public housing was not dramatically expanded; it was cut. We remember that under the Liberal and National parties there has been no articulation of policy and no recognition that there needs to be any kind of public debate—no recognition of the need to involve the public in discussing these kinds of fundamental issues. That is why people are inclined to be sceptical about the opposition, in part because its record—I say this to the member for Kooyong who appears to be trying to interject—is not only abysmal but extremely regressive and in its time in government resulted in a decline in real terms in almost every payment in the social security system. That is why we are sceptical. But your failure to articulate any kind of social policy, to engage in any kind of debate, means we can be quite clear that, apart from scoring the odd debating points, your leader and your party—the opposition party—have no commitment to social reform.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Prime Minister, is on the matter of record. I refer the Prime Minister to his speech at the 1995 national social policy conference on 7 July this year. Prime Minister, you quoted Samuel Johnson, who said:

QUESTION.PARA: In a civilised society, we all depend on each other.
I have not found a better broad definition of what this government is about.

Given that the lowest one per cent of neighbourhoods have lost 23 per cent of their income and that male unemployment has increased from 6.4 per cent to 28.1 per cent, and yet the highest household incomes have increased by 31 per cent and male unemployment has increased to only 4.8 per cent; that there is a 28 per cent youth unemployment in Australia; that there are 1.9 million Australians living in poverty, and 592,000 of the 1.9 million are children; that one in five sole parent families are living in poverty; that one in six younger single people are living in poverty; do you expect the battling Australians you have long abandoned to believe that you will treat them any differently in the future than you have treated them in the past?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We often have the opposition jumping on social analysis and social data trying to make a case—
—Because it is true.
—Order!
—about a change in income distribution and relative prosperity in Australia when they themselves—and I will come to the numbers in a moment—have opposed every wage increase bar one since 1978.
—Are you sure that is true? I don't think it is.
—Order! The member for Mayo—the 4.20 has left.

—They sought to introduce at the last election full medical fees based not on a progressive system such as Medicare—which has a levy across the board and very large exemptions, such as a per child exemption, down the bottom end—but on a system where you will charge, regardless of income, full fees for private insurance and for medical insurance. These are the policies you have followed. You have always regarded the expenditures we have made, such as those on Working Nation—which was about getting unemployed people back into work—as an extravagance. That was how it was described by one of your frontbenchers, then the Leader of the Opposition. Generally you have put no premium on high employment, which has been the main way in which poverty in Australia has been alleviated. As a consequence, we have now seen over 25 or 26 per cent employment growth. In fact, I think it is nearer to 30 per cent, but I need to check that figure. As a consequence, we now have a work force of over 8 million people—we had 6 million people in 1983—household disposable income has risen by 40 per cent, and household disposable income per capita has risen by 21 per cent.

PARA.TAB: In terms of this so-called NATSEM research, what this data does not do is adjust for the size of the household. Relying on that research means that families with several children would have higher incomes than single or pensioner couples. Professor Ann Harding, whom I think the honourable gentleman is relying upon in part for her view, says this:

ANSWER.PARA: In summary, the provision or subsidisation by government of non-cash benefits, such as health, education, housing and community services, has an important impact upon material wellbeing. Excluding them from poverty measures may give a misleading picture of trends over time if the magnitude or type of such non-cash benefit is changing. NATSEM estimate that the addition of the social wage substantially reduces estimates of poverty by nearly 50 per cent overall. For couples with children it is estimated that the social wage reduces poverty from 10.2 per cent to 3.9 per cent, while for sole parents the corresponding reduction is from 22.4 per cent to 4.2 per cent.

It always rings hollow whenever you have a member of the opposition out there worrying about people in the lower deciles of income and poverty because, always through their history—not just the history of the current opposition, but right through their history from the beginning of this century—the conservatives have always been about chopping the guts out of the wages of working Australians. They have always been about chopping the benefits back. They hate working Australians; they are always about cutting their wages.

PARA.TAB: That is why they have opposed every wage increase bar one since 1978. That is why they oppose the social measures and why they attack the social spending. The $10 billion of spending cuts you have in mind have all been cut from families, from the aged; all those cuts in government spending that you have been brandishing around and saying the country needs are going to come from those on the social wage—the very people you are now pretending to represent.

We have seen the opposition this week on wages. We know what they are going to do there. They are going to try to tip ordinary people out of award protection so they will lose up to $5,000 a year. That is what the tough hairy chested ones do. Another one will wander up to the dispatch box saying, `What about the unemployed and those in poverty?' Don't make us sick! Don't make us sick!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Can the minister inform the House whether a bus driver in Sydney earns more than a bus driver in Seoul, South Korea? What conditions of employment are bus drivers in Australia guaranteed under our system of awards?

—The member's question relates to the opposition's assertion here in question time yesterday that a bus driver in Sydney earns much less than a bus driver in Seoul in South Korea. We all remember the question and the assertion from the member for Adelaide. I am now aware of the source of the claim made by the honourable member. It is this document produced by the Union Bank of Switzerland. It is a study called the `Prices and Earnings Around the Globe: 1994 Edition'. I have had a chance to have a bit of a flick through it.

PARA.TAB: According to this publication, a Sydney bus driver earned the equivalent of $US16,000 in 1994. That compares, according to this, with the Seoul bus driver who, it asserts, earned $US16,800. Unfortunately, the basis for the opposition's claim is hopelessly inaccurate. The Department of Industrial Relations advised me that the Australian full-time adult bus driver earns a good deal more than $US16,000. In fact, it has given me the ABS report for the year of 1994, which indicates that the Australian full-time adult bus driver actually earned an average income of $US24,583. That just happens to be 46 per cent more than the figure for the Seoul bus driver in the report you quoted from.

That is not the opposition's only problem, because when you go through the report you find some very interesting things. This report says that in Seoul the old bus driver works a 44-hour week. Guess what the Sydney bus driver works.

TALK.START.PARA: —What?
—He works 38 hours! So there is another little difference—46 per cent more money, and a snip of six hours per week.

PARA.TAB: But hold on—that's not it. If you go on in the report you find that the old Seoul bus driver does not get any annual leave at all—none whatsoever, a big zero. He works 52 weeks of the year, whereas his equivalent in Sydney gets four weeks annual leave. As if all this—the annual leave, the hours of work, the 46 per cent—were not enough, the report goes on to highlight the disparity in living standards between Sydney and Seoul. This is your own report. It indicates that the purchasing power of wages in Sydney is twice as high as it is in Seoul. The Sydney bus driver gets 46 per cent more and his wages buy twice as much. Have you got that? It is worth getting.

It really does make you wonder how much the Liberal Party is paying the driver of the debt bus. If he is being paid according to the opposition's policy he is driving the highway to hell, the low way to hell. The Liberal Party policy would take from that Sydney bus driver or from the debt bus driver, if he is getting the award, his overtime allowance, would take from him his penalties, would take from him his annual leave loading, would take from him his cumulative sick leave, would take from him his award super, would take from him his hours of work provisions. You should look at your reports a little more carefully in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I think at this point we will leave the Leader of the Opposition to his back bench. I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.
