INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received letters from the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) and the honourable member for Banks (Mr Melham) proposing that definite matters of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion today. As required by standing order 107, I have selected the matter which, in my opinion, is the most urgent and important; that is, that proposed by the Leader of the National Party, namely:

PARA.TAB: The contradictions of the Government in its policy approach to key issues, including the operational procedures at Australis's major airports, particularly Mascot.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mr TIM FISCHER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I commend you on selecting this matter of public importance. I am also proud of the fact that my wife is a No. 1 citizen and is at home this day proudly looking after our son, Harrison. Shame on the honourable member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio).

PARA.TAB: There is a sense of deja vu about this. As I delightfully raise and support this matter of public importance, I cast my mind back. I happen to remember November 1975 in another parliament sitting opposite the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton), who was known at the time as the member for Heffron. He was in opposition and I was in government. It was 11 November 1975, which is perhaps why I remember it so well. I happened to move a motion in the New South Wales state parliament in support of the operations of Mascot airport, twin parallel runways on a north-south axis—the building of a third runway, in effect—and expanding the use of wide-bodied jets to reduce the number of jet movements in the area of Mascot. Remembering that there were not many wide-bodied jets in full operation at that time. The Airbus, 767s and others have come on stream since then.

I then looked at the speech given by the Minister for Transport 20 years ago. I find that I am in agreement with some aspects of his speech. Those aspects made up not a bad speech 20 years ago. In the course of that examination of the state Hansard, I found that he was in support of part 2(a) of my resolution with regard to wide-bodied aircraft. But, with regard to the third runway, he got that wrong then, and he has got it wrong now. He spoke up in opposition to the third runway at that time. It is a little embarrassing, as he is the minister who then presided over the completion of the construction of the third runway. He championed its cause when he eventually brought on the official opening at about the worst possible time last year.

It is instructive to go back through the detail of the speech of the then member for Heffron, the now federal Minister for Transport, which he made 20 years ago in the New South Wales state parliament. Some of us have long memories. Some of us will hold you accountable for the complete mess the government has made with regard to the operation of Australia's largest gateway airport.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us what you said back then.
—It is very clear. It is on the record. Will you allow me to table it? Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to table the New South Wales state Hansard with regard to these matters.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move onto the second matter. It really does go to the nub of the matter. It relates to this question of Simops. One particular type of crossover runway operation can be termed Simops. Another kind of crossover runway operation is better known as independent interspersed operation. They are two separate things.
—Which one are you for?

—I will answer that in a moment, Minister. Wait your turn. I made contact as a private citizen, and as an identified federal member of parliament, with an officer of Airservices Australia. What he told me about the Tullamarine operation this month, this week, was pretty interesting. He confirmed that, yes, there were two crossover runways—0927, the east-west runway, and 1634, the north-south runway.

PARA.TAB: He confirmed, as well he might—and it is a matter of public record; it is not confidential—that Tullamarine is used for Simops, known by that name internationally for that type of operation, on a regular basis winds permitting. Separate to that, Tullamarine is also used for independent interspersed operations. The difference is a technical one. When they are using it for Simops, it is when they are using both runways for landings interspersed and one runway for take-offs at the same time. That is Simops. When they are using it for independent interspersed, it is when they are using the north-south runway for landings, for argument's sake, and the east-west runway for take-offs, which is the frequent pattern to maximise usability.

I thought I would test this at the coalface. I have a contact, who is not well known to me but is one I respect, who operates as a captain of pure jet aircraft here in Australia. Earlier this month, he chose to land, as part of his program and schedule, at Tullamarine in that particular jet. He landed into the south. He decided upon taxiing in to just check with the tower because he noticed the aircraft were taking off east-west on this particular occasion while he was landing interspersed on the north-south runway. The tower at Tullamarine replied, `This is the preferred runway operation for maximum utilisation—planes taking off to the west and landing from the north.'

That is the absolute answer to the lies perpetrated by this government with regard to the debate over the future use of Mascot. What the coalition, what the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), is responsibly proposing is to provide the intersection to be where it is most controllable and most safe, and where it is the logical place to provide it—that is, on the ground at Mascot—as opposed to the government's alternative operation of Mascot which is to provide the crossover of aircraft traffic at low altitude in the suburbs to the north and south of Mascot.

This diagram makes it very clear that you are in fact crossing over aircraft in their approaches and departures from Mascot at different altitudes with interspersed operation, I fully accept, but you choose to do it at low altitude over the suburbs of Sydney. We would choose to do it within the boundaries of the aircraft in the maximum controlled safety environment involved.

So I say to the Minister for Transport that you cannot have it both ways. You cannot argue that it would be wrong to resume the full operation of the east-west runway, even allowing for the displaced third runway further to the east and its operation, and on the other hand argue that it is okay to operate Tullamarine on a Simops basis. Minister, for all I know, as the winds may abate in Melbourne, they could have resumed Simops at Tullamarine at this moment.

Simops, the thing you will not allow to happen at Mascot, is operating at Canberra airport. As members flock to the airport in the next hour, have a good look at the runway you use. Have a good look at the cross runway. Those of us travelling on flights direct from Canberra to Albury tend to get shunted on to the cross runway where we wave goodbye to all our colleagues taking off in jets on the north-south runway at the Canberra airport. The minister really is exposed on this particular point.

I would like to go on to talk about the airlines directly. It is interesting to hear that a couple of weeks ago Ansett and Qantas came out and said that they did not support the opening of the east-west runway. Some of their management have intimated otherwise in private discussions with members of the coalition. I am not going to do the wrong thing in regard to those discussions. I respect the confidentiality of the people involved. It actually goes further than that. There are papers around indicating that the major airlines have fought long and hard with regard to the operation of the east-west runway and the problems created by its closure.

I have a document from Hazelton Airlines. That airline is not to be sneezed at because it is a substantial commuter airline operator, a decentralised commuter airline operator and a publicly listed commuter airline operator which has modernised its fleet and withstood drought and everything else that the state and federal governments have thrown at it from time to time in relation to the intrastate licensing scheme which is operated by your colleagues—they were mine in the past, regrettably—at Macquarie Street. What does Hazelton say with regard to this particular matter. Their media statement of 25 September 1995 states:

SPEECH.PARA: The two largest independent regional airlines operating in New South Wales, Hazelton and Tamair, today called on the Federal Government to reopen the east-west runway and implement long overdue changes to air traffic management procedures.

The airlines believe that a substantial reduction in the levels of noise now affecting thousands of Sydney residents can be achieved by introducing changes to air traffic management procedures which will also increase the number of aircraft movements and further reduce delays at Sydney Airport.

That is the direct opposite of what the Prime Minister was saying with his hub nonsense here this afternoon. Hazelton Airlines, which you spit on, Minister, has done the hard yards in developing decentralised links. SAAB aircraft—

TALK.START.PARA: —No jets east-west. Stub operations only.

—We are not talking about stub operations. They have called for the full east-west runway operation. The minister is rather embarrassed by this very clear-cut statement. Clearly he could not have heard the first paragraph. There it is in absolute terms. He made the same presentation very directly to a number of us in Parliament House.

PARA.TAB: Can I say with regard to this matter of public importance that there is another and related matter with regard to the reopening of the east-west runway. I refer to yesterday's Hansard, which happens to record the results of a very interesting division. I find five names here—they are Keating candidates in particular seats around New South Wales—who voted against the reopening of the east-west runway and by that action jeopardised commuter airline flights from Lismore, Orange, Albury and elsewhere.

The members involved were M. Easson—she has now long since departed from Mascot and will probably land on a Simops crossover runway in Europe, try Paris or Frankfurt—N.J. Newell, D.W. Simmons, J.H. Snow and H.F. Woods. Here are Keating's candidates in the Hansard voting to jeopardise their air links and undermine decentralisation in the process. They have been exposed in their electorates. Their electorates will make a judgment on them I hope on 4 November, otherwise 11 November—the sooner the better. If not, they will make the judgment in February or March 1996. Those electors stand ready to throw out those members who have voted against the interests of their electorates.

We come back to another aspect which the minister will dwell on. It relates to the asset sales, which the shadow minister for finance—the member for Forrest (Mr Prosser)—and the member for Hinkler (Mr Neville) remind me have been an area of massive underperformance by this government. How dare you suggest that we will not be able to handle asset sales efficiently. Let us look at your record. For the financial year 1990-91 you put in the budget $1 billion of asset sales. What did you achieve—$161 million. In 1991-92 you put in the budget a target of $625 million of asset sales. What did you achieve in that year—$301 million. In 1992-93 you put in the budget $1.6 billion of asset sales and what did you achieve—$801 million. It is a pretty shabby record with regard to the actual performance of the government in its asset sales.

We will capably manage asset sales and privatisation in a proper manner with due reference to community service obligation and with due safeguards to the national interest and to the interests of the community at large. It is interesting that the government has bracketed both Sydney West and Sydney as part of their privatisation process.

I say in loud and clear terms—and I look forward to being supported by the member for Hume (Mr Sharp) with regard to this matter—that the crunch time has come with regard to Mascot. Its operation is regarded as a laughing stock by international airline operators worldwide. They are fed up with the extra delays at that level. At the local level, those travelling from Orange to Sydney are fed up with a 29-minute flight taking 54 minutes and with automatic extra tracking by virtue of the navigation system imposed on the crazy runway operation at Mascot.

It is time for the minister to come clean, to swallow hard, to get it right and to reopen the east-west runway on an independent interspersed operational basis, which would not only reduce and spread the noise funnel that has been created by this government with regard to the operation of Mascot but also make more efficient and effective, as well as protect the safety of, the operation of Australia's most important gateway airport. It is time, Minister, for you to depart. It is time for us to take over the Treasury bench and reopen the east-west runway at Mascot.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brereton The Hon L.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BRERETON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Transport)

TALK.START.PARA: —If ever there were proof that the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) should have stuck to farming, it is his contribution this afternoon in the parliament. Certainly, there is no place for him in modern aviation. Can I begin by saying thank you to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) both for the opportunity to speak and for reminding me of my long consistency in respect to the affairs of Kingsford Smith airport. It is a great pity, it is a dreadful shame, that he cannot boast the same consistency, because what he is arguing today and what his whole party have been arguing this last week since this madhouse decision of theirs to reopen the east-west runway for jet operations is absolutely inconsistent with everything they have collectively stood for for more than 20 years now.

PARA.TAB: Why are they doing it? They are doing it for the basest of political motives. If you look at the map of all of the surrounding seats, it is very clear that there are only two seats that are truly highly marginal, and they are both on the alignment. There are actually three—there is one of ours, but it is nowhere near as marginal as the other two. Lowe is our seat at 5.1 per cent, which is reasonably marginal, but the two really marginal seats are Bennelong with 3.2 per cent and Cook with 3.5 per cent. They are at either end of that parallel runway configuration. In the case of Cook, the village of Kurnell—the Kurnell you could not give a hang about when you were campaigning for this runway configuration—is also being dramatically affected.

When this airport expansion was announced in 1989, it was announced on the basis that there would be a north-south axis for traffic, because that is the only way you could get the throughput that is necessary to meet the demands for Australia's No. 1 international gateway, our principal airport—the one that overwhelmingly carries traffic, international and domestic, in Australia. Every day 75 international jets come in or go out of Mascot airport. Right from the very first moment it was the north-south axis that the airport was to operate on. Indeed, the environmental impact statement was predicated entirely—

TALK.START.PARA: —You're wrong. Gary Punch thought he had failed.
—The honourable member interjects. Let me just announce to him the submission of his colleague, Nick Greiner, to the EIS in December 1990 when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The number of people seriously affected would reduce from 54,700 to 26,900. Those moderately affected would reduce from 170,000 to 82,000. However, new areas will become exposed to aircraft noise and some areas will be exposed to higher levels of aircraft noise.
This is the actual New South Wales government's submission, the Liberal submission, to the EIS:

The decreases would be in the east and the west with moderate reductions to the south but increases to the north. The noise outcome is a logical conclusion as those movements arriving from the north on the third runway are much higher over urban areas because of its staggered threshold 3 kilometres south of the existing runway's northern threshold.

When I talk of inconsistency, what was the Leader of the National Party saying a little later? He could not say that he did not know: he had had chance to study the EIS after it was published, with this attachment from the New South Wales state government. This is what the man proposing this matter of public importance this afternoon said publicly on 13 August 1991:
Any further delay in deciding on the third runway for Mascot could mean loss of life . . .

What was he talking about? I will tell you what he was talking about. He was talking about that series of questions that had been raised about what would have been the world's worst accident. The accident in Tenerife was the world's worst accident to date with two wide-bodied jets. On that occasion, had that Boeing 747 of Qantas which was parked at the intersection been taken out by the Ansett domestic jet and the Thai Airways DC10—there were only three seconds in it—it would have been, heaven forbid, the world's worst accident. That was the concern. That is what the Leader of the National Party was speaking about then when he said:

Any further delay in deciding on the third runway for Mascot could mean loss of life as well as economic insanity. With Mascot now operating at near maximum capacity, air traffic controllers bending over backwards to extract maximum efficiency out of the present archaic runway set-up, the risk factor must greatly increase.
He went on to say the following month:
The EIS has already found that a third runway would mean an overall reduction of more than 50 per cent in the total number of residents affected by aircraft noise.

If you didn't know where these 50 per cent fewer people were going to be, it's a mighty strange state of affairs. There you are saying that you have studied the report and you know that there are going to be 50 per cent better off. The report says there are going to be some people worse off and they are going to be on the north-south axis. But you had this absolutely hypocritical act of saying this week that the cross-runway should be reopened, even though every piece of expert advice says the opposite.

PARA.TAB: I have seen some funny things, some weird things, in 25 years in public life but I have never seen anything that exposes people as badly as this exposes the opposition. I have spoken to all the experts. I am pleased that the Leader of the National Party referred to Max Hazelton as one person who was in favour of the east-west runway. Max has been to see me. I sat down with Max.

TALK.START.PARA: —When?
—I have sat down with him a couple of times.
—This week?

—No, not this week, but I have got his written advice. Max Hazelton is a very honourable man. If he puts a submission to me on behalf of the regional airlines, I think it is serious: I take it seriously. These were his words:

SPEECH.PARA: To give maximum capacity it is imperative to open 0725 runway for regional aircraft (Saab 340s, Dash 8's, Metros, smaller aircraft) that have a very low noise factor.
He said:
In fact, a bus on the road would make more noise.
He went on to say:
Every non-jet aircraft taken out of the mainstream traffic flow—
that is, the north-south axis—
allows more jet traffic onto 16/34—
that is, the two north-south runways. He said:
There should not be a noise problem as this procedure has been used for many years.

This is Max. I know where he is coming from. I know that this week other people's names have been thrown around very carelessly indeed. BARA was one that was mentioned as being in favour of jet operations on the east-west runway. BARA was quoted in the context of the Senate inquiry. I have correspondence here from Lucio Cadone, who is an honourable man, who says that BARA has not made a submission to the inquiry nor has it given any evidence at the hearings currently being conducted by the Senate select committee. Secondly, BARA has not called for the reopening of the east-west runway.

PARA.TAB: What are you fellows saying? Let me go through a couple of others. The Civil Air Officers Association of Australia has been quoted. I do not want to delay the House, but the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) went through the press release of Mr Lorschy who is the president of that body. He felt obliged to republish his evidence to the Senate committee. Senator Parer asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Are you suggesting that cross runway operations are not safe or just less safe?
Mr Lorschy responded:

They are less safe. They rely more heavily upon the skills of the aerodrome controllers in judging the point of conflict set up between two aircraft operating on the cross runway set up. At the moment with parallel runway operations any conflict is removed from the precincts of the airport itself.

You come into the House and you talk about Hazelton, BARA, and the Civil Air Officers Association. It is just the opposite. Today you threw in a new name: Tony Williams. Tony Williams is a decent poor soul, but he has no status. He has no formal qualifications in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did Richardson employ him?

—Just because someone has been employed in some capacity many years ago by some government does not qualify the fellow to cut down the advice to government. Let me go through that advice because it is not just the Civil Air Officers Association that has given us advice. The Civil Aviation Authority gave us advice and said, `Don't do it, minister. Don't do it.' Air Services Australia went further. They said they would not let us do it. They reaffirmed their position on 14 August saying that while parallel runways were available at Sydney airport it—that is Air Services Australia—would not be prepared to restore simultaneous independent operations using east-west runways in intersecting operations with the parallel north-south runway system.

PARA.TAB: The Civil Aviation Safety Authority is charged with the responsibility of guaranteeing safety. This is why you fellows are in trouble. This is madhouse stuff. The position you have taken is indefensible. With regard to the Civil Aviation Safety Authority we see remarks such as `new leadership' and `world best'. The shadow minister has praised this body so generally. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: To me the Civil Aviation Safety Authority is of the view that the restoration of Simops procedures at Sydney airport while parallel runways are available would be less safe than the current parallel runway system in operation.

It is as clear as a pikestaff. Having been cut down yesterday in respect of Los Angeles and Heathrow—in fact every airport you mentioned—you come in here today and throw in a couple more. Today you threw in Adelaide and Melbourne. The traffic in Melbourne is 134,000 movements compared with Sydney with 239,000. Adelaide has 96,000 movements. Of course you can do all sorts of things safely when you are moving only half or one-third as much traffic. It is dead easy. We are talking about the lives of all those people who come in each day on those 75 international jets—not to mention all the domestic aircraft.

PARA.TAB: I repeat: this is why you are in so much trouble. When you get into trouble you seem to go further and further in. In the debate this afternoon the Leader of the National Party of Australia was reflecting on the integrity of James Strong and the general manager of Ansett Airlines, Graham McMahon. Mr Fischer said that the airlines had done a backflip and that they had been dragged screaming. Let me read to the House exactly what they said because it is terribly serious advice. These people are terrified of what the opposition has in mind—and why wouldn't they be? Their experts have told them—and they know—that this cannot be done. However, if they do not agree with you they are cut down.

TALK.START.PARA: —Bucketed.
—And they are bucketed. Mr Fischer said:

SPEECH.PARA: The airlines are now part of an official extended Labor family, which included the Reserve Bank Governor, Bernie Fraser, and was part of a network which the ALP cheerfully and capably used.

That is what the Leader of the National Party said at his doorstop today. The airlines' Graham McMahon and James Strong are part of the ALP official extended family. It used to be reds under the bed. Now it is reds in the air and reds in the banks. This is the most bizarre thing, quite frankly, that I have seen in all my time.

PARA.TAB: Nothing will get the opposition off the hook that they—and only they—have impaled themselves on. It is a very big hook indeed. What they have done defies all credibility. I repeat that it is, quite frankly, the most stupid thing I have ever seen proposed by someone who holds himself out to be the alternative government of this nation. Why? For a handful of votes in his own marginal seat, the most marginal seat in all of those many seats surrounding the airport, according to the map published in the Sydney Morning Herald this morning. Bennelong is on 3.2 per cent, or maybe it was a bit of Cook on 3.5 per cent. You could say that perhaps he was trying to put a bit of a line up on Lowe—our seat—on 5.1 per cent.

The reality is that this is driven by four days of a no aircraft `noisemare' in the town hall at Hunters Hill, and he is terrified. He has seen the writing on the wall. He saw what happened in the state election. The Liberal for Gladesville was defeated by the Labor Party for one reason: the electorate knows the hypocrisy of the opposition on this aircraft noise question. They know where they came from. They know the full history. You cannot treat them with contempt. They are much too smart to be conned at this late hour of the day by someone with all the form and track record of J.W. Howard. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abbott Mr A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is one reason and one reason only why the government has been so stunned by the `not for sale' sign hung out by the Leader of the Opposition and member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) over Sydney airport: it is that the Prime Minister and member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) now wears Australia's privatisation crown. It is now the Prime Minister, and no-one else, who wants to sell off the family silver. It is the Prime Minister who is worshipping at the altar of economics. It is the Prime Minister who has swallowed the economic textbook. It is the Prime Minister who would sell his grandmother if he thought he would get a decent price for her. Fear is spreading through the ranks of the ALP because it has been stuck with this unpopular privatisation policy. Fear is creeping across its back bench the way the bald spot is creeping across the Prime Minister's scalp. Just the other day the Prime Minister boasted to caucus about the fantastic scare campaign he was going to run against the opposition. The fact of the matter is that our policy is to open Badgerys Creek airport. Our policy is to send the big jets west. Our policy is to reduce noise all round. Please, please, Prime Minister, run a scare campaign on that. That is not scary at all. The only people who are scared by the coalition's policy—and I can see them arguing like cats and dogs up the back there now—are the Prime Minister's own backbench.

PARA.TAB: The other thing the Prime Minister told his caucus the other day was that he was going to keep the faith. He said, `Keep the faith, fellas. Hold on.' What is the Prime Minister's faith? It is quite clear that the Prime Minister's faith is nothing but privatisation—privatisation whatever the cost, privatisation whatever the pain, privatisation whatever the electoral discomfort it causes to his own people. The Prime Minister now wears the privatisation crown like his paramount chief headgear. There he is—the Prime Minister, Chief of Privatisation. The Prime Minister wears his title, Sir Paul of Privatisation, like he wears his Thai knighthood. The Prime Minister will be made to wear his degree—Dr Paul Keating, PhD in Privatisation—like he wears his Japanese doctorate. He will wear this crown. He will not be allowed to get away with it.

The fact is that this move of the coalition has completely confused members opposite; they just do not know what to say. On the one hand, we are big spenders; the next minute, we are terrible cutters. They cannot decide whether we are wimps or ogres.

If the Prime Minister wants a contest in hairy-chested economic rationalism, good luck to him because we are not going to compete. He is the one who now wears the privatisation crown and he will wear that like a crown of thorns until the next election when his government will be crucified on the cross-runways of Sydney airport and all the lies that they have told about this issue.

What does privatisation mean? According to two experts in today's Sydney Morning Herald, privatisation means that Badgerys Creek will never be built. It means that Sydney west can remain `an intention' forever. This government's privatisation bill contains no requirement that the private operator must construct Badgerys Creek, places no obligation on the private operator to shift in the near future or at all from Kingsford Smith to Badgerys Creek, establishes no statutory limits on the operation of Kingsford Smith, and creates a competitive environment which acts as an incentive to maximise aircraft and passenger movement through Kingsford Smith. That is the truth. This government's policy means that all the people of inner western Sydney will be prisoners forever of Kingsford Smith airport. They have a life sentence to aircraft noise under the privatisation policy of this government.

The problem with this whole third runway is that it is not a third runway at all; it is a replacement second runway. The so-called third runway was supposed to mean more flights and less noise. In fact, it has meant less flights and more noise. The so-called third runway was supposed to mean aircraft landing and taking off over Botany Bay. It has not meant that at all. It has meant aircraft landing and taking off over the homes of more and more Sydneysiders. The so-called third runway has been a $200 million failure.

Under this government the incredible has been achieved—two plus one equals two. That is a feat of mental gymnastics worthy of the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence). You have to ask yourself: who is to blame for this? According to Graham Richardson and Laurie Oakes:

SPEECH.PARA: Keating is the one people should be mad at. He not only got the third runway decision through cabinet but was responsible for changes to the original plan which are now causing massive problems.
Mr Keating proposed that the new north-south runway be fully operational from both directions and the old east-west runway be virtually made redundant.Get that?
`Get that', say Laurie Oakes and Graham Richardson. The people of Sydney will `get that'. They will know that the author of their discomfort is none other than the Prime Minister himself. Continuing:

The original proposal was supposed to be that aircraft should take off only to the south and land from the south so that they flew over water rather than houses. Clever Keating changed that and sent them roaring over suburbia.

That is why the member for Barton (Mr Punch) so strongly backed the Prime Minister's campaign to stab the former Prime Minister in the back. And that is why the people of Sydney will blame the current Prime Minister for all the misery and all the agony that this so-called third runway has inflicted on them and which the government's privatisation policy is just going to make worse.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister is the chief villain in all this, but he is not the only villain. The Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) has been making a mess of this issue ever since he roared off into the middle of the night on his Lambretta with the Prime Minister's ballot boxes on the back in 1969.

What is the record of the Minister for Transport? He sold ANL to the British, he sold Qantas to the British, and he is going to sell Sydney airport to the British. No wonder he is a republican! Everything else has been sold to the British. He has been a hopeless Minister for Transport, but he has been an arch-political manipulator.

The Minister for Transport knows a lot about rezoning. He knows an enormous amount about rezoning in Botany. The real agenda of the Minister for Transport is to rezone his electorate, to make it aircraft noise free, and dump all the noise on the electorate of the member for Lowe (Mrs Easson). The Minister for Transport, in conjunction with the member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay) and the member for Blaxland, have dudded the member for Lowe. They have dudded Mary Easson in the same way as they dudded Michael Easson when he wanted a seat in parliament. Of course, we all know about the member for Watson. His only contribution to transport policy was by falling off his bike around Lake Burley Griffin.

TALK.START.PARA: —He likes water sports too.

—Indeed he does. But don't tell us about the love boat, please. The Minister for Transport talks about safety. The cheek of him! Today he even called upon Bernie Fraser to back him up when he talked about aircraft. That is how desperate he is—he has to call on the Governor of the Reserve Bank to back him up on a safety issue. The only person, apart from the Governor of the Reserve Bank, that the Minister for Transport was able to call on to back him up was the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister keeps saying that the old east-west runway intersects with both north-south runways.
—Dyslexic.

—Someone said he is dyslexic. He is blind as well. He was talking about Portnoy's complaint the other day. We all know what that is. He is suffering from Portnoy's complaint. He does not have a clue about what Sydney airport really looks like. If simultaneous operations are a problem, the Minister for Transport had better close down nearly every other major airport in Australia—as well as O'Hare airport, which uses simultaneous operations and has four times the number of aircraft movements that Sydney airport has.

PARA.TAB: This is not about the member for Bennelong's electorate. This is about truth. The truth is that the Labor Party has betrayed the people of inner western Sydney for too long. When the member for Bennelong speaks out on this issue, he speaks for Sydney—for the whole of Sydney and for all those people who have been used and abused by the Labor Party for far too long.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melham Mr D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The proposer of this matter of public importance, the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer), came into this parliament and challenged the government to table his private member's motion that he moved in the New South Wales parliament. We accepted his challenge. What has it revealed? The documents are now before this House and they reveal that the current Leader of the National Party, when he was the member for Sturt in the New South Wales parliament, moved a motion that contained the following paragraph:

SPEECH.PARA: Urges the Commonwealth Government to—

PARA.TAB: (b) Construct twin parallel runways along the north-south axis to cater for future needs and provide a substantial reduction in the noise problem over residential areas.

SPEECH.PARA: Do the hypocrisy and the cant stop there? No. In his speech in the New South Wales parliament on 11 November 1975, at page 2476 of Hansard, the Leader of the National Party said:

. . . The construction of a second north-south runway would reduce the noise problem in Sydney suburbs now affected by aircraft movements. The suburbs to the east and west of Mascot would gain particular benefit, and suburbs to the north and south of Mascot would also enjoy relief. The proposal caters for an expansion in traffic.

PARA.TAB: A second runway would overcome the necessity this century to proceed with the construction of a second airport for Sydney. It simply will not be needed.

SPEECH.PARA: Here is the clincher:
Acceptance of this solution would mean that cross runways would not have to be used.

That is the direct opposite of what the Leader of the National Party is now arguing, together with the Leader of the Opposition, the member for Bennelong (Mr Howard). They are not my words. They are the words of the Leader of the National Party when he was a member of the New South Wales parliament. So let us nail the hypocrisy of the opposition. The reason that they are interested in this proposal now has nothing to do with policy. It is not policy driven. It is driven by the polls. It is driven by those seats on the north-south axis—the seat of the member for Bennelong, the Leader of the Opposition, where the margin is only 3.2 per cent and the seat of Cook where it is only 3.5 per cent. And we have just had the election to Hunters Hill of a mayor from the No Aircraft Noise Party. Also, it is directed, in effect, at shoring up the opposition's position.

PARA.TAB: In today's editorial of the Financial Review, the lead question is: `Who is the real John Howard?' You only have to turn to the article on page 4 by Christine Wallace to see the answer. She writes:

Howard the policy man is clearly subservient to Howard the political animal in this third runway gambit. The ploy reflects his true political nature. Howard has always been a pragmatist and in the run-up to the election he will do whatever it takes to try to win office.

SPEECH.PARA: That is why they are concerned about what is happening at Sydney airport. That is why they are concerned about the east-west runway—for pure, crass political motives, not for policy reasons. However, it has backfired on the Leader of the Opposition because the past has come back to haunt him.

PARA.TAB: I think the headline on the front page of the Financial Review says it all `Howard's crash-landing; aviation industry denounces Sydney airports proposals'. What the opposition is now doing is exactly the opposite of what it has been preaching for over 20 years. This is evidenced by what the Leader of the National Party said in the New South Wales state parliament on 11 November 1975 and by various other quotes. They were leading the cheer squad, as was the then New South Wales Liberal-National Party, for the construction of the third runway. But it is their pollsters who are driving the opposition agenda at the moment. It is a policy free opposition but it is one driven by the pollsters.
I was the beneficiary of a fax from Republic Advertising Pty Ltd dated 6 February 1995, which was in the lead-up to the budget. This is what the pollster was advising the opposition:

SPEECH.PARA: Surely the object till budget time is to make every welfare recipient feel like they are about to lose it and if they don't lose it this time they'll lose it next time.

That is their approach on Mascot, Badgerys Creek and the east-west runway; it is all poll driven. They think there are votes in it. Their hypocrisy will be and has been exposed for what it is because the record speaks for itself.

PARA.TAB: Is that the only area in which the opposition is driven by the polls? We no longer see the other half of the dream team, the member for Higgins (Mr Costello), parading around as often as he did. He was the battlers' friend. The pollsters are now telling the Liberal Party that he is not going so well in voterland, so they have pulled him back a little. That is what has happened to the member for Higgins.

When it comes to French testing, the opposition is driven by the opinion polls. For the first time in 20-odd years we now have bipartisan support. Previously it was the members of the opposition—and it is all there on the public record—who were supporting French tests in the Pacific. We saw the U-turn by the Leader of the Opposition after the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) delivered his blueprint for a republic. Again, it was poll driven. We have a poll driven opposition. It poleaxed the former member for Wentworth, Dr Hewson. It poleaxed the other half of the dream team, the member for Mayo (Mr Downer). We have the third Leader of the Opposition in this session of parliament. He was not the first choice, he was not the second choice but he became the third choice. They are asking us to accept him as an alternative Prime Minister. The electorate is too smart for that.

This debate on Sydney airport and the third runway, when you cut through it, will be a turning point in the lead-up to the next election. It is the crassest example of naked political ambition by those opposite. They are not interested in going to the next election on policies or principles; they are interested in going to the next election on what votes they can grab. The phones are running hot from their own constituency because one of the good things is that it is all on the public record.

The Leader of the Opposition was the leader of the cheer squad for the opening of the third runway. But now he has a marginal seat; now he thinks he can pick up the seat of Lowe so he comes out with this crass, politically opportunist solution. That is all it is. He is a policy free zone but he is not a poll free zone. Is that the sort of person the electors want as their next Prime Minister? I think not and I know not.

I think the tide is turning because, in the end, it is a question of choice. How can you have the Leader of the National Party talking in here about contradictions in the government's policy when he, as a state member of parliament, talked about the need to close cross-runways and the east-west runway? It is hypocrisy of the highest order; it is all about winning votes.

The electorate is too sophisticated for that. That is why the commentators are screaming. The front page of the Australian Financial Review, a paper hardly known as a sympathiser of the Australian Labor Party, talks about `Howard's crash-landing'. They scored the greatest own goal since Escobar in the World Cup—and he was carried out in a coffin. The Leader of the Opposition and the Leader of the National Party, in their tactics this week on the airport, have dug their own political grave because they have exposed themselves not only to the gallery but also to the electorate at large as hypocrites, as wanting office not by any policy or principle but by pollsters. (Time expired)

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Mr Bilney) proposed:
That the amendments be agreed to.
Debate interrupted; adjournment proposed and negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will not be opposing the amendments that we are now examining, but we believe they are not the most satisfactory approach that could have been taken on this matter. We argued in the other place—and my colleague Senator Amanda Vanstone, the shadow Attorney-General, moved an amendment—to ensure that the government's proposals, which would have dramatically increased the reporting requirements on large exempt proprietary companies, were amended so as to ensure that these companies would continue under the existing reporting requirements if they wished to do so. The amendment would allow them to continue to choose between having an auditor or lodging simple key financial data.

PARA.TAB: The government's proposal, as we understood it before the amendments, was to force these companies not only to have an auditor but also to lodge financial returns. Under the Corporations Law, exempt proprietary companies were able to choose between appointing an auditor or lodging key financial data. The government in failing to support the amendment showed itself to be no friend to the business community—and that, after all, is where many jobs come from. Many businesses raised concerns about the bill with the coalition. The cost of undertaking a full audit, which the bill now requires, was a particular concern. That is the reason we picked up that argument and advanced it in the other place.

Despite the fact that the government has rejected our amendment and maintained the existing proposal—that is, for reporting requirements for large exempt proprietary companies—there were in the way in which this matter was dealt with some good news for businesses affected. The coalition was successful in getting the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities to review the bill for a second time. Because we pushed for that review the government agreed to clarify the conditions under which the Australian Securities Corporation can grant an exemption from audit. This could be of benefit and ought to be of benefit to a significant number of companies that had concerns about these new requirements. So there is this exemption proposal. We do not regard it as the best option but it is obviously an improvement.

We were also successful in ensuring that the small/large distinction will be reviewed after two years of its operation. In this way we can assure business that a comprehensive review will be undertaken. So we will not be opposing these amendments. They go part way to improving the bill. It could have been further improved if the government had been so minded, but regrettably in this case they were somewhat obdurate—

TALK.START.PARA: —Bloody-minded.

—I thank the minister for his comment, which I certainly hope Hansard picked up. I would hate to think that something like `bloody-minded', which is not language I would use readily in this House to describe the government's conduct, was part of the Hansard record. As I say, the matter can be reviewed further. It will come up again in two years time and at that time we can see how these provisions have operated.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted that the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs (Mr Bilney) is at the table. For the next five minutes, I am going to talk a little about the ministerial modus operandi of his senior minister, the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans). I am afraid that some of what I have to say will not be terribly complimentary.

PARA.TAB: Nobody doubts the foreign minister's deep intellect and high profile when it comes to some of these international matters, such as nuclear non-proliferation, comprehensive test ban treaties and his latest trip to the 50th UN General Assembly. I say to both the ministers at the table, the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs and the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Walker), that when it comes to consular matters, particularly in looking after some Australians—some might say that they are very mundane matters—the foreign minister is very weak.

We do not have to go any further than a comment that was made by our shadow minister, the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), yesterday in relation to an ongoing sore, which is the case of Dr John Flynn. The honourable member for Mayo said:

SPEECH.PARA: What Senator Evans fails to realise however is that principal amongst the functions of the Minister for Foreign Affairs is the protection of Australian citizens abroad. It is a matter of profound disappointment that Senator Evans has failed to give his full attention to the care and treatment of Australian citizens abroad.

There are simply too many instances in which friends and families of Australian citizens caught in terrible situations abroad have been driven to complain directly against Senator Evans for his neglect of their cases. The Wilson, Maresh, Martino, and Flynn cases are all examples of ministerial neglect.
Although John Flynn's case is another case of ministerial neglect it is not too late to act in order to give John Flynn the treatment to which he is entitled as an Australian citizen.

I take this opportunity to pay tribute to the contributions that have been made by the shadow minister and Senator Michael Baume in the other place in this case, which continues to cause difficulties both here and in New Delhi. A few weeks ago I received a letter from Tim Eakin, John Flynn's solicitor, who said in part:
Dr Flynn has been under administrative detention in the notorious Tihar Gaol, New Delhi, for nearly 15 months.

During Dr Flynn's detention, our Department of Foreign Affairs and High Commission in New Delhi have failed to ensure that he is treated justly and in accordance with law and applicable international conventions. His health is in a precarious condition.
This situation came about after Dr Flynn was apprehended in June last year—

on suspicion of attempting to smuggle coins out of India. His subsequent detention has been protracted because of administrative and legal malice in India aided by bureaucratic lethargy in Australia. His case reflects great discredit on the Governments of both countries.

I do not have time to go into the detail of why Dr Flynn is being mistreated at the moment other than to say that very strong inducements and duress were involved. His health is suffering. He has suffered detention without trial. The bottom line is that the Australian government has been distinguished only by its lack of application to Dr Flynn's wellbeing. The day before yesterday, his lawyer once again put out a very strong media release to that extent. I would like to be attributed with it.

PARA.TAB: Since Minister Bilney has departed, I say to Minister Walker, who is at the table, that there are several questions I would like to place on the record to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Firstly, does he still have faith in the Indian legal system that has treated Dr Flynn fairly? Secondly, does he believe that justice delayed is justice denied? There is a perception that the Australian government has not pressed Dr Flynn's case because they think he is guilty. Does the Australian government think that Dr Flynn is guilty?

The department has said that it cannot interfere in judicial proceedings of another country unless an Australian is discriminated against on the basis of nationality. That has been done. I just say to the minister that, in opposition, we will continue to hound the foreign minister. In government, we will put in train a number of ministerial, diplomatic and consular initiatives that will enhance the situation of Australians travelling overseas. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —As is well known in this House, the Australian Labor Party is a strong supporter of local government. Indeed, it was the Australian Labor Party, through the Brisbane constitutional convention of 1985, which eventually got the question of constitutional recognition of local government to a referendum. It was the conservatives of this country who totally opposed that constitutional recognition of local government. In Victoria's local government we see that they not only hate Australian workers but also hate democracy and local government.

PARA.TAB: I have long been a supporter of rational amalgamation and restructure of local government in Victoria. There were in fact 210 councillors in Victoria when I served in local government. But my support for amalgamation and restructure is not support for what the Jeffrey Gibb Kennett government has achieved in Victoria through his political apparatchiks. When I say `political apparatchiks', that is exactly what they were because the local government board was headed by a Liberal Party member.

Instead of the community being asked what sorts of changes they wanted, it was totally imposed upon local communities. For example, the old Mansfield shire was amalgamated with the city of Benalla. To give you an idea, the entire town of Mansfield closed down in protest for being lumped in with another body without any consultation. The way this amalgamation was done really has been a major political embarrassment for the government in Victoria. The boundaries are a joke and, of course, politically inspired.

They say they have in fact improved local government in Victoria. Yet they have created municipalities such as the shire of Strathbogie, which will now be known in Victoria as the New Pyalong. Pyalong was one of the very small municipalities for some 650 ratepayers. Pyalong has gone but they have created Strathbogie in its place—a municipality which does not conform to all of the research which indicated what should be done to local government in Victoria.

The politicisation of the local government system in Victoria has been compounded by the fact that, instead of calling for elections and letting democracy take its place in the restructured areas, political appointees were put in as commissioners. That is no secret. Some 27 per cent of the people appointed, called commissioners—it is almost Stalinist—are members of the Liberal Party. The chief commissioner is paid some $90,000 and the two other commissioners—they are not chiefs—are paid some $60,000 a year. They have given themselves mobile phones, new cars and fax machines, along with all of the perks of office on top. The commissioners are in fact costing a hell of a lot more than the volunteer councillors who used to run local government in Victoria.

The commissioners are not responsible to the people whom they purportedly represent because they are not elected. In fact, none of them live in the municipalities over which they now have dictatorial control. These commissioners in Victoria are dictated to by the Minister for Local Government and the local government board. For example, Kennett said that they would cut rates by 20 per cent uniformly across the state on these new councils irrespective of whether that is good or bad for the district or whether they could afford it or not.

We know that the commissioners are dragged in on a regular basis and told what to do by the local government board—Leonie Bourke, the political apparatchik of Jeffrey down there. We see some nonsense taking place. For example, in order to achieve some of these so-called cheaper rates, we are now seeing some very bodgie accounting.

Most of us here have a rough idea of what revenue is and what income is. Would anyone here agree, for example, that $3 million worth of asset sales and a $1 million transfer from reserves is income? It is a one-off and it is not income, yet we are now seeing local government accounts in Victoria showing one-off asset sales as income. They are showing transfers from reserve as income. That is the reserve that former democratically elected councillors put aside for capital works. They are bringing these reserves back in on their current income account and saying, `We have a surplus.'

A shire like Yarra Ranges, for example, shows a surplus of roughly half a million dollars. It is actually running a $4 million deficit. Right across Victoria these shonky accounts are now coming out as the Kennett government's shame in local government is being exposed. There is no democracy, but shonky accounting and commissioners running councils in a Stalinist style not for the benefit of the people but for the benefit of the Liberal Party of Victoria. It is a shame. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr E.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to speak on behalf of a constituent of mine, Cherry-Dell Phillips. Cherry-Dell is a very special lady who works extremely hard for the community and for charity groups in Stirling and around Western Australia.

PARA.TAB: Cherry-Dell contacted me the other day about a deceptive method alternative telephone carriers are using to sign up new customers. The carriers are doing this by offering charities and other organisations benefits by getting them to enlist their subscribers or members. They do this by bulk buying or hiring lines off Telstra at reduced rates, and then renting these lines to customers, via a charity or organisation, with the offer of cheaper rates for the customers, plus benefits to the charity or organisation through whom they apply for the connection. Cherry-Dell wrote to me about this. Her letter stated:

SPEECH.PARA: I signed with the Cancer Foundation thinking by the conditions written on them that I was getting a reduction in the cost of my calls and that the annual rebate could help the Cancer Foundation.

On getting my Telecom bill, I discovered that my service was taken over by another carrier. Now this also means I lost my sole parent concession. Fly buys have been cancelled, and any other existing flex plans I had as a customer with Telecom have also been cancelled.
In getting a discount, Cherry-Dell was meant to receive a six per cent reduction, but only received three per cent—another deception. She goes on:

What I object to is the dishonesty in this deal—the use of charities and organisations names to draw subscribers away from their existing service. These people can steal customers away from Telecom and yet Telecom are not permitted to let their subscribers know what is lost by their signing with these other carriers. It is okay if that is explained what we are signing, but it is not clear. Age pensioners are vulnerable because if they sign, thinking they are just getting a discount, they then discover they have lost the Telecom pension concession, and may not know why.

What happens essentially is that members of charities or organisations receive an offer asking, for example, `Do you want a discount on your telephone bills and to help this charity at the same time?' Of course it sounds like a great deal, so people tick the box saying yes. What they do not realise, as Cherry-Dell pointed out, is that they will be disconnected from their existing carrier and connected with a new one who has bulk bought or hired the lines off Telstra.

PARA.TAB: Some organisations or businesses also rent out the lines to charities and the like, so instead of charities or whichever group renting or buying the lines in bulk off Telstra direct they get them second hand from another organisation who is buying or renting the lines off Telstra. So some organisations are buying or renting the lines, and I imagine they are then writing to charities or sporting clubs or the like and saying, `Have we got a deal for you.' They would offer the organisation the opportunity to offer their members and subscribers discounts on telephone calls plus, for every member they sign up, the organisation would get a donation. They just do not tell them that they will be disconnected from their existing carrier, and that is where I agree with my constituent.

If they told people the whole story that would be fine, but people are being disconnected from their existing carrier without their knowledge or consent. As was pointed out to me by Cherry-Dell, if the customers are on a flexi plan, pension benefit or even in Fly Buys they will also lose that benefit, unbeknown to them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shameful.

—It is absolutely shameful, as the member for Fisher points out. It is not until a few months down the track that they actually find out. I think the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee) needs to address this scam. People who are renting off Telstra are being conned to join other carriers when they want to remain with Telstra. Telstra is aware of this but at this stage can do nothing. It is time for the minister to do something.

—As you would be aware, Mr Speaker, this Saturday at the MCG we host another premier sporting event in Australia—the AFL grand final. This year the grand final will be fought out between the Geelong Football Club—I represent that city in this parliament—and the great Carlton Football Club.

PARA.TAB: I take this opportunity to wish the President, players and officials of the Geelong Football Club all the very best in that contest on Saturday. It is going to be one of the great titanic struggles in Australian Rules between two sides that have earned the respect of the sporting world in this particular code. I will tell you, Mr Speaker, at the end of this adjournment speech who is going to win that game.

This is the fourth grand final that Geelong has contested in seven years which, by anybody's measuring stick, is a great achievement. We have recently seen at the club changes in coaching personnel, changes in playing personnel and a restructuring of the club. Yet it has managed to propel itself to the very top of the league table in this premier football code in Australia.

Some very important changes have been made to the coaching staff. I would like to pay tribute here tonight to the efforts of the very young coach of Geelong, Gary Ayres. Gary came to the club from the Hawthorn football club, the famous Hawthorn stable, and has a real wealth of finals experience behind him. He has brought a new dimension to the free-flowing Geelong game, and he has brought some great stability to the players of the club.

But my heart tonight, 48 hours away from victory, goes to the President of the Geelong Football Club, Ron Hovey. Ron has been a great stalwart of the Geelong Football Club for the past three decades. I know from speaking to him earlier on in the week and speaking to him last week before the preliminary final that this particular game and this victory will mean a lot to him, as they will to the people of Geelong.

I would like to pay tribute here also to the efforts of Malcolm Blight, the coach who preceded Gary Ayres at the Geelong Football Club. As far as Malcolm was concerned, his coaching style well suited the players at the club. There are many players playing on Saturday in this great event who owe a lot to the efforts of Malcolm Blight.

This game means a lot to the city of Geelong, because it gives the city an opportunity to profile itself in both a sporting and other sense to the rest of the nation. As you would know, Mr Speaker, in recent years Geelong has been hit by recession, by industry restructuring and by the financial collapse of the Pyramid Building Society. But the people in the city are a very resilient people. They have come through that period of their history with flying colours. The total weight of the city now sits behind the Geelong Football Club and the players in this contest on Saturday.

To the players, let me say this: these opportunities to play at this national level and to play in one of the premier sporting events of the world come very rarely in one's sporting life and those opportunities must be grasped with both hands. I will give this advice to the players that was given to me in my `illustrious' football career: play like there is no tomorrow, show them no mercy and take no prisoners. If you want to put a little wager on it, Mr Speaker: Geelong by 27 points.

DEBATE.SUB2.TITLE: University of Queensland: Conservative Action Team

TALK.START.PARA: —When I listened to my colleague opposite, the member for Corio (Mr O'Connor), talking about the AFL grand final, I was wondering whether he was going to tell us that he had been offered a place in the team because he is obviously a very strong supporter. My only regret, of course, is that there is not a Queensland team in the AFL grand final. One can only hope that the situation will remedy itself next year.

PARA.TAB: I came into the House tonight to congratulate the conservative action team at the University of Queensland which recently won the union elections. Before I come to that particular matter, I want to comment on the remarks made by the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) when he criticised the actions of the Victorian government with respect to local authority amalgamations. When he criticised the Victorian government, he could well have been criticising the Goss Labor government, which has really forced very many local authorities into a situation of amalgamation without consulting the local communities at all.

We have had a situation where the residents of the shires of Rosenthal and Allora and the city of Warwick were forced into an amalgamation. When the citizens of one particular shire took the matter to the Supreme Court, the state government just arbitrarily postponed the election and put it off. It is absolutely amazing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite extraordinary.

—It is extraordinary and outrageous that there should be these kinds of changes in local authority boundaries without the consent of the local people. But it did not stop on the Darling Downs. The city of Ipswich and the shire of Moreton were amalgamated in a special election just 12 months after the local authority elections which took place throughout Queensland. The state minister arbitrarily sacked all the councillors and called fresh elections for the amalgamated local city. What he did was pass one area of Carole Park away from Moreton shire and put it into Brisbane, leaving that area totally without representation until the next general election of local authorities.

PARA.TAB: The same thing happened when he took the area of Fernvale and put it into Esk shire. Again that area did not have any representation. Mergers were forced between the city of Gympie and the shire of Widgee, the city of Cairns and the shire of Mulgrave. The city of Mackay and the shire of Pioneer and the city of the Gold Coast and the shire of Albert also merged.

These amalgamations have taken place without the consent of the local people, without a referendum, without giving those people any choice as to whether they want to maintain the pre-existing situation or whether they want to go into an amalgamation.

It is interesting to hear the honourable member for McEwen coming into the chamber and complaining about the Victorian government. He could equally be complaining about the actions of the Goss Labor Government which could well lose office on the basis of a by-election in Mundingburra which may be called following an appeal to the Court of Disputed Returns. So we have an interesting time ahead of us in Queensland.

The University of Queensland Union for the last little while has been controlled by the Left of the Labor Party. The people who have been running the union have abused the money belonging to the union members. In fact, we find that they have been using union funds for obscure and unacceptable political purposes without the consent of the student body.

TALK.START.PARA: —Typical.

—It is typical. Consequently, I was very pleased that the conservative action team ran in the recent University of Queensland elections and most of the members of that team were successful. I would like to congratulate Jody Thomson, who is the new president for next year; Luke Myers, secretary; Michael Barry, treasurer; Heidi Pietzner, general vice-president; Kathleen Vromans, welfare vice-president; Matthew Cavanagh, education vice-president; Natasha Bowden, activities vice-president; Ben Wilson, colleges vice-president; and Amanda Hausler, national student affairs officer.

PARA.TAB: This union is one of the few student unions in Australia not to join the National Union of Students. I think it is absolutely outrageous that in Queensland students at the University of Queensland are forced to be in the student union. They have not got the right to choose whether they want to join or whether they do not want to join. It is absolutely outrageous that this situation is permitted to continue by the Goss Labor Government. I believe that the unacceptable activities of the left wing of the ALP, which has controlled the University of Queensland Union up until recently, have resulted in such a swing to the conservative action team. I also congratulate the Australian Liberal Students Federation on the excellent job they do on university campuses throughout Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 August I moved a motion in the House of Representatives calling for a joint federal-state inquiry into the Hilton Hotel bombing in 1978. This followed, in 1991, the unanimous decision of the New South Wales parliament calling also for a joint federal-state inquiry. Since that time another motion has been passed in the New South Wales parliament, again calling for a joint federal-state inquiry. I notice that a similar motion to mine is now on the Senate Notice Paper for debate over there.

PARA.TAB: It is high time we got to the bottom of who was responsible for the bombing of the Hilton Hotel. I believe there are no further excuses. We need this joint federal-state inquiry. To not have an inquiry will mean that we will never get to the bottom of who committed these crimes. It is the worst unsolved murder case in Australia's history. It was an embarrassment to Australia. I believe there will be a suggestion of a cover-up if people are not going to support an inquiry into this.

Bob Carr, the Premier of New South Wales, has supposedly opened the files held by the New South Wales government on this matter. When Terry Griffiths, one of the victims of the bombing, went down to look at the files he was told that eight particular files were restricted: he could not look at them. When he phoned the Premier's office to ask why, he was told that the New South Wales government had opened the files but the Commonwealth government had placed restrictions on eight of those files. I would like to know why that is. There may be a very good reason.

Indeed, it is a debating point as to whether it is a good idea to just throw open files to the public anyway, given the sensitive nature of this issue. But, whatever the merits of that, it is high time we got to the bottom of this sordid issue and had a joint federal-state inquiry.
