SPEECH.PARA: We don't only represent, as we proudly do, the interests of small business and the interests of private enterprise but we also represent those hundreds of thousands of Australian men and women who work in a very effective, faithful and conscientious way in both the state and federal public services and, as I've said on an earlier occasion, you don't advance the cause of the private sector by denigrating the public sector. The public sector has an honoured place. It provides many important services and it is comprised of hundreds of thousands of men and women of enormous commitment and dedication to the future of this country.

Indeed, the Leader of the Opposition reiterated this statement recently by saying that the Australian Public Service has nothing to fear from a coalition government. He made it quite clear at the most recent annual general meeting of the ACT division of the Liberal Party when he said:
Upon the election of a coalition government at the next election, we will not be adopting, as perhaps some have suggested, a slash-and-burn attitude towards the federal Public Service.

The Public Service is very important to Australia and to have an independent Public Service of good quality is very important to the implementation of any government's policies. I commend this bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak on the Public Service Legislation Amendment Bill 1995 which effectively amalgamates the Public Service Commission and the Merit Protection and Review Agency. I am particularly pleased to speak after the member for Canberra (Mr Smyth) who, like myself, is an ex-public servant. The member for Canberra has not been around all that long, as is quite obvious from some of his comments not only today but also on previous occasions in the House, when he said that the public servants of Canberra have nothing to fear from a coalition government. I was in the public service when Malcolm Fraser was Prime Minister and did we not have a lovely time then in the public sector! It was industrially unruly. Certainly in the history of the Public Service there were more industrial disputes in the period 1976 to 1983 than in any other period. That was because of the attitude of the Fraser government to the Public Service, which was far different from what we were led to believe by the member for Canberra a few moments ago.

PARA.TAB: There was legislation such as the CE(RR) Act and the CEEP Act, which was very draconian legislation and took away basic industrial rights of public servants. I even recall—this is testing my memory—that the public sector unions, as they were at the time, did not have access to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. There was a separate public service arbitrator set up by the Fraser government which was very heavily loaded in favour of the government. Public servants and their unions could not even take industrial disputes to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission as it was then. So much for the Liberal Party's attitude towards public servants!

TALK.START.PARA: —Public servant numbers grew during that period.

—I do not know whether or not that is true. When the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) was Treasurer there were terms like `the Phil Lynch razor gang' and `snouts in the trough'. There were allegations that public servants were bludgers and we had the famous name `dole bludgers' for the unemployed. Those were all very much flavour of the month expressions in the late 1970s under the Fraser government.

PARA.TAB: The bill gives effect to the government's decision announced in the l995-96 budget to amalgamate the Merit Protection and Review Agency and the Public Service Commission to form the Public Service and Merit Protection Commission. Presumably, it will be known as the PSMPC.

The Public Service Commission was set up in 1987 following the 1987 election. Massive changes were made in the public service on Bastille Day, 14 July, 1987, when a number of smaller departments were amalgamated into super-departments such as DEET, as we call it now, and Human Services and Health which was called Community Services and Health. It is fair to say that some of the decisions at the time did cause concern amongst public servants, in particular the trade unions who have not always agreed with anything that any government has done.

One of the significant changes in l987 was the abolition of the Public Service Board and the devolution of the functions of the Public Service Board to individual departments—responsibility for selection procedures and recruiting, et cetera. Also, many of the functions of the Public Service Board were passed on to the Department of Industrial Relations, the Department of Finance and the newly formed Public Service Commission, which was a much smaller version of what had been the Public Service Board.

The Public Service Commission has approximately 150 staff. The other half of the equation is the Merit Protection and Review Agency which was set up by the Hawke government in 1984 and commenced operating from 1 July l985. The MPRA brought together a number of other smaller bodies such as the Promotions Appeal Committee, the Disciplinary Appeal Board and the Redeployment and Retirement Appeal Committee, which needed to be brought in after the Fraser government's redeployment and retirement legislation. The MPRA also deals with a number of other public service matters, such as grievances, under the various public service regulations. It is a very important part of the Public Service, as has already been said today.

The right of appeal against promotions, as the member for Canberra correctly pointed out, is a very important part of equity and the merit principle in the public service. We have not always had the merit principle.

I inform the member for Canberra that, under the Fraser government and governments before the Fraser government, it was all about equal efficiency and seniority. Indeed, in the past I had the good fortune to win two appeals in the Promotions Appeal Committee. In the first situation, another person was put onto long-term higher duties ahead of me on the basis that he was senior; he had been there for 30 years and I had only been there for 12 years. I managed to knock him over in the Promotions Appeal Committee, but I will come back to that. There were concerns about some of the changes that were made in the 1980s and there were concerns in 1986 when, under the streamlining provisions, access to the Promotions Appeal Committee was limited to fairly junior officers and up to middle management officers. In today's language, access was granted up to the level of ASO 6. Senior officers and senior executive service officers do not have access to the Promotions Appeal Committee, but they do have access to the Merit Protection and Review Agency for grievances and other matters to do with process.

The merit principle is important and it is enshrined in the Public Service Act. I particularly refer to section 33, which talks about prohibition of patronage and favouritism, and, of course, section 33.3 deals with all forms of discrimination. I used to teach people about these things in the Public Service. Discrimination is illegal on the grounds of race, colour, sex, sexual preference, religion, age, marital status, pregnancy, social origin, ethnic origin and physical or mental disability. There is one other form of discrimination and it will come back to me in a minute. The words `mental disability' worry me a bit. As I said only a week ago in this chamber, the words used should be `intellectual and psychiatric disability'.

The Promotions Appeal Committee—and, indeed, the MPRA itself—is there to protect public servants against discrimination, patronage and favouritism and it is very important that the committee be maintained. The committee has been maintained—albeit in a different form since it will be amalgamated with the Public Service Commission—and its integrity is maintained, which is a very important thing.

There were concerns raised by the Community and Public Sector Union as to whether this legislation ensured the independence of the MPRA and concerns were also raised about resourcing matters, as has been pointed out already. However, I understand that there were discussions and that the concerns were largely overcome in this legislation. This legislation does protect the independence of the MPRA—and the Public Service Commission, for that matter—and it does not have any adverse resource implications for these bodies.

My own experience in the public sector was as a trade unionist in the Department of Health. As a unionist, obviously I had to represent people who had been discriminated against. I also experienced discrimination myself—usually because of my trade union activities—and sometimes I was given a hard time.

From 1979 through to 1993 when I was elected to the House of Representatives, I was only promoted once in the Public Service without the need for an appeal. A job came up and the selection criteria required that I sit an aptitude test. Obviously I did fairly well because I got the job. Whenever a promotion was up to a selection panel of Public Service managers in the department I never seemed to score a promotion, but, on a couple of occasions, I did manage to take the matter to the Promotions Appeal Committee—once, as I have described, on the basis of long-term higher duties, when I was passed over because the other person was more senior. This situation can no longer occur under this government's reforms, but it was very much the go under conservative governments in this country.

The Promotions Appeal Committee was created by a Labor government—the Chifley government—back in the late 1940s. A fairly important point to remember is that this decision arose out of the sectarianism that dominated the Public Service in those days; it was rife. Depending on which department you were in, you either had to be a Catholic or a Mason to get promotion in the Public Service.

Of course, Catholics and Masons are not known for loving each other or particularly liking each other, but there was an unwritten power-sharing agreement between the Catholics and Masons. Depending on which department you were in, you were either one or the other. You would be in a department that was either a Mason stronghold or a Catholic stronghold, and you were usually looked after. If you were neither Catholic nor Mason, you were in a bit of trouble in the Public Service in those days. You also had to be a male, as I recall, to get on in the Public Service because, before 1949, women could not be promoted. They could not even get into what was then the third division until 1949. In fact, until 1966, if you were a female in the Public Service and you got married, that was no good. You had to either `live in sin', as it was called then, or resign or become a temporary employee.

Things have come a long way in the Public Service under this government, I am pleased to say. We have preserved the Promotion Appeals Committee which was set up in the late 1940s to overcome sectarian bias within the Public Service. As I said, I was fortunate not only to win two appeals myself but also to help a number of union members whom I represented, by preparing their cases and enabling them to have successful appeals—which I thought was a pretty rewarding part of what I used to do.

The second occasion when I won an appeal was in 1989. Ironically enough, it was for the position that I had held previously but that was being upgraded: of all things, the position of equal employment opportunity officer. I was passed over for that job and was rated unsuitable because management did not want me in a job like that when I was a union delegate, and that is basically what it came down to. I was rated unsuitable, but I fronted up to the appeal and was unanimously successful, which was very unusual and did not really please the department very much.

That is an illustration of the fact that it is important to have the merit principle, that it is enforced and that there are safeguards. I note with interest the concern and the scaremongering in the community about the government's unfair dismissal legislation as it affects the private sector. How dare we have due process in the private sector, and how dare we have a fair go for people who are wrongfully dismissed! I do not believe that any employer has anything to fear from due process.

Certainly, there are times when you have to sack somebody if they have done the wrong thing, and there are also provisions in the Public Service now for people to be disciplined and eventually dismissed if they have done the wrong thing: if they have stolen or they have hit somebody or whatever. There are procedures to be gone through, and those procedures should also apply in the private sector. If somebody has done the wrong thing or, for whatever reason, an employer has fair and reasonable grounds to dismiss somebody, then they can do that. But I also think that there are plenty of times when that is not the case, and that people should have a right to be represented in a due process, and that is why we have the unfair dismissal legislation. It is also why in the public sector we have, and we need to have, the existence of the Merit Protection and Review Agency and the merit principle enforced, as it is to a large extent because of the provisions of the Public Service Act, and section 33 in particular.

I support this legislation. As with a lot of other pieces of legislation in the Public Service over the years, there are always concerns about change and sometimes they are quite justified concerns. I must admit that, in the past, with another hat on as a trade unionist and as an employee in the public sector, I have not always welcomed some of these changes. But you can fairly say that the Public Service today is far more efficient and better managed than it was in 1983, when this government came to office.

As I said, I do have a pretty long memory about the Public Service: I have been a public servant since the early 1970s and I have been active in the trade union movement in the Public Service since the late 1970s, so I have a memory of some of these issues. It is fair to say that the Public Service, warts and all, is more efficient today. Nothing is perfect, but we do have a very efficient Public Service with a lot of hardworking people, as the member for Canberra pointed out, and the existence of the MPRA goes a long way towards ensuring that that remains the case. I believe it will continue to be the case under this legislation, which, of course, amalgamates the MPRA with the Public Service Commission. I commend the bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief because most of the points that need to be made about the Public Service Legislation Amendment Bill 1995 have already been made. This is a turbulent time in management in the public and private sectors. There has been a lot of debate about how to encourage the growth of efficiency whilst retaining humanity and effectiveness and an orientation towards meeting the goals of organisations. That kind of debate has occurred just as much in large private organisations as within public ones. I do not think the debate has, in any sense, concluded.

PARA.TAB: There is a tendency for some people to say that the public sector should be treated in exactly the same way as the private sector. I question that. The goals of private organisations and public sector organisations, or the public service at least, are significantly different. The public sector is there to deliver goals, to serve the public, to make accessible the services that are best provided in common with the whole community and to do that in a way that ensures that they are accessible, equitably available and effectively and efficiently delivered. To a large extent the private sector overlaps with that but, of course, their bottom line is making a profit. In a sense, the goals are narrower. Equity does not have to be one of the goals of the private sector. Accessibility is important but it does not have to be a top priority in the way it does in the public sector.

The public sector should, by definition, be working for the common good while private enterprise is working for shareholders, for management and employees and also for consumers. A good private enterprise will have a balance between those goals but that balance is not always as well achieved as it might be, any more than in the public sector the balance between efficiency, effectiveness, accessibility and equity are achieved as well as they ought be.

It is important that we continue with this debate about how best to deliver public services. Some of the reforms that the government has introduced, including devolution to departments for responsibility for a lot of personnel management, will probably contribute to that but, given that the devolution has occurred, it is also important to have somebody that has the task of ensuring that departmental heads and senior officers administer their staff fairly and in a way that ensures that their rights are preserved.

The Merit Protection and Review Agency is a very important element of doing that. It is there to provide an external appeal body which can be available to anyone who feels unfairly treated. It was very important that the agency be established. It does not matter greatly whether it stands by itself or as part of the Public Service Commission.

It is ironic that, in the report on reform of the Public Service commissioned by the government, the proposal to combine the Merit Protection and Review Agency with the Public Service Commission was explicitly rejected and yet it has been decided to do it. Anyway, I do not think it matters greatly. The important point is that the chair of the Merit Protection and Review Agency retains her independence. That ensures that her tasks will be pursued with impartiality and a commitment to fairness and that the government will continue to fund the organisation effectively, therefore enabling it to do its work.

It is very important as a guarantee, as a visible reminder to public servants, that they can appeal if they feel wronged in any way. The work of the agency, I know from the personal experience of constituents who have come to me, as I am sure the member for Canberra (Mr Smyth) is also learning, is very valuable. It is very helpful to us to be able to refer them to the MPRA. It is also important that we have confidence that the MPRA does its work impartially and I have every confidence that it does.

I am glad to be able to support this legislation, particularly because I want to reinforce the value of what the MPRA does and also to urge public servants generally to continue this debate about how best to ensure humanity not only in the delivery of services but also in personnel management within departments.

TALKER.NAME: Mr JOHNS
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State, Assistant Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I would like to close the debate by thanking those members who have taken part in it—the member for Ryan (Mr Moore), the member for Canberra (Mr Smyth), the member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) and the member for Bonython (Mr Martyn Evans).

PARA.TAB: It is a reasonably narrowly based debate but it has broadened out and it is important that I make some comment to rebut some arguments that are being given, especially by the members for Ryan and Canberra. The member for Ryan suggested that the McLeod report, which was an investigation established by me to be used for rewriting the Public Service Act, had somehow recommended against the amalgamation of the MPRA and the PSC. It did not recommend that. It had a preference for leaving those bodies apart but it did not recommend against amalgamation. But neither did the McLeod report—and this ought to be written down and remembered—have a brief on machinery of government matters. It did not have a brief to discuss whether there would or would not be amalgamations, which I call machinery of government matters.

It was up to the government to make up its own mind on this, and it would have been anyway no matter what Mr McLeod had said. I get a little bit tired of people, having established reports and having them received by the government, then believing that somehow that report is written in stone and that the government needs to accept the findings. We sent people away to do a major exercise, the rewrite of the Public Service Act, with a major level of consultation, but governments not only reserve the right to make their own decisions in the end; they must do so.

We are bound to make decisions about what we consider to be meritorious. We use reports that we have established to give us a guide, to give us a feel for the debate, but no more than that. However, having said that, of the 118 recommendations of the McLeod report, cabinet accepted 112 recommendations. It was a successful report in the sense that it reflected accurately the sorts of changes that needed to be made and in that the government concurred.

A point made by the member for Ryan was that this may be an uncomfortable situation where the MPRA, which was seen to represent the interests of individual public servants, and the Public Service Commission, which is seen to represent the interest of management, the bosses, should somehow be housed in the one organisation. He does not understand that, with the changes over the last number of years and especially with the changes ensuing from our rewrite of the Public Service Act, the responsibilities for personnel management will rest fairly and squarely with departmental secretaries. The PSC is not an arm of management. The key decisions about the conduct, hiring practices and so on of public servants will be made within the law by heads of department. That ought to be made clear so that there is not even an implied conflict between the roles of the PSC and the MPRA.

However, it seemed to me that great strengths would derive from the amalgamation. These are not large organisations—the MPRA especially—and although they have some outposts outside Canberra, it is very difficult for them to bring in any staffing power to those regional headquarters. Through the amalgamation we may have some strengthened regional presence under the new commission. I know that the amalgamating bodies are putting together their heads, and their resources, to ensure that the roles of the old PSC and the old MPRA can be delivered at regional centres outside Canberra. That is a strength that we hope will arise from the amalgamation.

Another consideration was to ensure that the MPRA, which had been deciding particular cases, should be well informed on personnel policy, and that the PSC should learn from those cases when it comes to the question of drawing up policy. There had to be an intimate flow of material and understanding between the two groups. I think it was happening and it ought to happen now. The quality of that interaction will be improved somewhat by the amalgamation. The discussions about cooperation between the two groups are well advanced. I recently appointed Dr Peter Shergold to head the commission. He has been in discussions with Ms Ann Forward, the director of the MPRA, and they are getting on famously.

I might also use this opportunity to thank Mr Dennis Ives, the former commissioner, whose five-year appointment came to an end recently. He has been a sterling and outstanding public servant and has undertaken great duties as the Public Service Commissioner. I wish him well in his future role in the Public Service.

The other point was made by both the member for Ryan and the member for Canberra. The member for Canberra said that he took us on trust, and that the role of the MPRA would remain, that is, the statutory obligation for looking after the merit principle. You do not have to trust us. It is in law. We are not affecting the powers—

TALK.START.PARA: —Like the l-a-w law tax cuts.

—It is here. You need to understand that this bill does not affect the powers of the commissioner or of the director of the MPRA. It is in that sense a minimal amalgamation. It is a re-housing; it is an opportunity to make sure we get the greatest efficiencies in the staffing of the two organisations; it is an opportunity for them to have a stronger regional presence, should we be able to do that; and an opportunity for them to work more intimately together. But it does not cut across the statutory obligations of either the commissioners or the director. It cannot—
—Read your lips.

—Yes, not only read my lips, read Hansard and read the act—take it to bed. It is not changing. We are not for turning. What some other government might do in the future I cannot say. I always had the view that the MPRA was a very small organisation hanging out there in the wind, and I would not mind betting that the coalition would have knocked it off, had they come to power. They have less regard for those sorts of matters. Over 12 1/2 years, we have consistently had a very high regard for the importance of individual public servants having access to an independent tribunal in order that their grievances could be heard, and this has been taking place since 1984.

PARA.TAB: There are some other matters on the question of Public Service numbers, which I do not really need to address, but nevertheless they have been raised by the member for Canberra. The member for Canberra will remember that he asked me in the House, and he has written to me, about the impact on Public Service staffing as a result of the running costs program announced in the 1995-96 budget. The answer is in the budget papers, as you know, and published there—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an indicative number in the budget papers.

—It is an indicative number because we give managers the money to manage their departments, and one component of that is salary money. Depending on how they manage running costs, there will be an output on the numbers employed at the end of the year. We can provide only an indication. I think the indication will become more accurate. I am sure we will give an answer wherein we give an update on that indication. But the entire notion is that we did not set a level of numbers of public servants.

PARA.TAB: In fact, we said—as part of the drive for efficiency, not only in the public service but also in the private sector—that we would have to make considerable savings in the public sector as a result of the 1995-96 budget. So we had to tighten our belts too. But that goes to the question of running costs—not that of public servants, as such—so we can make only a reasonable prediction. As I say, the prediction we made has been published in those papers already. We would be happy to update it as we learn more. But it really is a matter for the managers of the public service to see how they can best manage that money.

The other question raised is the hoary old one of the War Memorial and the MPRA's investigation into it. I cannot say a great deal about it, because the matter is before the courts. But I will reassure you, as I have a number of newspaper journalists who keep getting it wrong—as did Crispin Hull, most recently, in the Canberra Times. Firstly, quite clearly, I operated on the basis of the powers in the act when I said that the MPRA should undertake its investigations into the War Memorial. Secondly, I did so on the basis of very good evidence. It included evidence that was given to me by the MPRA, evidence that came to us from the CPSU—the union—and the view of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, who was consulted on the matter on the way through.

This is public. It has been known. I have said it a number of times. I wish Mr Hull and others could get this one right: we were as one. There was considerable unease about matters at the War Memorial and we used, quite properly, the powers available in the act to see if we could assist in those matters. The matter is now before the courts and I cannot say any more on that.
I think that covers my response to all the matters raised by the various members. I am very pleased with this amalgamation, and I support the bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Motion (by Mr Johns)—by leave—agreed to:
That the bill be reported to the House without amendment.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Standing Committee of Attorneys-General: Human Rights

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 23 August 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) What items on human rights were placed on the agenda of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General (SCAG) in Perth on 14 July 1995.
(2) Who placed each item referred to in part (1) on the agenda and what was the outcome.
(3) When will the next meeting of SCAG be held.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Commonwealth's written report placed before the meeting of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General on 14 July 1995 referred to a number of human rights issues. These included:
The draft Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples;
The United Nations Commission on Human Rights;
The draft optional protocol to the Convention Against Torture and Other Cruel Inhuman and Degrading Treatment and Punishment;
Complaints under the First Optional Protocol to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and other communications procedures;
Cooperative arrangements between the Commonwealth, States and Territories regarding complaints under the international communications procedures;

Reporting under the Convention on the Rights of the Child, the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the Convention Against Torture and Other Cruel Inhuman and Degrading Treatment or Punishment;
The Convention on the Rights of the Child Draft Protocols;
The reference to the Australian Law Reform Commission on Children and the Justice System;
The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission inquiry into the Removal of Aboriginal Children;
Disability Anti-Discrimination Legislation
Racial Hatred
Sex Discrimination Amendments
The Review of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission
Enforcement of Human Rights Determinations
State of the Nation Reports by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner
State of the Nation Report on People of Non-English Speaking Background
Australian Health Ministers Advisory Council National Working Group on Mental Health Policy
Report by the Federal Race Discrimination Commissioner on the Provision of Water and Sanitation in Remote Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Communities
SCAG Working Group on Human Rights
Human Rights Forum For Non-Government Organisations
Other items on the agenda included
Female Genital Mutilation
International Transfer of Prisoners
Treaties and the Response to the Decision in Teoh
Aboriginal Justice Issues
Gender Reassignment

(2) Most items were raised in the context of the Commonwealth Attorney-General's Human Rights Paper which serves to inform States and Territories about the Commonwealth in this area. With regard to the outcome of these agenda items, discussion of them in the Standing Committee is on-going. As far as the separate agenda items which relate to human rights are concerned, all States and Territories have agreed to legislate to specifically ban the practice of female genital mutilation. In relation to the International Transfer of Prisoners item model legislation is currently being drafted. Gender Reassignment was placed on the agenda by the Northern Territory. The item on treaties and the response to the decision in Teoh's case was placed on the agenda by the Commonwealth. With regard to the outcome of these latter 2 agenda items, as with Aboriginal Justice Issues, discussion of them in the Standing Committee is ongoing.
(3) The next meeting of SCAG will be held in Adelaide on 2 and 3 November 1995.
